description:
Came here this past Thursday and was blown away with how good the sushi tasted!

It's a small restaurant so expect a wait, but it's completely worth it once you get in. They also have outdoor seating as well in front of the restaurant.

We ordered miso soup, a crunchy california roll, a Domo roll, and a Temptation roll. Everything came out super quick to us!

I've tried a good amount of sushi places in San Francisco, but the minute I tasted our first roll I was absolutely SOLD on this place as being one of the best sushi restaurants in SF. The sushi tasted fresh, flavorful, and the prices were very comparable to other sushi in the city.

Our personal favorite was the Domo roll, I would highly recommend you get that if you come here! 

No doubt that we will be repeat customers.
author: James D.

description:
I waited 20 minutes for a table, but it's a small place so it was not surprising. I had never been here before and didn't do any research in advance, so didn't know what I was getting myself into. Thankfully, everything was delicious! I started with a sweet potato roll and a red dragon roll (on special) - both great! I also ordered a hot sake, and put in a second sushi order: sake (salmon) nigiri and another sweet potato roll. My server was attentive and made great suggestions throughout the evening, and it was great sitting at the sushi bar. 

Great food, and an enjoyable experience. The restaurant was pretty dark but not so much so that I could not read the menu. Highly recommend!
author: Bri T.

description:
Recently grabbed a Domo Roll from here. It's essentially a Lion King Roll (the most common name) with scallops added in. I thought it was pretty good but not great which in my world makes it a 3 star venue. The servers were friendly, would be nice if this place had a flat screen as some other sushi spots have since there was a big game going on when I popped in and that would have been reason for me (and I'm sure others) to dine in and order more. As it was there was no one in the venue when I came to pick up my order. 

Domo Roll $14 
baked california roll with salmon & scallops outside, spicy mayo, unagi glaze, tobiko & scallions
author: Rod M.

description:
My friend took me here after I was craving a good dinner and having a bad day.  Thankfully she knows me well because usually when I have a bad day, it gets fixed with either good company or good food, or a good (and usually spontaneous) travel plan.  Domo did NOT disappoint.  I rarely give five stars, but I really did not have much negative to say. In fact, I would have to say it was the best sushi (nigiri) that I have had in the Bay to date.  Things that I tried (and she left it to my jurisdiction): 

uni shooter (appetizer)
scallop shooter (appetizer)
Hamachi Carpaccio
Daddy Roll (special of the day)
hamachi belly nigiri
salmon belly nigiri
snow crab nigiri
uni nigiri

Shooters: uni + scallop
PROS:
- good presentation: very clean
- pure, not too complicated: the uni came on top of avocado which complements texture wise but doesn't overpower that of the uni.  The scallop came out super clean and sweet, slightly torched but definitely not even close to being overcooked or fully cooked.
- quantity: the pieces of scallop and uni were very large and they were generous with their portions.
CONS:
- NONE

Hamachi Carpaccio:
PROS:
- great amount of fish, definitely shareable
- not overly seasoned with the sauce
- fish was fresh
CONS:
- NONE

Daddy Roll: tempura roll with salmon on the inside, fish roe (tobiko?) as well as topped with salmon on the outside (possibly smoked, but I cannot remember sadly)
PROS: 
- good quantity: huge amount of fish/filler and plenty of roll pieces to share
- good flavors and well balanced: not too much rice, the tempura and salmon on the inside were able to come through
CONS:
- could have a bit more fresh fish on the inside but I tend to be more of a fan of raw fish versus cooked fish.  The balance was fine, this is more of a personal preference.

Snow Crab Nigiri
PROS: 
- good quantity of snow crab
- very filling
- crab was not too salty (some snow crab come ridiculously salty from the salt water that it is frozen but I could be mistaken)
CONS:
- not as sweet as I would prefer, then again, it is not snow crab season.

Hamachi Belly Nigiri
PROS: 
- super generous with the fish
- hamachi belly was super flavorful: anything belly is, but this was an incredible rich but light and clean flavor
- not overpowered by the wasabi underneath: I honestly feel that sometimes too much wasabi can kill a piece of really amazing nigiri.
CONS:
- NONE

Salmon Belly Nigiri: this is probably one of my favorite types of nigiri.  It's not easy to find as well although I seem to have found it 
PROS: 
- very generous with the fish like the hamachi belly
- not overpowering with the wasabi
CONS:
- cut was probably a tad bit thinner than the hamachi belly, but if I were to assume that because salmon is richer in flavor, it would be too overpowering to have as thick of a cut similar to the hamachi.  That being said, this was probably more of a preference than a con.

Uni nigiri: from Hokkaido.  Can't go wrong.
PROS:
- super generous with the uni
- super fresh uni: Believe it or not, I've actually had spoiling uni, in Hawaii of all places, where the uni tasted metallic.  My friend told me later after a bout of GI issues that the metallic taste was consistent for uni-gone-bad.  No issues here at Domo!
CONS:
- NONE

I would hands down come back here.  There is no real table seating though, and this place gets crowded very quickly.  Their rolls were also very unique and their daily special rolls were even more exciting.  Service was on point, waitresses were very attentive, but it also wasn't a full house when we were there and the last game of the finals for professional basketball (Warriors vs. Cavs).
author: Vera L.

description:
Great sushi with a cute atmosphere and wonderful location in Hayes! However, their wait times are so so long (easily over an hour for a party of 3 on a Thursday, Friday, or Saturday), and the service at the door is not always the best. 

Would easily be 4 stars if they had a better reservation system, but my last 3 experiences here have been quite stressful and underwhelming.
author: Michelle B.

description:
We try to get into a new Hayes Valley venue each time we head to a concert at SF Jazz. This time a client recommended Domo. He courted his now wife when they both lived in the city, and he swears it's the best.  So not being all that hungry we figure "soosh" is the best bet and decided to give it ago.
Fellow elites are pretty spot on. The sushi is fresh creative and clean with emphasis on creative. 
The poke made me remember my first poke in Hawaii with lip smacking fondness. Clean plentiful slices of grade A tuna on a bed of seaweed salad that was an awesome start. 
The taco was pretty creative and tasty but I was addicted to the fireballs. Reminiscent of monkey brains, hot spicy chewy goodness! So I wound up eating most of em. 

The place is ridiculously small. I dropped Bae off to get in line while I ventured the area for 20 minutes to park. We still had to wait 20 more minutes. Highly recommend lift or Uber to this neck of the woods especially on a Friday evening!  As I walked toward the restaurant a Silicon Valley Bus dropped off a crap load of folks getting home from work, right out front and I noticed a few dropped in  to pick up to go orders.  Smart!

I was shocked by the smallness of the place including the kitchen area that looked more like a closet. But man those hombres in back were busting it, preparing very delectable looking plates to the 15 or so patrons crowded into the dining area. 
The wait staff was efficient and worked to keep pace with Diners and take out orders alike. 

I was tasked with not only snapping for Yelp but was told by my client who is land locked in Tucson to send pictures so he and his wife could ooh and Ahh with fond memories of their apparent multiple times a week dining experiences from the past.

I like the creativity of sushi that's not 100% traditional and  knows to keep international palettes happy, and that visual presentation is equally important to be inventive and bold without venturing too far from traditional ingredients and flavor profiles.  Domo does this expertly and with so many creative and delicious specials written in white on the mirrored wall... you literally want to try em all. 
A place that's so intimate that you are seeing what the folks next to you are getting and have no compunction to ask "wow that looks amazing... what's that!"

It's just to tiny cramped and long to wait to be a regular thing. But I totally get it if you are lucky enough to live nearby. 

Great date night place. Just be patient it's gonna be a while.
author: Craig G.

description:
I stopped into Domo this past week for a quick business lunch as it's one of the few sushi spots open in Hayes Valley at noon. I've eaten at Domo a few times before and always found it to be pretty run of the mill sushi. I'm not knocking this place but, it's one of those sushi spots that gives you an experience like you'd expect for basic sushi. The only difference is that Domo is more expensive than what you're getting. 

I ordered the lunch special which was a solid deal. 14.99 for soup, salad and your choice of two proteins on top of rice. I opted for the spicy tuna and seared albacore and they were what you'd except. I also ordered a side of ikura nigiri and they were decent. 

Look. The fish is good, just good. If you're looking for a casual sushi spot in an intimate setting then it's a good option.
author: Benjamin F.

description: Had a great experience going to this place! It is a small little restaurant but the wait was not bad. They do not take reservations. On a Saturday night around 730 our wait was only 15 minutes! I got the Kobe Beef roll and the Alpha roll and the Old School Negihama roll! All of them were delicious.
author: Sophia K.

description: A good trendy fusion sushi place. We got the Tokyo (right), Castro (top), and negi hama (bottom) which was perfect for two people. The place is tiny so it's kinda cramped and takes a while to get a table, but we didn't mind because the food was good and the environment was nice and cozy. Also it's like a place where you could eat alone and it's not awkward at all, if that's ur thing. Would come back!
author: Brittany H.

description: Very small, but nice sushi spot. We came here on a Sunday night and didn't have to wait too long. We were seated at the bar and it was extremely tight. Still enjoyed our meal though, as our food was good. Not the largest menu, but the food was high quality and that's all you can ask for. I'll definitely return to eat at Domo!
author: Lillian B.

description: Pretty good! Super cute and cozy spot in downtown Hayes. It's a small spot so make sure you plan appropriately (lunch rush). A little too tiny for me but enjoyed the rolls. I will say they weren't anything special. But I did enjoy my soup very much. Ordered the sushi combo (lunch special). Should've ordered the open face. Service is good!
author: Sahar N.

description:
Small restaurant, mostly bar style seating. This place is mainly known for their delicious rolls.

Fire Tuna Balls: does not need to be dipped in soy sauce as this is bursting with flavor with all the different sauces it's bathed in. I liked the crunchy batter/tempura that wraps the rice together.

Domo roll: similar in flavor to the fire tuna balls because of the sauces used so I would recommend one or the other, but both are exploding with flavor.

Kobe Beef Roll: a unique roll where a thin slice of Kobe beef wraps cucumber and other vegetables with scallions on top. This was really good I just wish it had more stuffing or felt more full on the inside of the roll (wish there was rice).
author: Tom P.

description:
My friend and i saw all the reviews and just had to try this place out. We got here around 6 and didn't have to wait for a table. We were so excited and just started to order.  We ordered the following

Wiki wiki- tempura, cucumber, butterfish, scallions and tobiko.  This dish was supposed to be my favorite because i love butterfish, But this dish turned out pretty odd, the taste of all the ingredients together didn't mix well. 

Fire tuna balls- This one was pretty good, it had a good kick to it. 

Spicy hulk- this one was pretty good, a little like the fire tuna balls, minus the deep fried. 

Kobe beef roll- as fancy as this sounds i would skip this.  

I was a little disappointed with this place,  i just don' t understand why the reviews are so high .  The service was great, the place was clean along with the restroom, but i prob won't return
author: Belinda C.

description:
Confession: I don't eat sushi and I still loved this place.  

Domo is so so so tiny, but it is the perfect intimate spot for a date night or small (and I do mean small) gathering.  By a miracle, we managed to get 7 people seated within about 30 minutes, but I think we got lucky.  They do have limited options for the non-seafood eaters like me, but the Kobe beef roll was such a pleasant surprise and so tasty!
author: Courteney S.

description:
Domo is one of my favorite sushi restaurants in San Francisco, and I have not had a disappointing meal there so far.  It's a small space, so during peak dinner hours there can be a wait.  There is indoor and outdoor seating, though I think it can be variable whether they are sitting customers outside or not.  

During my last meal, my friend and I decided to share a few appetizers and rolls.  The seaweed salad was solid, but I was more impressed with the fish taco: they somehow found a way to combine salmon, avocado, salsa, albacore tuna, and sriracha sauce on a sheet of what looked like tempura-fried nori.  It was a somewhat messy endeavor to eat it all, but it was definitely worth the trouble.  We also tried the firecracker, which involved panko-crusted spicy tuna balls fried and covered with unagi sauce, spicy mayo, and sriracha.  I thought this was tasty, though the fish taco was definitely the standout.   

For our rolls, we tried the Wiki Wiki and the Temptation; I thought both showcased fresh fish and were not overly covered in sauce.  I enjoyed the shiitake mushroom tempura in the Wiki Wiki, and the shrimp tempura in the Temptation roll was crispy yet not greasy. I will definitely be back!
author: Keith H.

description: We got there right at the 5:30 opening, and thank goodness, because it is a small place and by 6:00 they had a full house with a line of people waiting. We ordered  the firecracker balls which were delicious, the Domo roll (a baked sushi roll)...Delicious , an Alpha Roll..Delicious and the taco appetizer, which was not great just good. It was a mix of Japanese and Mexican flavors but would have been better if they stuck with all Japanese flavors. We would have preferred aioli instead of salsa. Good service. Will definitely go back.
author: Mary B.

description: So good! Small restaurant, so expect to be elbow to elbow, but ambiance is good and food is really good so yo won't mind the cozy seating. The crunchy California roll was delish. You must try!
author: Victoria W.

description:
I love food here. I have been coming to Domo for the last 6 years. The service was great always very welcoming and professional. 

I like their Wagyu roll and daikon salad. It was pretty good. 

Compare with other japanese restaurant witin that area the price was not bad at all. Eventhough the restaurant is a bit too small but i still enjoy the atmosphere here. There is no reservation so if you are very hungry on friday or saturday night, this is not the place for you ;(. The wait can take from 30 mins to an hour ish. But should go and give it a try
author: Ranae T.

description:
Terrible. The server wouldn't serve us at 10:30pm.
Maybe they should change their closing time to 10:30 and not 11:00. He also had a terrible attitude. I hope management takes action.
author: Hanna A.

description:
Came here on a Friday night for dinner with a friend. This place is tiny but then again so are many places in SF. Wait wasn't too bad though...and there's also a champagne bar across the street that we thought we could chill at but they were at max capacity. We ended up waiting inside Domo. 

Sushi was decent. Rolls were really good, fish tacos are delicious and a must try! The nigiri for some reason takes a long time even though we just had 1 order of 2 pieces. I wasn't impressed with the toro nigiri here since I typically expect it to be melt in your mouth but it was just okay. Everything else was good though. Hot sake is a good deal and of course pairs well at a Japanese restaurant.

Reminds me of this place in San Carlos because they have the fish tacos and the fire balls that most other sushi places don't have.
author: Melissa L.

description:
TL;DR: get to this restaurant early to enjoy unique sushi :)
The music is a little loud but what that they do play is amazing and adds to how fantastic the atmosphere of this small intimate restaurant is. The wait for a table can be a little long because of how limited their seating is, so be sure to get there early! I think it's really cool how the menu is on one side of the wall which is a mirror and also in front of you. In addition, these rolls were very creative and nothing like anything I had had before. There's normally only one waiter so please be patient and courteous. The food comes out fairly quickly and I felt like I could eat 10 rolls! However, after standing up, I realized that I was beyond full. Highly recommend and would return (of course)!
author: Emily S.

description: Service was great, they were very friendly. But the fish didn't taste fresh to me. I'll give them props on the creativity with the "fish tacos" but other then that, it was ok. Price is decent. the place is small so expect a wait.
author: Deezy P.

description:
Had dinner with a couple friends at Domo and really enjoyed it. Will definitely return when plans call for a small get-together.

The restaurant seats 20, maybe, and has a casual, homey vibe. Not too many patrons meant attentive service. We ordered approximately ten things off the menu - primarily rolls, but a couple apps as well. Most were hits for us, with a couple so-so items. Unfortunately, didn't try any nigiri or sashimi, so can't comment on those offerings. Won't go through everything, but a few call-outs below.

1/ GET THE FISH TACOS. Really unique and was the highlight of the meal imo. A couple slices of lightly seared fish, served on top of a fried piece of seaweed, garnished with some other accouterment. Should've ordered this x2 in hindsight.
2/ Kobe Beef Roll: Wasn't sure if I liked it or not. I think I did? A pretty interesting idea, where beef serves as a wrap for the roll. Would probably recommend 60% of the time, 100% of the time.
3/ Uni and Scallop Small Crudos: Probably the low-light of the meal. Fresh, but nothing special.
author: Trevor M.

description: Unimpressive. The spicy hulk roll was pretty refreshing but other than that nothing stood out to me food-wise. The service was very friendly though.
author: Menana B.

description:
Went to have dinner last night, party of 4.
The wait was kind of long but they do let you leave your phone number so they call you if you are not there.
The place was very small which was a little tricky for 4 people but we managed.
The staff was very nice and the service was great.
The food was really delicious! We had Fish Tacos which were really special, Salmon Carpaccio, Edamame and Miso Soup for appetizers and 7-8 rolls of sushi that were all special and yummy!
I gave 4 and not 5 stars because the wait, not being able to make reservations and most important it was so small, I wish the place was capable of holding more than parties of 2 people only.
author: Hai C.

description:
Love their simple rolls more than their specialties. California roll made with real crab. Try the shiitake roll even if you're not into veggie rolls. 

Friends have recommended to try their uni. The time I had it, it was not fresh at all. Wished for it to be good! Won't be ordering uni here anytime soon.
author: sungheui u.

description:
Solid place for sushi and nigiri. You might walk by and not realize you passed it. No tables, bar counter and window counter seats with stools. No wait 6pm on a Tuesday. Large 600ml bottle of Sapporo for $9 with small glasses provided. 

Hamachi Carpaccio was seared and pretty tasty. I'm used to cooler in temperature and non-seared carpaccio, so this was a new twist that I did fancy! It was flavorful and the jalapeño added a great little kick to my taste buds. 

Tried two different nigiris which were both delicious in their own ways. The walu nigiri aka butter fish, somewhat melted in my mouth and also seemed to have an actual buttery after taste! It was quite delightful. The other nigiri which was a special on the wall, was the Albacore Toro which was $9 for two pieces, solid. 

My favorite roll was the Saba Hit...I didn't know mackerel could be so tasty on a roll. The combination of the fresh ginger, avocado, and shiso flavors really blended well together...refreshing too.  

Also tried the Domo roll which I thought was mediocre. Would pass on that next time, it was essentially a less saucy and smaller lion king roll. 

Street parking pretty easy to find....on a Tuesday around 6pm. Area could get trafficky though!
author: Anna S.

description:
A nice and very tiny spot in Hayes Valley. We were a group of 6 and had to sit outside, so I would recommend this place more for a 2 people.

I thought their uni and monk fish were delicious. I would surely come back for it. However, the speciality rolls all were alright but they had more sauce than I would have liked. Also the tacos weren't that great. 

If some come for some uni and sake though.
author: Nikita K.

description: Literally down the street from me, it's way too convenient. Their sushi tacos are superb. I highly recommend ordering... a couple! Maybe it was an off night but the uni, was just horrible, we had to send it back. But everything else was really fresh and good and the price seems reasonable. I would definitely go back, not bc it's just in my backyard but it's really good!
author: Sandy P.

description:
Solid 4 currently my favorite sushi place in the city as I like my rolls sauced up! Basically I'm obsessed with the spinach 

Hawaiian poke bowl 7/10 for me needed a little more punch of flavor but meat was great 

Crunchy Cali roll: would be perfect if it wasn't hot! Menu was deceiving on this one you can have tempura shrimp and not heat the whole roll. So sad about this as it had all the toppings and spicy mayo like I love 5/10 

Fire tuna balls!: 11/10 everything was perfection here!!!! 

Kobe roll: hot again the asparagus was nice Kobe ok, but warming avacado makes it mushy and it really changes the flavor 5/10
author: Morgan S.

description:
I like to officially break down my reviews moving forward in a few categories: price/value, taste, and service. 

My bf and I decided to sushi hop and try out a couple of different places for the night. We went to another sushi location nearby and came to this location second. This location was about to close in less than 30 min so the moment we walked in the Asian women said to us, we're closing soon, please give me your whole order at once. A little shocked, I was like that isn't a 10/10 for service for sure. There is nothing wrong with sharing that your location is going to close, but the way she said it was shocking. Next time you (readers) say something to someone make sure you check your tone ;) 

Price/value: we ordered 3 things at this location: Fish Tacos (crunchi nori, avacado, albacore, salmon, salsa & sriracha), small crudos choose any two for $8:
(Salmon - capers, sweet onion, avocado & olive oil
Spicy Tuna - sriracha, sesame oil, cilantro & avocado 
Uni - avocado, wasabi soy & sea salt
Scallop - yuzu cucumber, tobiko, rice vinegar & sea salt
Ankimo - monkfish liver pate)

We chose the salmon and scallop. And lastly the Castro roll (crab & avacado roll topped with salmon, hamachi, maguro & albacore).

Of all the items we suggested, our total bill came out to be $33.71. I would rate this place a 3/5 for price and value. Mediocre. Nothing too special. The portions were not big, nor filling. 


Taste: The crudo came out first, $8 for what it is was not bad. Although I highly prefer the salmon over the scallop. The scallop wasn't as fresh nor was the taste amazing. My bf enjoyed the "juice" in it which is vinegar and seasalt but I did not like it. It was hard to chew, and did not melt immediately in your mouth. Next the fish tacos came I was surprised to see the fish cooked in this entree and the salsa+siracha being very spicy. I suggest doing raw fish on this one and adding spicy mayo which would help with the taste of the fish. The spicy salsa in this dish overpowered the fish causing it to taste merely like spicy salsa. Next the castro roll came, it was pretty much a rainbow roll, but a lot more dry. The sushi rice was subpar and the crab inside the roll was very bland. I would not suggest ordering this. Taste 3/5/ 

Service: as first mentioned I felt rushed since the moment I came in. Right after we got our third dish the roll, she gave us our check... I would rate service 3/5.
author: Amy Y.

description: A cozy space with very good sushi! We got here at 7pm on a Thursday and didn't have to wait, it's better for small groups or just two people as it's mainly bar seating with only one indoor table and a few outside. Sushi is all well priced and the staff were friendly and attentive. The favorite by far was the red dragon roll, which was on the specials board.
author: Lauren A.

description:
Want quality sushi, but on a budget? 

Look no further. This is your place. I've tried many sushi establishments and have eaten at the finest sushi restaurants in the world, including Japan. 

Don't get me wrong this is not at the level of those pre selected sushi courses that you would find at Michelin stars, but those also start at $100 dollars minimum. 

This is a casual, non pretentious sushi joint. 

Fish so fresh, that if I called out "Nemo" it would answer. 

Great for last minute dinners in front of the tele, flipping through Netflix. Or to impress that girl living at 22b.

Please for the love of all that is holy and sacred, come here and don't worry you're in good hands.

Much love. Arigato Gozimas.

San Fran-tastic.
author: Timothy P.

description:
Called ahead to ask about seating and was told there would be space enough for my party of 4. We arrive and they seat us at a tall table in the corner that was really only big enough for 2 people, we were crammed into the corner. 

That aside, we went ahead and ordered. 

The $15 crf of sake I ordered was HALF the size of every other sushi place I've been to. It only filled 1 tiny sake glass for each of the 4 of us. 4 shots of sake for $15. No thanks. I asked what seemed to be the manager about the size of the crf and he said, "no, it's right. This is our size. This is the size we serve." Don't come here if you like to have drinks with your sushi. Severely overpriced. 

The rolls were really average, nothing bad about them but nothing remarkable about them either. Same sushi rolls you can get anywhere else.

The sashimi was the only redeeming thing about eating here. Chefs choice sashimi, the fish tasted fresh and was a good portion for the price compared to other places in SF. 

Would not recommend for sake drinkers or sushi enthusiasts. Might be a good place for those who only want sashimi and don't care about the rest.
author: Morgan B.

description:
Hayes valley is such a nice area to walk around and do a little bit of shopping so we decided to do that before having sushi for dinner. 

Domo is definitely affordable. Each specialty roll costs about $9-15 which is average in most places and cheap in San Francisco. The place was super quaint and didn't have a large number of seats but a counter spot facing the street was still perfect. We had the firecracker balls, the spicy hulk, and the red dragon roll for our entrees and the chicken karage as an appetizer. 

The firecracker balls are highly recommended - it has a fishy eel taste to it but came out super hot and crispy so you barely taste the fishiness. The sauces for the roll was also a wonderful mixture of flavor. 

The spicy hulk is good, if you're into raw fish. It's just fish wrapped in cucumber with pieces of avocado in the middle and no rice. The sauce for that is spicy and quite heavenly as well. 

The red dragon roll is a typical spicy tuna roll, it was delicious but not anything out of the norm. 

Last but not least, the chicken karage. It was a rather large portion for $7 and was super crispy! We had to ask for rice though since chicken karage is salty in nature. 

Overall a wonderful experience and we'd definitely come back again.
author: My N.

description:
Things that make you go "hmmm."

Like I'm questioning why the one hour wait and high ratings for just okay Japanese food.

Like my brother said, "the basics like sashimi and the California roll are okay, but everything else..."

Well, I can't post what he said since it would be vulgar.

Here's the breakdown:

Fish tacos: super hyped up but it was just salmon and Mexican pico de gallo on a cold tempura fried seaweed. Everyone ordered this dish, but it didn't live up to the expectation. I took one bite and put it down and never touched it again. I'm not a fan of cold tempura fried anything. If it's fried it needs to be hot.

Firecracker balls: more like firecracker sushi since it's a sliced up roll topped off with sauce. Again cold fried food is a no-no in my book. It was both bland and cold even though it was fried. Maybe it was sitting out to long before they brought it to us. Neither of us finished this.

The negi Toro was the best thing but it's basic like my brother said.

Same with the salmon sashimi.

The tasting spoon with uni and the second with ankimo was a disappointment. Runny kind of old tasting uni and a less than fresh tasting ankimo.

The California roll with different fish on top, I forgot the name of it, was okay. The problem we had is that it just tasted like supermarket fresh and not like we were at a restaurant. Where's the flavor?

The worst roll was the baked California roll topped with special sauce. How could something baked still be cold and yet bland at the same time?

And service, well, they leave you alone with water and that's self service. If you ordered tea like we did you're lucky to get one refill since they are busy with phone orders.

2.5 stars rounded up only because they agreed to sit us inside.
author: Jack R.

description:
Before heading out the Opera I thought we should have a little sushi.
This place was a bit hard to locate based on it's size, but it was worth the search.
 
We ordered the Kobe Beef roll which was a bit different, but all the Kobe beef flavor was present. We also had the Crunchy California roll, it had a nice texture to it and the spicy mayo was a nice touch. 

Great place to get a quick bite before any events near the Hayes Valley area.
author: Jackson T.

description: My best frans took me here for my birthday dinner after we had delicious bubbly at The Riddler across the street! This place is worth it cause on a Wednesday evening we had to wait an hour for our table so that's why we got a bottle at the Riddler to pass the time! The ambience of Domo is popping, it's a nice, clean spot with a personable crowd! It's not quiet, it's not bland in decor! We got our sushi rolls and I've never gotten a spicy tuna wrapped in cucumber, instead of rice but my goodness it was so so delicious, so fresh (and so clean).  We got sashimi, salmon of course cause there's no other way to go and it was fresh, wholesome, we wanted more! Our service was excellent, our waitress was attentive and checked on us regularly which was impressive for how busy it was! In addition to our rolls, we got drinks (cause it's my birthday) and they even scored well there since I'm not really into sake, the white wine was pretty tasty. I give this place four stars instead of five because of the menu selection. You can really appreciate what the place has concocted and put together, delicious rolls I'm sure but it was a little frustrating not finding a simple salmon and avocado roll or a roll when salmon that had no crab or shrimp with it. I would 100% go again though for that spicy tuna roll alone!
author: Suria S.

description:
Best sashimi in the universe...it's THE place to go for true quality sushi/sashimi. Their sushi rice alone is just wonderful. IM Drooling thinking about the food just writing this. Of course it's a little pricy but I don't expect anything less for this type of service and food.
Can't wait to go back 
I  Domo
Domo I want a good promo!
author: Betty B.

description:
In New York City, my former home, there's a delightful sushi joint by the name of Domodomo. So stepping into Domo, a hole-in-the-wall at the intersection of Laguna and Linden, I couldn't help but think, "will this only be half as good?" As it turns out, not exactly. Like the city as a whole, it's about two-thirds of its east coast counterpart. 

Calling Domo a hole-in-the-wall is simply a turn of phrase. So apologies for any confusion. It's actually inside of a hole in the wall. Once you enter through the restaurant's door, the space itself is similar (though not identical) to other restaurant interiors you've seen. There is bar seating along the window and a sushi bar on the back wall. We sat there. 

I tried three rolls. The first was a special called "Daddy." It consisted of green onion tempura, avocado, shiso, tobiko and ocean trout*. This roll was the best and I really liked it. Go, Dad! Next was the "Domo," a ~baked~ California roll topped with salmon and scallop. This roll was the second best, and I liked it. Last came the "Kobe Beef" roll, containing Kobe beef, avocado and ginger. The roll was actually wrapped in the beef, which was a hoot. This roll was my third favorite, and I didn't really like it. Whereas seaweed generally succeeds in holding a roll together, the Kobe Beef roll easily fell apart. The Kobe Beef roll was less integrous than a seaweed-wrapped roll. 

------
*Curiously, ocean trout is commonly referred to as steelhead, and is often confused for salmon ("Sah-mon"). Though they taste and look similar, the ocean trout (or steelhead), is not actually a salmon but rather a trout. More curiously, the ocean trout (still the same as a steelhead) is the same species as the rainbow trout. When the freshwater rainbow trout enters the salty ocean, it is then, by definition, a steelhead (or ocean trout). The steelhead is simply an anadromous form of rainbow trout that has migrated to the ocean. If this reminds you of the movie Air Force One, it's for good reason: the Air Force's VC-25 plane's call sign only becomes the titular "Air Force One" when it is carrying the the POTUS. In this 1997 flick, the President is Medal of Honor winner James Marshall, played (spectacularly) by Harrison Ford.
author: Oliver S.

description:
The fish is fresh, the sushi is reasonable, and if you happen to sit at the bar, it's a great place to eat sushi and people watch too. The place is small, the bath room is big, and the food has seasonal varieties. Definitely go here if you're looking for a sushi place in the HV area. Though you might end up waiting, I think the food and price was worth it.

With my friends (who are picky), they loved it here, so give it a try.
author: Kevin L.

description: Unplanned dine out with my boyfriend at Domo. One of our bucket list restaurants to try in the city. We ordered the following items: Fire Tuna Ball (hot spicy tuna tempura, sriracha mayo, avocado, tobiko, & unagi soy), Castro (crab & avocado roll topped with salmon, hamachi, maguro &a albacore)& Alfa (unagi, mango, avocado roll topped with spicy tuna & jalapeño). Lastly, a large Sapporo for the both of us to share. Love trying new places with my lifetime partner.  I truly recommend the following sushi plates that we ordered! One recommendation that I have for the restaurant is to invest on outdoor heaters! It was a little chilly eating outside at 7pm (we got seated faster if we dined outside).
author: Jamie T.

description:
Dinner review. 

Chicken Karaage - 3/5
Fish tacos - 4/5 - Would be a 5 if topped with poke instead of salsa
Dynamite mussels - 4/5
Fire tuna balls - 3/5 - 
Temptation roll - 4/5 - So much crab
Domo roll - 4/5

Overall, great sushi place. "I'm a fan."
author: Mark O.

description: Had about an hour and a few minutes of wait, the host who was crossing off names was a tad rude. At first bite the sushi tasted heavenly, until it fell apart. Every single sushi piece fell apart. They simply do not know how to appropriately wrap sushi. The taste was great although a bit salty.
author: Nataliee A.

description: Ended up walking in here on a lark after deciding to ditch our original choice. Alas Domo is very popular even at 9pm Sunday but it was worth the short wait. The albacore and Hamachi sashimi were melt-in-your mouth tender and the salmon was good too. Service was fast and efficient at the sushi bar. Subtract 1* for the atmosphere (chairs are pretty jammed) and the somewhat abrupt but efficient server who seemed more interested in moving customers along so they could close down. But overall a great experience for those who are willing to venture a couple of block above Gough St.
author: Boris G.

description:
Yup, go get two of the Domo Sushi Rolls

Really delicious

Laced with scallops on top

Good warm flavor
author: Solomon H.

description: My favorite sushi in the City! The Domo roll is so fantastic, I feel like I could eat 10 of them. The restaurant stays very busy so an early dinner with less than 4 people is best to ensure you don't wait over 30 min. Lunch is eh. The chirashi bowl has high quality fish, but lacks other common elements (like avacado, cucumber, or egg) - if you're a Chirashi fan, just go to Ginto for one!!
author: Candace S.

description:
There is A LOT of sushi in SF and to be honest I have not been to too many yet, but so far the place right around the corner, Domo, has taken the cake!

The menu is different enough to be interesting but not too different to be frustrating. The wait can be tough at times, but again, I live around the corner so not a big deal for me. Anything with seafood you really cannot go wrong. The roles, nigiri, appetizers are all outstanding and I definitely encourage you to try something you haven't before.... except... the Kobe beef roll. Great in idea, but poor in execution. I should have taken a look at Yelp before since I see others have said the same. It just didn't hit the mark but that's okay, because the rest of the menu is outstanding. 

Also - a recommendation to management - get some heat lamps outside and then folks will be happier/you'll double your seating on a cold day :)
author: Brandon P.

description:
I really like Hayes Valley and had been wanting to check Domo out, so when we finally got the chance to I was pretty excited.  Their phone etiquette could use some fine tuning, because I called in to see what the wait time would be and if they took reservations.  The woman on the other end wasn't very friendly, but when we actually ate at the restaurant all our interactions were very nice.

DINER
Salmon and spicy tuna crudos- what are crudos?  I still don't know, but it was good!
Seaweed salad
Wiki wiki- favorite roll of the 3
Kobe beef- good roll to balance raw fish
Spicy tuna- classic, but in very large pieces

All the food was really good and bigger portions than I expected.  For two people, we could have ordered more but that was enough to satiate our appetite.  The restaurant is very small, so there could be a wait.  I would still come back though, just get here when they open to beat the crowd.  

Domo Arigato!
author: Lyn C.

description:
My friend took me here after we had a few beers, and we happened to be craving sushi. Fortunately we spotted an empty table on the outdoor patio and were seated immediately. There is usually a line, but I think that is mostly because this is such a small restaurant. If you want to eat here, late afternoon or early evening is best. The wait staff is friendly, and the food service is quick.

I ordered the popular Fire Tuna Balls that our waiter recommended, but I found them to be disappointing. The rice was mushy, and I was not impressed by the flavor. The roll itself seemed tiny for what I was paying too. We also ordered some hot sake, which made the whole trip worth it. This place has a cool vibe and interior, but I'm not really partial to its food.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
If I could give Domo a 3.5 stars, that would be my rating. Domos menu is very similar to Seiya's in the Peninsula. Our waiter told us there are people that work at both locations at this restaurant.

We came on a Sunday around 6:30pm. There was only one other couple waiting for a table inside but we wanted to be seated immediately so we took the table outside. Domo does not take reservations.

As many previous yelpers have summarized, Domo is a good place to go if you're into the "Westernized" Japanese restaurants. Most notable is their fish tacos. If I could do it over, I would have just ordered two of these instead of two of their rolls. We ordered the Salmon Citron roll and the Alpha Roll ($14). The Alpha roll was good but because it was lathered in sauce rather than because of the pure quality of the fish. I liked the Salmon Citron roll and the lemon undertones. It was still overall underwhelming. The tuna poke was satisfying - Having been to Hawaii, it wasn't a poke with the most fresh fish. 

The food is decent, but it is certainly overpriced. I would rather spend my money on omakase in San Mateo.
author: Nicole J.

description:
Used to be OK but their service at lunch is very rushed, they want you in and out quickly even when it's not busy... it made me uncomfortable.
The price is alright but the freshness of the fish wasn't there, no taste and even the rice fell flat.
Nothing special really.
author: Babs J.

description: Good sushi joint at a reasonable price. I wouldn't go here if you have a party of more than three people. It's a small space. I had the karage, toro and a few of the rolls. This is a great casual place to enjoy a bottle of sake, some nigiri and rolls would definitely come here again.
author: Ian C.

description:
Place: This is a small quaint sushi place that prides itself on carrying primarily regional fish. Most of the interior seating is bar (sushi bar or against the window). Price/value used to be really good, but prices have been going up to catch up with the other places in the area. This place has a pretty decadent variety of rolls, which I think is what most people come for. I like this place, and I'm always happy to stop by to eat here when the line isn't long.

Best value: They offer a really good lunch deal for sushi over rice. Presentation is ok. Price point is really good.

Btw, if you happen to come on a hot day, avoid sitting in the middle of the sushi bar. There is an exhaust fan from the refrigerator that blows out on two of the bar seats.
author: James S.

description: Slow service and an uppity hostess. I'm shocked about how slow the service is for such a small place. Hostess def seemed out of pocket on the attitude for sure, nbd just like don't be rude. Food is amazing and fresh. I'm willing to deal with this broad's crappy attitude for the amazing dinners here. No doubt the rolls are delicious and it's right across from Champagne Bar!
author: Kelly M.

description: Whats the point of a wait list when you don't seat parties in the order they signed up? We put our names on the wait list, quoted an hour wait, Ang went to get a drink. Came back before we got called to make sure we were there and ready. Four seats open at the sushi bar, we are next us the list as a 3 top. Male host, glasses, skips us and seats a party of 2 females. We inquire about why we are not being seated, as we are next on the list. Host responds, with a nonsensical answer, about how they can only seat so many groups. Hmmmmm
author: Bryan E.

description: Hands down some of the best sushi in San Francisco. Domo is our "neighborhood spot" but I think the quality of the fish is as good if not higher than that if much fancier (and pricier) Bay Area establishments. Consistently. The staff and chefs are incredibly sweet and efficient yet the vibe is very relaxed and hospitable. It's pretty small counter seating only and they don't take reservations but the wait moves fairly fast and they are great about calling from the list!
author: Aida C.

description: Found this place on yelp and decided to give it a try, came here with my dad. We tried 4 rolls, the crunchy California, the domo roll, the Kobe beef roll and the spicy hulk, all 4 were delicious! The rolls are very authentic and fresh! Also service was fast and friendly. Next time I'm in the city I would defiantly like to come back!
author: Brittany Y.

description:
Due to the small size this place feels up quickly! Be prepared if you are trying to nab a spot on a Friday or Saturday night. As far as the food goes- it's an untraditional Japanese style sprinkled with Asian fusion. To start we ordered the fish tacos- a crisp tempura like seaweed topped with avocado, fish, and salsa, this was by far one of the highlights of the meal! Another roll we loved was the Domo roll (baked California roll with salmon, scallops, spicy mayo, BBQ unagi glaze, tobiko, and scallions). For a baked roll this didn't feel too heavy, a great addition to any sushi meal!

Can't wait to come back and try more rolls :)
author: Nicole W.

description:
Small as hell, but with a really dope vibe. It's no surprise there are usually lines out the door, even on off hours.

But of course, the main reason why folks keep comin' back is the fish:
- Tasty
- Affordable
- Paired with good service.

My only qualm was that most of our speciality appetizer rolls were a tad over-cooked, especially the fish balls one. I know, I know, you shouldn't be ordering cooked fish at a sushi joint, but although it looked good, it wasn't so great in execution.

If you're looking for a chill sushi spot in the heart of it all, Domo definitely delivers in terms of quality and feel-goods. But keep in mind that everyone else probably has the same idea, especially when they manage to keep prices still so good in a rapidly transformative neighborhood.
author: Anthony N.

description:
Narrowly missed the lunch hour! They're efficient with their business hours, and close from 2:30-5:30. 

I quickly ordered the Domo roll, figuring that the namesake sushi roll had to be good, but was very intrigued by their lunch special of two choosings served over rice with lettuce salad and miso soup for the equivalent price of the roll. 

Namesake roll: Domo (4.5/5), basically a fancy baked California Roll with unagi and spicy mayo. I don't like TOO spicy, and there was just enough kick to satisfy my wimpy taste buds. Plating wasn't the prettiest since it was baked on foil and then transferred to the plate on the foil. Utility s understandable, but it didn't look the best. 

I felt a little apologetic for showing up so close to closing, but didn't feel rushed, so kudos to their good manners.
author: Amanda W.

description: A lot of creative twists on the menu.... Don't let that mislead you...amazing traditional sushi standards done right....But try everything...."All good" works for Domo.
author: Bill H.

description:
I understand why people get excited about the lunch (Lots of food for $14). It's a small quick spot, sushi is mediocre. They don't tell you the crab is premixed and sweet. Service was just ok, surprising for such a small place. Would not go back. 

Food ordered: classic yellow tail roll and temptation roll.
author: Sam B.

description: We had high hopes for this place but it disappointed. The roll we got was okay. The uni just ruined our palate. It was not fresh and just left a bad taste in our mouths
author: Anisha P.

description:
While there were two singles seated one away from the end, we were asked to move to not leave any spaces. I get why that's practical, but wonder why they didn't ask everyone. We were also the only Asians in the place. Maybe we look more compliant? Minus half star. 
The yellowtail sashimi had a nice texture, but had a persistent fishy taste. Minus one star, maybe a little more. It was fishy enough that I only had one piece. The two rolls (last two on the menu) we got were decent. The negihama was good.
author: Kris F.

description:
I've been on the hunt for my next solid sushi restaurant in the neighborhood, so I was excited to check out Domo.  The restaurant is located right in the heart of Hayes Valley and probably sits no more than 30-35 people at a time.  Specials are listed on their mirror, which is a pretty cool feature.  

My friend and I ordered a couple rolls, chicken karaage, and the hamachi kama.  Everything was presented quickly with little wait time.  The fish was served fresh and the hot dishes came out hot.  I would say the highlights of the meal were the negihama (y. tail, green onion, and sesame seeds) and karaage.  The negihama was buttery and delicious.  The karaage was crispy and tender.  Unfortunately, the spicy tuna roll was probably my least favorite.  The tuna lacked flavor, but was pretty spicy, and the roll had some sort of green sprouts in it.  The sprouts I think were there more for decoration, but really didn't do much for the roll itself (not like green onion would've).

Overall, the meal was just, ok.  I think Domo is a great spot to sit with a friend over a couple beers and order some apps, but I would skip on some of the other options.
author: Josh S.

description: Fresh fish, good rolls, nice dark bar setting. A bit on the pricy side. Would come back to try more options!
author: Chelsea W.

description:
Cute place and super cozy! (If you want to go on a date where you're sitting VERY close to each other, this is probably a good place). However, it's definitely a more "western" sushi place. Unfortunately, the chefs choice sashimi platter isn't the freshest. You have to get the specials to get the better, more fresh fish but obviously much pricier.  The sashimi is cut super thick unlike how Japanese sushi places do it.

Overall not a bad experience and not expensive. I'd rather pay a bit more for authentic Japanese omakase. I wouldn't come back unfortunately.
author: Rohenne L.

description: This place is Delicious!!! Highly recommend when you are in this area. The staff and chef were great and I can't wait to visit again.
author: Suzanne H.

description:
This review has three stars for a few reasons. 
1. The disastrous Kobe beef roll
2. The wait

Do NOT get the Kobe Beef roll. We tried it out of pure curiosity and didn't eat any more than the initial piece we first tried. The idea behind this roll is unique but the execution is a disaster. The beef is chewy beyond belief and overall flavorless. The inside is just avocado and another veggie, while the kobe beef wraps around it like nori. NOT tasty. Not worth it. 

The wait is 30 min - 1 hr on weekends at dinner time. Not the worst but I now feel like it's not totally worth the wait due to the Kobe beef roll partially (I'm just weirdly offended by it) and nothing incredible about the sushi that stood out to me otherwise. And with sushi restaurant prices- you want something to stand out. 

Pros:

The Domo roll is a hot roll with salmon that is super tasty. The Spicy Hulk is a Gluten Free roll with spicy tuna and cucumber wrap. These two were probably my favorite out of the five rolls we tried. Both had really great flavors and textures. 


Overall I wouldn't be excited to go back here, but good flavor and nice atmosphere.
author: Tamara S.

description:
Small sushi bar. Exactly what I was looking for for date night with boyfriend. Really fresh fish. Nice 'small crudo bites' -- got the uni (which was satisfyingly weird) and the scallop). Tried the cucumber roll with the spicy tuna and avocado on the inside. My boyfriend got a regular california roll (which I made fun of him for, because who gets a california roll these days?) but it was surprisingly delicious! Never had such a good california roll. I think they had other california roll's that came with tuna/salmon on top and other variations which probably would have been good. 

Definitely good tasty sushi, nice little spot, for 2 people. (not good for big parties, you sit up at the counter facing the street). 

But nothing BLEW ME AWAY. 

If I was a local or lived in the neighborhood, I would go back definitely. Since I'm from Berkeley I don't think Ill be making my way all the way to SF for Domo, but I hope the locals give it a try!
author: Victoria T.

description:
In a city crawling with Asians, we somehow managed to find the one sushi restaurant with non Asian chefs.  This is how we felt when we looked into the window of Domo and saw a white guy and a Hispanic guy behind the counter... needless to say we were a little skeptical.

However that skepticism began to fade once we bit into the poké and the seaweed salad appetizers, and that continued on as dish after dish was brought out.  The menu is small enough so that you're not overwhelmed, but varied enough to make an interesting meal.

This place is small but popular, so be prepared to wait, but with a place like Two Sisters (five star review pending), around the corner, waiting is easy.
author: Ajay R.

description: Not terribly expensive but absolutely delicious. The poke was amazing. The sushi fresh. The fish cut well and fresh. The rice done impeccably. The atmosphere perfect for a date. No reservation just a board to sign up on. Not really a Japanese sushi dinner feel but it'd be a great night out with food not to disappoint.
author: L J.

description:
Eh I wasn't a huge fan of this place, probably because although I do love Chinese food, when I'm eating Japanese food, I'm a purist at heart and can't deal with these not Japanese Japanese joints.

Anyways, I came here for dinner on Sunday right when they opened and it was insane how quickly they filled up. I got there about five minutes after opening and all the indoor seats were already taken. Luckily, they have a few tables outside which are actually really  nice since weather in SF has been pretty good. They're also more fun if you want to people watch. I also personally liked the outside seating more because the inside smelled really oily and restuaranty. 

I got the seared albacore tataki, the fiesta roll, and the I.C. roll. Part of me regrets not following what other Yelpers suggested, but I'm just not really a fan of unagi so some of the more popular rolls wouldn't have made much sense for me.

Seared albacore tataki--so spot on and so so so delicious. Would highly recommend you order this if you go! The albacore slices are super generous and the ponzu sauce just completes it perfectly. I''d definitely consider just eating this as a whole meal. It's five slices per order, so if I ever go back, I'd be down for two of these lol.

The rolls... were not so great. Pretty mediocre rolls. The fish cuts were really thin and not worth it. Rolls were fine but nothing special. I liked I.C. enough, but I honestly felt like both rolls were super mediocre. 

All in all, price came out to be about $20/person without tax which wasn't too bad since we didn't eat too much.

tldr; meh not as good as I think Yelp makes it out to be, though the seared albacore tataki is spot on
author: Jasmine X.

description:
Oh domo, you deliciously devil you! :)

Perusing thru my bookmarks, my hunny and I were trying to pick a place for dinner last night. We were amazed that this place has such a high health score-- 100 out of 100?!?!?!? Wth!? 

Normally, I don't even notice the health score on restaurants. Since, I use my yelp app on my phone, the health score rating is not necessarily the thing that pops out at me when I research a place. Haha but we were looking at the restaurants' page on my boyfriend's laptop so the health score section was pretty visible to the eye which helped our decision of picking this place for dinner.

They don't take reservations. Upon arriving, we noticed there were prob about 7 little groups/couples waiting for a seat. Domo is most definitely a very petite restaurant. They had a notebook by the entrance where you can write down your name & phone #. We ended up going back to car to kill some time instead of waiting outside since it was kinda chilly & there weren't really any shops open to wander around about. Oh and we found parking in one of the residential streets/alleyway that was about 2 blocks from Domo.

The wait was about 45-50mins, I think. Yeah, the wait wasn't that fun, but it was so worth it! 

We got seated in the middle of the bar counter in front of the sushi chefs making their creations. My hunny was more interested in watching them work their magic than me. Haha... We ordered the Kobe beef app, Domo roll, Crunchy Cali roll, Firecracker Balls, and the Red Dragon roll. All were very yummy, but my fave would be the Domo roll-- so hot (temp) & über nomness!

So in conclusion, Domo = a very intimate tiny restaurant that has awesome sushi. :)
author: Amy C.

description: Delicious sushi, nice friendly staff and service. Unfortunately, small location so the wait was killer, even when it wasn't so busy- but the food was worth it. Try the dragon roll and baby octopus!!
author: Robert R.

description:
The name "Domo" keeps conjuring up images of the Japanese cartoon character, but I'll put that image out of my head and just focus on this really amazing sushi place. Domo is a tiny (there's maybe 15 seats total) place in Hayes Valley that serves San Francisco-themed sushi. 

I'm a big fan of "rainbow roll"-type sushi, since it means I'll get to try a lot of different types of fish, so I ordered the Castro roll, which I really enjoyed. The fish was fresh and "melts" in your mouth. There's also some unique appetizers, such as fish tacos and crudos. I ordered the salmon and scallop crudos, which were delicious. They're served in little spoons, so it's a little confusing whether chopsticks should be involved in the consumption of crudos.

Service is really fast: they serve sushi as soon as it's made, and they work pretty quickly! The price point is reasonable, but it's sushi, so of course it isn't going to be cheap. However, there's apparently $13 chirashi at lunch, so I'll need to come back and try it!
author: Brittany C.

description:
Visiting from LA and this place lacks in service and atmosphere. Extremely small and cramped place. I wouldn't recommend it or come back either.
Sushi was okay. They also charge gratuity for a party of 5.
author: Anthony D.

description: So glad that this is yet another gem of a sushi place that I can enjoy in SF! If you go here, give them a chance with some of their more creative offers and let yourself have a 5 star meal instead of a 3.5 star meal that I was going to have if I had gone the non-experimental route. I tried their tuna wrapped in fresh cucumber roll and it was hands down the highlight of the meal. The two friends that I was there with felt the same and so much so that we got a 2nd order that night. Will be back! There's very limited seating (probably enough for 12-15 people, including the seating at the sushi bar), so you might face a wait. We had a half hour wait on a Thursday night at 730PM.
author: Meryam B.

description: Terrible service. Put our name in and waited 35 minutes (quoted 20-30). Went back to check and they had skipped us without calling and crossed our name out. When we asked they lied and said they tried to call. We said no problem but they then decided to seat two other parties in front of us. The main girl was very rude even after I was trying to be polite.
author: Ann N.

description: A local favorite. Great service and consistent food. Don't miss out on the fish tacos!
author: Kim M.

description:
Despite its tiny size, this is my go-to sushi place in SF. You'll probably have to wait no matter what time you go, but there are several bars in Hayes valley nearby for a drink while you wait for a text. Some of my faves are the fire tuna balls, IC and Domo roll - absolutely delicious! 

My only small complaint is it's a little frustrating when there are a ton of 2 people groups waiting and they absolutely won't sit anyone at the 3 top in the back just in case a group of 3 walks in and has to be seated asap. But overall, great food and good Hayes valley location!
author: Stephanie E.

description: Don't bother coming here at 10:30 they won't seat you even though they close at 11:00. Last seating should be at 11 not 10:30. Big thumbs down for showing up 30 mins before closing and not seating us. That's BS!
author: Claudia R.

description:
One of the best sushi restaurants in SF and worldwide apart from Japan. Fresh, super creative and unique rolls. You really can't go wrong. The fire tuna ball is really all it's cracked up to be. It's saucy and probably not healthy but super delicious and has a kick. The wiki wiki was a smash hit too with our group. The Castro roll is basically just a rainbow roll and a hit as well. I liked Saba Hit and well actually everything we ordered.

The only drawback of this place is the size. There's only one table that seats 4 people. Otherwise it's mainly bar seating or there's a few 2 people tables inside and outside. It's really a date place! But a great choice for a date place as its intimate, romantic, and the food is delicious plus sushi is great for sharing. The wait can apparently be insane but we got lucky and didn't have to wait too long Put your name down on the clipboard and get a drink nearby.
author: Alison B.

description:
No tables!

What?

Domo  d-o-e-s  n-o-t  have tables.

Okay, I get it. No point in making a reservation. Just show up and hope for the best.

A restaurant without tables would probably be frowned upon in most instances, but not so here, my Sushi loving friend. Tight spot with window front and bar seats. Hipster clientele. And fresh rolls that have a reputation across town.

Domo's menu can be described as experimental - if you're a fan of speciality rolls (and who isn't?!) then you'll dream about their menu for days - SALMON CITRON ($8) not too crazy with a slight hint of citron, just right. DOMO ROLL ($14) , a warm baked california roll with salmon & scallops outside, spicy mayo, unagi glaze, tobiko & scallions. Delicious. And Filling. 

There is so much more to discover on the menu - and I will - as the chefs do great things here we're here to admire.

That deserves a full five star, eh? Yep sure, only thing is they charge for the miso soup,  and tea needs to be requested. Other than that - groovy. One of the best Sushi spots in the city.
author: Sebastian F.

description:
Only bar seating so only good for groups of 2-3 people.

Food: Uni and ankimo crudo were good. Ordered Uni and ikura nigiri, also yummy. Shared a couple of rolls which were ok. 

Service: not great. Staff wasn't very friendly and when one of the waiters was cleaning our bar area and dropped a significant amount of soy sauce on me, no apology was uttered. 

Still searching for a good overall sushi place in Hayes valley.
author: Laura D.

description:
Located in Hayes Valley in San Francisco, this is one of the best sushi joints I've ever been to! Definitely, come early - or better yet, come before they open because lines form quickly! And it's not a big place either - seats maybe 25-30 people max. The best thing about this place is the presentation of their food! The presentation of their dishes looks so great that you take a moment to enjoy looking at it before stuffing your face! :D

For the appetizers, definitely try the carpaccios! They are delish! Their fsh tacos are also a must!  - and no, its not the type that you fold and hold with your hand. All the ingredients are layered up top and it's held up by a round, crispy taco shell on the bottom.

And definitely order the Crudos - which is similar to sashimi but served on a spoon with different seasonings and flavorings.

As far as the rolls/nigiri/sashimi goes, they have the usual and from experience, it just depends on personal experience what you like to order (eg. I don't like my fish cooked - baked or fried - when i order rolls). 

Overall, an excellent sushi joint to come and visit if you're in the San Francisco earlier! The atmosphere is charming and intimate, and the employees are friendly and attentive.
author: Ryan N.

description:
There's a certain vibe that goes on in Hayes Valley.
It's nicely tucked away from the wind so you can sit outside and enjoy a drink while your name gets called off a hand written clipboard hanging off he wall. The chefs are not traditional, but this place is anything, but ordinary. We started with the Spicy Hulk- perfectly wrapped and light on the palette.
After that we were ambushed in the nicest way. Croquettes are not usually in my favorites, but they were crisp and wash down perfectly with a Sapporo. The Domo roll is a must- as with most restaurant's "house roll". This left me with a rush of flavorful, crunchy goodness that leads into the absolute number one reason to come here...
The fish tacos are somehow the best dish in this gem of a sushi treasure. Overall my experience was one I would repeat and would recommend others to do so as well. The man with the glasses? Yes. That's the manager and although he won't crack a smile or offer a warm welcome, this establishment makes up for it in terms of food selection, eclectic dishes and overall warm atmosphere. In contrast, his staff was very accommodating and always stopped by at the right time to follow up with the dishes that were being brought out. Price should rarely be a factor, especially in this neighborhood, but leaving perfectly satisfied at about $30 per person- drinks included seem like a great deal.
I recommend this for a casual date night or to catch up with a friend over some drinks. (4.5/5 Stars)
author: Jony V.

description: Just amazing. First date spot in SF, sat right by the window during a rainy night and it was a wonderful night. We go here all the time, and it's consistently great. Very small, so tough for parties bigger than 3, but that adds to the charm. Pro tip- put your name down, and go to one of the many bars in Hayes for a drink to kill some time. M
author: SR S.

description:
Long-ish wait (30-50 min) but definitely worth it!

1- really small restaurant, wait was shorter if we sat outside, so didnt really get to experience the ambience. Sitting outside was a little weird because we were across from people sitting and waiting to be seated.

2- service was slow just to get drink orders and place food orders, but once we did, the food came out quickly.

3- appetizers. Cucumber sunomono was fresh and not super sweet like you find at many of the cheaper sushi spots.

4- rolls! Fire tuna balls were good, not too spicy. Salmon citron was good, but fire tuna balls were better. ALPHA ROLL WAS AMAZING.

Definitely get the Alpha Roll!
author: Kimia M.

description: This is me and my boyfriend's go-to date night sushi place! We've been here at least four times now and have tried almost every roll on the menu! Our favorite is definitely the Temptation roll and the Kobe beef roll is also worth trying. The best way to do it is order a couple rolls and share. Highly recommend to people who love sushi. Plus the sashimi is delicious - tastes super fresh. Try the Otoro/Toro! Perfect fattiness. If there's a long wait, try asking for outdoor seating and bring a jacket. Otherwise, be prepared for around a 30 minute wait.
author: Haley A.

description:
Domo is the place for all things fresh (FISH!) in Hayes Valley. 

This cozy sushi spot is worth the parking headaches or Muni ickiness. There's usually a wait since they don't take reservations, but 30 min wasn't bad. Gladly squeeze yourself in between patrons at the almost non-existent waiting area and hold onto your green tea while you warm your hands up. 

The best seats are actually the ones facing Laguna to check out the street action, but we liked our corner sushi bar chairs.

Despite being run by non-Japanese folks and having more "saucy" rolls on the menu, the fish is very fresh and the place is neat and clean.  Loved the Old School Negi Hama and Salmon Citron rolls (the shiso was a nice touch!) The temptation roll was devoured fast: shrimp tempura, unagi, avocado and crab. You really can't go wrong with that combo. 

Walked out into the cool San Francisco night with a warm feeling and a full belly. Domo Arigato!
author: Janice C.

description: I am really picky about sushi and good sushi in NYC is super expensive.  We have so many sushi joints but most are run by people that do not give a shet about quality or good fish.  Warm, mushy, flavorless fish is usually what is on the menu.  But not here.  The sushi here was glorious.  I tried pretty much all the special sushi pieces and each one melted in my mouth.  Wish I could get sushi this good at a these prices in my city. If anyone knows of a place, send me a message and let me know!
author: M A.

description:
I'm a sushi snob.

What's fresh +'s:
+ Fish taco appetizer
+ Window seating that allows you to look at passerbys in hip Hayes Valley

What's fishy -'s:
- Limited seating. Meant an interminable 45' wait even though we were #2 on the list. 
- Nigiri was not memorable. Did the chefs not season their rice or fish?
- Service was nonexistent. Meaning we got served and forgotten.

Overall I can't figure out why everyone has highly rated Domo. This place is not 4-5 stars when there are places such as Ichi which ranks at 4-5 stars. No comparison. Period.
author: Yiven C.

description:
Great, fresh sushi. 

It is a quaint restaurant and quite cozy for a date night. There is bar seating only; facing sushi bar or windows (which allows for excellent people watching). There are also a few small outdoor tables. Service was friendly and quick. 

Ordered the Dragon roll from the day's specials. It was amazing. Highly recommend if it's an option. 

Will definitely be back to try more rolls!
author: Caroline L.

description: Sushi solid is here. I did love the fried octopus, must get. There's so many other great places in the city for sushi, with better sushi, atmosphere and service. If you want to go here for the hype and check it out, that's OK. But otherwise, I would take my sushi cravings elsewhere in the city.
author: Sonia A.

description:
This place is a gem! We ordered 4 items from the menu and each was a strong dish on its own! Our least favorite is probably the kobe beef roll which is not bad at all. But compared to other things we ordered, it's a pale comparison.

1. Dynamite mussels: our favorite hands down!! It was creamy and delish. Baked and topped with tobiko
2. Uni and scallop crudos (tasting spoon): the uni was creamy and just wonderful. Scallop was refreshing with a hint of saltiness and cucumber to balance out the taste. $8 for 2 tasting spoons is considered a bargain when you get a generous amount of uni.
3. Wiki wiki roll: has layers of taste and it's not just a typical roll. There are different things that you can taste in one bite
4. Kobe beef: too creamy because of avocado. It drowns the taste of the beef itself

Service is a bit slow and portion is a little small (but just right for me) but I will definitely go back for more!
author: Cliff T.

description:
Dear Domo, I love you.  Seriously.  I travel to SF a few times a year for work and eat here every. Single. Time.  At least once, usually more than once each trip.  Yes, it's that good.  It's not odd for me to eat here multiple nights in a row.  It's that good.  I refuse to tell all but a few very close colleagues where this place is, because I don't want a bunch of them coming here when 30+ of us are in town.  It's that good.  

Tucked in on an alley corner, this place is tiny, with only one table for 3 and the other 15 seats or so "bar style".  I love seeing how they utilize every square inch of their space for storage, etc.  my bedroom is bigger than the entire restaurant, and I don't live in a palatial house.  Anyhow, enough about the place, now on to those scrumptious bites.  

I prefer to come here with one or two people so I can order and eat a little of  everything I want from the menu, because I'm not that much of a gluttonous pig on my own.  The hulk roll, domo roll, red dragon roll, spiced tuna balls, albacore nigiri, spicy tuna, I could go on and on.  Always super fresh, always quick service.  

Downfalls- usually a line (but it moves quickly), they don't serve liquor (beer, sake and plum wine only) and they don't take American Express.
author: Lola W.

description:
DOMO ARIGATO!

After downing an entire bottle of 40 proof shochu by myself: http://bit.ly/GB7K6r, I spent the night bowing and saying, "Domo Arigato!" like a crazy woman when we got home. Apparently, even to my Pomeranian (no wonder he was tilting his head and looking at me all funny). 

"WTF is wrong with you?" asks, Mr. NSS. "I'm like that blonde chick on MTV's 'Money From Strangers', she has to bow and say, 'Domo Arigato' to everyone in the sushi restaurant to get the $1,000", I replied. "The only thing you'll be getting is a bad hangover tomorrow", the smart ass said. Well, no hangover today so HA!

The older I get, convenience and comfort are my bffs. Not wanting to travel far for dinner, we decided to go to Domo which is near my work. Even though Domo boosts 4 stars on Yelp, I was a bit weary going in after reading some reviews that it was a Chinese owned sushi joint. While I'm 3/4ths Chinese myself, I prefer going to Japanese owned sushi joints because most have a purist approach to sushi which is what real sushi is; no CA rolls and no bukkake of sauces all over. Would you eat an 21-day dry aged bone in ribeye covered in gravy? Doubt it; so the same thing applies with sushi. The purer the better. 

Domo doesn't take reservations and it's small with just 14 counter seats and three two-top tables outside so come early to avoid the wait. 

Fitting for the neighborhood, Domo offers an array of jiveass rolls which they seem to be known for. But what separates Domo from other sushi joints in the same category is they serve solid nigiri to appease the purist sushi snobs as well. I dare say, it was better than some Japanese owned restaurants I've been to like the overrated Eiji in the Castro. 

For $100 pre-tip, dinner for two was very reasonable for sushi especially with a  bottle of shochu. 

OUR ORDER:
*Crudos: Ankimo, Hotate, Spicy Tuna & Sake ($14): http://bit.ly/1aOG5It
*Fish Tacos ($8): http://bit.ly/GB4nwz
*Hamachi Kama ($12): http://bit.ly/17x2gTP
*Sake Toro, Kanji, Hamachi Toro, Hamachi & Sake Nigiri ($5-$5.50/pair): http://bit.ly/1g7ttAa
*Unagi ($5): http://bit.ly/GBlEVp

The Crudos were a great way to start dinner. They sadly didn't have uni available last night so I settled for the ankimo (monkfish liver) and hotate (scallop) while Mr. NSS for the spicy tuna and sake (salmon). Both of my Crudos were very fresh with a nice tang from the ponzu sauce. They don't compare to Koo's Spoonful of Happiness though which is in a league of its own. 

The Fish Tacos were surprisingly stellar. Crunchy tempura battered seaweed topped with avocado, a thick slice of salmon and tuna that was slightly torched then a generous dollop of housemade salsa. It was Japo-Mexi fusion done right. 

The star of the night was the Hamachi Collar. It was perfectly broiled which left with a yummy crisp skin. The flesh was insanely buttery and flaked off with the fork with minimal effort. What made this the BEST Hamachi collar was the accompanying ponzu sauce. Not sure what was in there but it was like phuckin' liquid crack. If you see this on the specials menu make sure to order this. Lucky for us, it was available last night. 

For a place that's known for their jive ass rolls, the sushi chef made some solid nigiri. My only gripe was the fish selection was minimal but of no fault of the chef since the owner is usually the one who controls the ordering. If they broaden their selection, I would love to try their omakase to see what they chef can really do.

We stayed with the more fattier selections like sake, hamachi, sake toro, hamachi toro, and kanji (trout; tastes like sake) and were not disappointed. The buttery cuts were blanketed over perfectly seasoned shari (sushi rice) and each bite made me want to kick myself for not coming to Domo sooner. Since I'm not a fan of tamago, we ended dinner with rich unagi which was glazed with a savory sweet sauce. This usually takes the place of dessert but not going to lie, we went to Smitten afterwards for some Kelvin action. 

Service at Domo was excellent. The staff was very friendly, attentive, and timely. They work in a very small space with no real kitchen so what they do, they do it well. 

I'm adding Domo to my sushi rotation which means poor Mr. NSS will have to endure a whole lot more of Domo Arigato, Domo Arigato, DOMOOO ARIGAAATOOOO!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
I came here with a group of four at 830pm. We waited around 30 minutes as it had super limited space, like everything around downtown SF. 

Food: a friend from my group knew the guy behind the bar and he was super nice and let us try a variety of appetizers. The memorable ones were the Hawaiian style tuna poke (very unique dish, loved the mix of tuna, seaweed, and fish eggs), Uni (he gave us a good portion of Uni on spoons), fish tacos (the variety of fishes on this taco made this dish so delicious). I would highly recommend trying out appetizers, the blend of ingredients in these dishes made them so delicious.

Aside from appetizers we also got some rolls. The temptation roll (had a creamy crab taste) and domo roll were yummy. 

Definitely try to come with a group and share a variety of plates as each plate is very unique in its own way. Very different than a normal sushi bar.
author: Beth H.

description:
not sure if maybe I ordered the wrong things but I was not impressed... 

I was in the neighbohood at the Beirgarten for a friend's going away this past Sunday and turned to my trust yelp app to see what bookmarks I had nearby. Domo popped up as something that I have been wanting to try for a while so a short walk later, I am in front of Domo. It's a cute little restaurant and very intimate. It was close to 6 and there was no wait at all and only a couple of tables. I got a to-go order of the two items

Ahi Poke - This was a botom layer of seaweed salad followed by a  mix of tuna, white tuna, and octopus topped with green onions and tobiko. It could have used less sauce and was a little too sweet for my taste

Sashimi Salad - So not worth like the $13 for like 4 pieces of sashimi and lettuce... 

might give it another chance but not anytime soon
author: Tao Tao W.

description: Pretty good sushi, really small space, fine service.  Plan on waiting a while for a seat.  I particularly enjoyed the Kobe beef roll, which was cooked and seasoned perfectly.  The sashimi combination was about average, nothing out of the ordinary.  Overall fish quality seemed good.
