I am talking about genuine sushi -- the kind of sushi that makes life on earth worth living -- and the kind that enables men and nations to grow and to hope and build a better sushi for their children -- not merely sushi for Americans but sushi for all men and women -- not merely sushi in our time but sushi in all time.

It's like Nanking on Columbus. Rachael Ray went there, $40 a day,  and she loved it.
So you know what I mean.

What a waste of money.
I did not like it.
Why should I go back?
Sorry, not my kind, I know better places.

Btw, You know it sucks the place payin 300 bucks to Yelp for the Ad and seeing honest review like mine.
Yelp has to remove my review over and over!
But Heck no, I won't give up either for tellin' the truth!
author: Nobu K.

description:
Domo is a great place for some good Japanese food. 

I started off with the edamame, miso soup, and seaweed salad appetizers followed by spoonfuls of small crudos. The salmon crudo was fresh and perfect with the small wedge of avocado. The spicy tuna crudo had a nice kick to it with the addition of the sriracha hot sauce. The scallop crudo was wonderfully balanced with delicious seasoning. Last but not least, the uni was delicate, bright, and very fresh. Really, how else would you prefer sea urchin gonads for consumption? Mmm... That's some serious good eats!

Moving on, I ordered some of the sushi rolls including the Fire Cracker Balls, Sexy Mama, and the Domo Roll. Each were fantastic with Sexy Mama being my favorite! The Sexy Mama is really great if you love the taste of citrus in every bite because it's completely lined with thinly sliced lemons. Yum!

Domo is located in Hayes Valley in a cool neighborhood, perfect for outdoor seating. 

Service was attentive and friendly!
author: Ann S.

description: Damn good place! Small spot so only go with one person. Everything we ordered was fresh & yummy! I would skip the spicy hulk tuna not that it was bad just not my favorite! I can't wait to go back!
author: Melisa O.

description: Best sushi in SF.  Every piece of fish is of very high quality and well prepared.  Service is excellent.
author: Tristan M.

description:
This was some of the best sushi I've had in a very long time!! Although, I have to admit that I enjoy more adventurous plates rather than traditional rolled sushi, so this is an adequate review if that is what you're looking for.  We ordered six plates to split and tried a bit of most of them: 

Hawaiian Style Poke: Might have been the best Poke I've ever had! The addition of the seaweed salad and the octopus made it phenomenal. 

Kobe Beef Roll: Might have been my favorite unique dish of the night. The flavors were delicious and it was a nice alternative to traditional sushi rolls. 

Fire Cracker Balls:  Good, but I've had other fried sushi before and this was about on par. Would order again though. 

Butterfish Nigiri: Just because :) 

Not sure what the last roll was because I did not try it, but it was apparently good as well.  

Overall a great dining experience even though you should go into it knowing you will need to expect a wait!  Put your name down on the list and head across the street for a drink while you wait!
author: Raina D.

description: Excellent little sushi place. Service was friendly and everything tasted really fresh.  The place is pretty tiny inside but has a nice casual neighborhood feel to it.  Can't wait to go back
author: Debbie L.

description:
Great sushi at a super affordable price.  Beware that there's not a ton of seating in here, so you may want to arrive a bit early.  My girlfriend and I were lucky enough to grab two window seats so we could watch foot-traffic whilst enjoying our meal.

All of their fish was notably fresh!  I would highly recommend ordering a few special rolls and some items off of their special menu.  I've only been here once, but it was far better than any Japanese restaurants I've encountered in SoMA.
author: Andrew H.

description: Walked in to domo sushi on a Saturday night with some friends, expecting standard SF sushi fare. Domo defied expectations in every way. The place is very small and intimate - it seats probably 30 at most. The food is simply amazing. I had the Fire Tuna Balls, friends had less adventurous fare like California and red dragon rolls - "this is the best California roll over ever had," more than one time was heard. The food was also pretty fast and the staff was very friendly. I can't wait to come back and sample more.
author: Patrick W.

description:
Nothing bad, but nothing truly great. Itsa an a-ok joint. Got there @ about 5:45 no line and not too noisy. Not a Hayes valley hipster, just a Hayes Valley visitor ( it is great and amazing how each SF neighborhood has its own distinct vibe ). Being  a bit of a Japanese food snob, I was kinda underwhelmed with Domo... especially based on many rave reviews. I kinda think the expectations of diners poking sushi in their mouth has gone down, or perhaps more accurately maybe they just don't know any better. Yup, I will admit I LOL when someone raves about how the Edemame is cooked, and I have gotten grumpy about hearing how wonderful the cutesy "rolls" are at joint like this.  

Dinner with 2 friends @ one of the rare (maybe the only) 3 person table. Thought the fish was ok. Had all of the usual nigiri treats & a roll. Having not seen one friend for quite a while, we were a chatty group. As reported it is a small & popular place. 

Service is best described as odd, with the space cadet waiter accidentally poring tea into one of the water glasses on the table. After a few seconds the  realization  that the cheap glass tumbler was not a tea cup gripped his face.  Maybe he was trying to make iced tea. Hmmm but there was no ice. Once the sushi was mostly gone off of the plates, started feeling rushed, like hearing "anything else you would like?" 3 times. I then felt like saying "good service" would be a start. 

Kinda wished we had gone to Suppenküche a few doors down for a high calorie German fare with no apology.. Only in SF could you have this kind of distorted dining thought, like oh I just had an OK Japanese dinner but maybe should  have gone to Suppenkuche.
author: Matsuo U.

description: Way too crowded to relax while you eat your overpriced Sushi. Saw a chef go out, walk down the street, smoke a cigarette and the come back AND BEGIN TO MAKE SUSHI AGAIN WITHOUT WASHING HIS HANDS.. NO thank you.
author: Brian W.

description:
Sunday night on a unusually warm SF night (it hits 75!), I decide to pop in at Domo with a friend.  We had to wait for 30 minutes for a table - not bad especially given the entertainment options on Laguna/Hayes.

We were given a seat by the window bar and our food was brought out within minutes of ordering.  I was slightly taken back at how quick their service was (almost suspiciously so), but all that melted away alongside that first Fiesta roll.  

My choice for the evening: Fiesta roll (deliciously fresh), spicy tuna (yummm), firecracker balls (it's like a party in your mouth), and the scallop crudo (could have done without this one...it was too chewy and lacked the buttery flavor). 

One quick tip - if you plan on coming here, do it in 2's.  There was a 3 person party that had to wait much, much longer.
author: Nikki G.

description:
Best sushi I've ever had. Hands down. 

The restaurant is TINY. It can hold about 15 people max, so expect a bit of a wait since they don't take reservations or call-ins. We came at about 7:50pm on a Thursday night and were seated at 8:30pm. Since there are so few patrons seated at once, the wait is very dependent on when people sat down. Sign your name on the sheet out front to get on the wait list.

I always have trouble keeping track of what I eat at sushi restaurants, so I know I'm forgetting a few items and probably mistaking one or two, but here's the breakdown to the best of my ability:

My Top 3 Favorites:
+ Small Crudos. These are little spoonfuls of goodness. We got one Uni (Sea Urchin) and one Ankimo (Monkfish Liver Pate). I tried the sea urchin and was blown away. Flavorful, delicious. My date seemed to enjoy the monkfish liver pate.

+ Hamachi Carpachio, but they were out of Hamachi, so my date had the brilliant idea to ask for Butterfish instead. SO GOOD. My favorite thing all night.

+ Fried octopus. A mound of little octopuses on top of arugula. I didn't think I liked octopus, but I was so very wrong. This competed with the Carpachio for my favorite item all night.

Other Deliciously Fresh Items:
+ Miso soup. Can you really go wrong with miso soup?
+ Octopus Nigiri - made with a bit of wasabi
+ Butterfish Nigiri - I'm officially obsessed with Butterfish
+ Tuna Nigiri 
+ Salmon Nigiri 
+ Sea Urchin - Also one of my new favorite things ever

Everything I had here was great. Highly recommend if you're willing to wait a bit and throw down for some good quality seafood. 

Bargain Alert: They have a $13 lunch special: Soup and Salad with your choice of Chirashi, Sashimi salad, Open Face Dragon, Sushi Combo, or Maki Combo.
author: Talia G.

description: Best sushi I have ever had. I'm obsessed. We got the Kobe beef roll, Domo roll, crab balls and another roll. 5 stars hands down. Can't wait to come back!
author: Patricia L.

description: Favorite sushi place in the city. Super small, don't  recommend going in groups larger than 2. Get the temptation roll, soo good, and the fish tacos. Also I had read reviews about the fried octopus special- got it and didn't like it at all so wouldn't get that. But everything else I have gotten has been great
author: Kelli L.

description:
Great sushi joint with fresh and creative rolls. In order of deliciousness, I thought the fish tacos were best, then dragon roll, then jalapeño himachi, and finally the castro. 

Would have given four stars based on food but the hostess snuck us in at 9:50pm and was super friendly/nice
author: Sandeep M.

description: My boyfriend and I were so excited to try this place after hearing so many good things from friends. Sadly their service was terrible! After waiting at a nearby bar for about 30 minutes we politely checked in with the hostess to check our place on the list. The hostess ignored us for the first couple of minutes and when we finally got her attention she was incredibly rude. Instead of waiting, we decided to hop over to the restaurant next door which was equally as busy where we were greeted right away by their super friendly host. Sorry Domo, maybe next time!
author: Margot G.

description:
How I dearly wish that Domo would take reservations!  My cousins, who grew up in Japan all their lives, and I went to this restaurant on a non-holiday Sunday night - wait was still 45 minutes long!  It was worth it, though, because I got to impress my 3 young tastebuds with one of the best Americanized sushi experiences :)  We made a point to only order rolls (for an obvious reason - the cousins get the real deal in Japan).  Wow, every roll was so well made!  Fresh ingredients and innovative construction.  We especially enjoyed the following rolls:
- fire cracker balls
- dragon
- domo roll
- castro
- crunch california

P. S. They offer iichiko hot sake, and I highly recommend it!  Such a smooth hot sake to go along with the meal!
author: Lindsey O.

description: After we spent the day together enjoying the City, wanted some sushi; however, Horrible sushi never again got sick off fish $70 for sushi that wasn't fresh and sadly the service lacked. I can't say id recommend this place to anyone and only say if you do decide to try it just make sure fish is fresh so you end get sick like I did. Sorry it was just awful
author: Gabriela W.

description:
Went late on a Sunday night and didn't expect there to be a wait.. but there was! I think that's better than no way at all anyway. We weren't too hungry but we got a good amount. It's a very small restaurant with just 1-2 servers and 1 hostess. The bathroom is SUPER nice and clean.. just the way it should be! 

On to the food... we got the hamachi/jalapeno roll.. the hamachi was good but the jalapeno didn't have as much flavor. I still prefer the good old negi hama rolls (hamachi with green onions!). Also got salmon nigiri and albacore toro. We also go the domo roll.. which is a baked roll with salmon and scallops. I usually wouldn't go for the baked rolls or even LOVE it.. but this one was good and is worth a try! Lastly, we go their special: Wiki Wiki roll which was topped with butterfish and has shitake mushroom tempura in side. Perfect crunch!
author: WENDY K.

description: They've gotten a lot better since my last visit with the seating and the rolls themselves are fabulous.
author: Grace L.

description:
Cute and intimate (small) spot. 

Delicious food... I mean have you seen their fish taco. You now must TASTE the fish taco. Whoever thought they I'm gonna put this fish taco on a deep fries piece of nori... Genius, and for $8 for two. You can also add additional taco for $4 

Love that they had toro negi $10 in their special rolls. That was yummy
author: Tiffany N.

description:
Overall I think that Domo is a good restaurant and not a bad place if you want to get Sushi. It is very small and if you do not show up early you should plan on waiting for a bit, especially on a weekend - every time I walk by it is always packed. This is a sushi restaurant with sashimi, nigiri and rolls; there is not an option of chicken teryaki or anything similar so keep that in mind.

The quality of the fish they serve is good and getting one or two of the special rolls written on the mirror is probably the best course of action. Overall it is a little overpriced compared to similar restaurants in the area that have just as high quality of fish that I can tell. 

The one thing I can not understand is why it has consistently smelled like a sewer in front of this restaurant for months now (unfortunate location maybe?). Because of this I would definitely not opt to eat outside. Hopefully this is not an issue anymore though.
author: Frank J.

description:
Cute little sushi place in Hayes Valley with some inventive rolls (the firecracker roll in particular was awesome). Everything was tasty, the waiters kept it coming and I didn't have to wait forever for a check. I only went with one other person and we sat at the "bar" that's in front of the windows. Didn't feel that cramped because you're staring out through glass.

The only thing that marred my experience was it was a little weird for them to ask me to put my name on a paper list when there was no one inside and they immediately sat me.
author: Joshua B.

description:
I must be in a generous mood today. It's probably because I had a great night last night. 

Domo is an authentic little sushi bar that also has a fairly complete menu. 

Everything we had was amazing sake, maguro, uni, domo roll was ok not the best item on the menu. 

Terrible place for kids, groups and bad attitudes.
author: Joseph M.

description:
Uh....dang.

 I have NEVER in my life had sushi this delectable and dreamy. The fish is really fresh and the rolls are just amazing. I want to say awesome, but the word is just too plain in comparison to what the sushi actually is. 

For starters, I ordered two orders of uni. So dang fresh, I closed my eyes and had dreams of ocean living. My husband, on the other hand, liked watching me.

The place is small and crowded- elbow to elbow crowded. While waiting for seats, my husband (oh yay, I can actually say that now!) and I met a really cool couple, whom we ended up buying their desserts cause they were just that awesome, or it could have been the sake that I was feelin while I was waiting as well. 

Let's get back to the nitty gritty. The sushi was amazing. We ordered the Domo roll, which was a crazy roll that was california roll with scallops and salmon or hamachi and some other stuff I can't even remember right now, but damn, that roll was made up from some crazy imagination, it was HELLA GOOD. The sauce was somewhat garlicky, which I believe was the magic of it all. Mmm. I'm dreaming of it right now.

We also ordered the Spicy Hulk. Man. Unbelievably fantasmic. Great for spicy lovers, which I am famous for, wonderful for tuna lovers, which I am not. So it says A WHOLE LOTTA SOMETHING.

The reason why I'm not giving it 5 stars is because when we ordered mochi for dessert, please tell me why my husband saw them pull individual mochi balls from the box of 6 that I can buy at Pacific Super for $4.59 and then get charged $3 per ball on a fancy little dish with acrab fork? Everyone who eats this mochi ball knows we don't need utensils!!! BOO!

I'm coming back! But not order mochi. I'll just bring it in my purse, just to be ghetto.
author: Sharon B.

description:
I'm pretty much in love with Domo. This pint-sized sushi nook is one of my favorite places in the whole city--the service is excellent and the sushi is always delicious. One of my favorite SF activities is grabbing a couple of rolls and a Sapporo or two (or four) on a late weeknight with a pal. 

If you go on the weekend and it's terribly crowded (which it always is), you can leave your phone number next to your name and grab a drink at one of the nearby bars.

It's a casual, sweet spot to cozy up next to someone you love over sushi. Sounds like the perfect date to me. :)
author: Meredith C.

description: Excellent sushi, great service and an intimate setting. My sister and I went there for lunch with my baby and they were so accommodating. The vibe you immediately pick up is pleasant and chill. Can't wait to go back. 6 stars! Love this place.
author: Camille A.

description:
We found this place while searching for options for our first nights dinner in San Francisco. It was a few blocks away from out hotel and had raving reviews. We walked on over and even though it's quite small with there being only 1 actual table and the rest bar seating we got seats right away. The staff was on top of everything and very nice. We ordered a bottle of sake, a seaweed salad and 4 rolls. 
All of our food came out pretty quick and did not disappoint at all! We left full and happy from the deliciousness of our dinner! The price wasn't bad either it was about 20% less then we usually pay at home in Orlando when we go out for sushi! If you're looking for a good night out head on over to Domo!
author: Katie H.

description:
I love this small sushi bar tucked away quietly in a neighborhood. The seats are always full so there is a bit of a wait, but it's nothing unusual for good restaurants in this city. Great sushi at reasonable prices. Another big plus is they always have uni, so if you are a fan of the prickly sea creature ~ you won't ever have to be disappointed.

I've been here twice and both times the service has been excellent. So to sum it all up good atmosphere + good food + good service = Domo. Thanks again for a great night.
author: Jasper S.

description:
This place is tiny and only has bar seating, but we arrived at 5:30pm on a weekday so we didn't have to wait. The seaweed salad was pretty standard, and the crudos (salmon, spicy tuna) were fine, nothing to write home about. The Saba hit roll was mediocre and a bit bland, but the Domo roll was great. It was warm and flavorful and completely redeemed the meal. 

The service was friendly and the other specialty rolls looked really good, so I'm excited to come back and try more. But reading some other reviews, I'm not sure I would wait over an hour to eat here. Also, because of the seating availability, I would only come with a party of 2 or 3.
author: Audrey M.

description:
Creative rolls, great sushi with daily specials. The food was delicious and you can sit in front of the windows facing the street and people watch. They also have outdoor seating, which is nice on a warm day. 
My fav: red dragon rolls and domo rolls. 
Note: The place is pretty small so seatings are limited.
author: Nancy Z.

description: So my review may be biased since I cannot eat fish or shellfish so I usually don't eat sushi but none the less I tried their sweet potato roll, and a avocado roll, both were absolutely Devine, this is a cute place to sit at the window and watch people while eating with a friend. Very fast friendly service also. Parking wasn't to hard to find.
author: Nelanne C.

description: Our first time there since we were in town. And they did not disappoint. We loved the fish tacos and Domo roll! WILL DEFINITELY BE BACK!
author: Sandra P.

description: Interesting rolls selection. Great service.  Cute and intimate atmosphere (love the wood theme) although it's tiny. I wish the fish portions on the rolls were bigger is the only thing. I think the nice thing about this place is if you get discouraged about the wait, there's plenty of other restaurants nearby to choose from. But if you can wait it out, you'll be pretty pleased with the selections
author: Melissa T.

description: Amazing sushi creations and extremely fresh sashimi offerings. I'd advise getting there early but it's well worth it! Also, groups of 2 seem to work best. Actually, speaking of a group of 2, this would make for a great date spot - cozy seating, shared plates - it's practically Paris on a budget, and in California, and ok, without the Eiffel Tower to gaze up at while enjoying a nice bottle of wine. But back to Domo, this place is great, possibly my favorite new restaurant of the summer, and definitely somewhere worth checking out!
author: Erin W.

description:
This sushi place is DELICIOUS! 

We ordered the following rolls and I highly recommend ALL THREE: 
-Veggie: At first I was skeptical of this role since it wouldn't have any meat...but it is delicious! It could be the shiitake that gives the rolls a chewiness that mimics meat. The combination of the different flavors also make this really delicious. We liked it so much that we ordered another one!
-Fiesta: This is a great roll especially if you like tuna. It features a slight twist in the taste due to the mango and black pepper salsa, the right kick to warrant its name, Fiesta!
-Sweet Potato: This roll is also deceivingly tasty. It's not as sweet as you think it'd be so I'd give it a try.

Overall, this sushi place has very unique rolls that have an amazing taste! 

As with all sushi restaurants, I just wish that I got more food for my money!
author: Lillian C.

description:
This is the other sushi place in the area. Unlike O-toro, it's pretty much all sushi and sashimi. No fillers (re: noodles, chicken skewers, etc.).

If you've got a big appetite like me I'd peg it closer to 2.5-3 dollar signs.

That being said, the place is great, and there are tons of tasteful rolls to try -- that is, they're novel enough to be interesting, but conventional enough to call sushi (cheese and creamcheese in your roll is not strictly sushi IMO, but we can take that conversation offline).

All in all a fun sushi place for twos, much harder for anything larger since bar seating dominates. We did squeeze four on a table though, so it is doable. Waits can be long since spacing is limited.
author: Christophe C.

description: The food was pretty good. But the we had a particularly odd experience with the service. They were really nice when we got there, sat us very quickly and took our order right away. Then they seemed to completely forget about us. We asked to order food and the waiter thought we had already ordered. At the end of the meal, after we had paid our bill, we were finishing our drinks and the hostess told us she needed our table and we would need to finish up and leace. Ive never had that happen to me at a restaurant and it put a very bad taste in my mouth.
author: Elizabeth W.

description:
This place is pretty much a true hole-in-the-wall, but it's a nice find on a part of Laguna Street where many years ago I would've never expected to find a sushi restaurant.  The place is small. with only about 15 seats inside pus some outside seating on days that they put tables out on the sidewalk.  There's nothing fancy about the decor.  In fact, I'd say it's the most closet-like decor (for lack of a better description) that I've been to.

As for the food, it seems to be all about sushi and sashimi.  Do not come here expecting to order tempuras or other cooked items.  The sashimi was pretty fresh and tasty.  Unfortunately, I was given a bad initial impression by the sushi chef (the Asian one) when I said hi after being seated at the sushi bar and got no response.  He even kinda looked away.  Some star rating deduction for that.
author: H K.

description:
Don't come if you're looking for traditional sushi. 
Come here if you're looking for fun, unique rolls!

1. Spicy Hulk (spicy tuna & avocado, tobiko wrapped in a cucumber sheet with lemon ponzu): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/xeRy4mjZWczet5V9Jtmx1g?select=tDIlLytWufqR3wrHTRlKZQ
+ Refreshing with the cucumber sheet
+ Very light with the ponzu sauce
- Tuna quality was so-so and not too spicy

2. Kobe Beef (asparagus, ginger, avacado, ponzu & seared american kobe beef outside): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/xeRy4mjZWczet5V9Jtmx1g?select=1EJ0Bm8dsIVLMfIoC7zM6w
+ Beef was extremely tender, and soft
- Too oily on the bottom

3. Special: Apollo (avocado, cucumber, shiso roll topped with baked scallops, crab, and tobiko): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/xeRy4mjZWczet5V9Jtmx1g?select=zEqaJY3rgbWqp_hJ2vY1Kg
- Nothing special -- too many together, wasn't really able to taste individual components

4. Sashimi (3 pieces of tuna, yellowtail, salmon, albacore): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/xeRy4mjZWczet5V9Jtmx1g?select=Z81nMnJn36N8iWsnwfi7KA
- NOT WORTH IT AT ALL. Sashimi pieces were of poor quality. Didn't taste fresh (had that mushy texture)

Overall, sushi was just unique, but not the best quality. A bit expensive for not a lot of pieces per roll.

BEST PART: The bathroom was extremely modern, cute, and most importantly...clean!

Tips:
1. VERY SMALL - not good for big parties!
2. Sign your name on the board in the front
3. Park on the side streets around it -- free metered parking after 6!
author: Evelyn S.

description:
Their sushi, sake and service are all solid.

Ambiance: The space is small but cozy.

Service:  Friendly and staff is always willing to clarify ingredients with the chef.

Food (gluten-free dairy-free perspective): They have Tamari (which is gluten-free soy sauce) available at request.  Many of their rolls are gluten and dairy free or can be customized to be.  One of my favorites is the Mexican-inspired Fiesta roll.  Domo is popular on weekend evenings and combined with the small space, you can expect a short or long wait depending upon the size of your party.  I generally frown upon waiting more than 15 minutes for restaurants and since they don't take reservations, I always have a nearby backup.  So if you're like me and want to enjoy their delicious food, plan to go early or during a less busy week night.
author: G B.

description:
Thanks to Yelp, we found another good Sushi Place close by our area. 

   We got here on the Wednesday cold evening so there were no line or no long waiting. The service was decent but the best part of all is the food itself.

 We had Crunchy California, Fire Ball and Temptation Roll, plus Chef's Sushi selection. They're all good. 

  We will definitely coming back for more.
author: Dom G.

description:
Great small place for sushi.  With so many great choices in the city, it's hard to find the right balance of quality, price and ambiance.
We came here around 8pm on a Thursday night and only had to wait for about 5 minutes for 3 people.  We ordered a bunch of stuff and the bill only came out to $100 - not bad.  
These were some of my favorites:
Fish Tacos - tempura-fried seaweed with salmon, avocado and some kind of salsa on top
Fiesta Roll - albacore tuna, mango & cilantro with black pepper salsa

Solid place for sushi.
author: Michele S.

description: It may not be a large place but they have some amazing sushi! If you end up having to wait to be seated, it's worth it! You won't be disappointed in the food. My friend and I shared a lot of amazing rolls. It was hard to pick my favorite one. I highly recommend Domo the next time you're craving sushi.
author: Ryan B.

description:
Got here around 6:30 on a Sunday night.  We were seated right away by the window, which made for interesting visuals as it was Bay to Breakers day.  :)

The servers were very friendly & the food came out at a perfect pace.

We started with the Daikon Salad.  Delicious!  I loved the dressing that that they used.  Wasn't overly dressed either.

We also had the Sake sashimi, which was melt in your mouth fresh!  

The jalapeño himachi is something to try if you like a little bit of kick.  It's basically just a plain roll with rice, himachi, fresh jalapeño and seaweed.  It was awesome!

We felt daring so we decided to try one of their interesting rolls... The Mac Daddy.  Tempura veggies and avocado rolled up with fresh salmon on top.  SO good!  

We ended with their Toro.  Mmmmmm

2 things that stood out to me was the freshness of their fish and the rice to fish ratio.  Not too much rice.  Just perfect.  I believe that less is more. :)
author: Delilah B.

description:
If you go to Domo expecting a traditional sushi experience, you might be disappointed. This is a Fusion project and it should be appreciated as such.

Had the Spicy Hulk - it was refreshingly not overly spiced up. I was still able to taste the freshness of the fish. Clearly, it wasn't some old/frozen tuna disguised as an innovative dish.

Had some hamachi toro. Yumm. You can never go wrong with that... Until you see hamachi belly nigiri right before you write a review. Ugh.

Fish tacos - real interesting layers of flavor. Tasty. And difficult to eat (that may be just me). Slightly greasy from the fried base.

Albacore toro. - fresh, so as expected it was good.

Madagascar something-something. Hmmm. My first time to eat raw shrimp. It tasted cooked, but it the texture was a little chewy from the rawness. It didn't taste gross, try it.

My regret was not getting anything omakase, whether it was nigiris or sushi. Go for it!

Missing a star because I felt like the dishes were missing their oooomph. However the service was awesome, kudos!
author: Paulyne R.

description:
My girlfriend and I went to Sushi Zone originally, and the place was junky and cramped, watched one table take about 10 minutes to get tea (only one waitress and one guy cooking, other two were standing watching the one man making rolls). 

So we walked over to Domo and were so glad that we did!

Excellent variety, cozy atmosphere, attentive service, and tasty rolls means this was an stellar find!  Just having a server that notices when your out of tea makes a huge difference in the experience, and the candle lit window seating was the icing on the cake.

4 out of 5, not 5 because I've had better sushi elsewhere (Tomodachi in Hayward for instance has a Tuna Poki puts this one to shame!)
author: Sean K.

description: My neighborhood sushi joint. I live across the street and go frequently when I need my sushi fix. The dishes are decent, but not all that authentic, so if you're looking for a bit more californian sushi, this place is ok. The sashimi is not expertly cut, with big slices of fish (if you're into that - personally, it doesn't work with my taste buds and it's not authentic). The atmosphere here is really nice and I do enjoy sitting here for a casual meal or getting takeout.
author: Naomi L.

description: This place is AWESOME! Super "hole in the wall" feel but WOW the firecracker balls are to die for. Went with my brother and sister in law so we ordered a few different plates and shared and that was by far our favorite. I'm usually not a fan of miso soup but I get a bowl every time I come to Domo! Super delicious- great service, great food. Definitely worth checking this place out!
author: Shamsah H.

description:
The sushi and wait staff here is great. But the size and popularity of this place ruin the dining experience because you end up having to wait for so long, the expectation builds and then you're facing disappointment. The sushi rolls here are "I'll wait up to an 45-60 minutes"  delicious - definitely not worth waiting over 1.5 hours for. 

Normally, it's not a big deal but it's about setting expectations and it's all downhill. 

1. You tell me the wait is 40 minutes. No harm done. 
2. You don't seat me for another one hour and 40 minutes - so now I'm really hungry, possibly hangry. 
3. I sit to order and you tell me that everything I want to order is out so I have to go for your mediocre every-day stuff. SO you starved me and now can't give me what I want. 

Now who's fault is that? doesn't matter - you're average at best and I'm not coming back.
author: Zahir A.

description: Amazing!!!! I've been here three times and each time was so splendid! The service is great, the food is great, the ambiance is great, the drinks are great. Best sushi spot in San Francisco.
author: April R.

description: Came for lunch and i like Domo! It's in the quiet area at hayes valley. Restaurant is small and only bar table is available. They have lunch special at $13 for two items plus salad and miso soup. Sashimi is fresh and decent. I tried their crudos ($7 for 2) with Uni and Ankimo. Uni was fresh and ankimo was just okay. I like here because not too many authentic japanese restaurant in the area. You know what am I talking about if you working in city hall/civic center area =P
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I thought I wrote a review but guess I forgot...went here a while back and it was good, but I didn't recall it being fab but solid (kinda in the vein of Tataki).  But this time around it stuck out...I didn't recall all the little variations of standard fare but it was super fresh and tasty.  The fish tacos...holy magoly.  Hell my friend even made me try the umi (which normally makes me puke), but it had a bit of mango in it and was very clean and tasty.  Rolls were great too...do they put mint or something in there?...there's a herb in the rolls that was different which made it clean on the palate.

Anyway, better than before, and now a place I'll hit more.  That rhymed!  You got a review and a song!
author: A A.

description:
Great date place if you're looking to impress her with some delicious sushi! It's small and the wait can be long even at 9pm, but well worth it. I love small sushi places and always enjoy sitting by the chef counter to see things being prepped and to get to talk with the chef himself. This place probably only seats about 15 people max, btw. 

Would come back here for my nigiri fixings and maybe on a M/Tu/W/Th night.

Street parking in the area is also not bad at all and you're close by to Smitten Ice Cream if you're looking for dessert afterwards!
author: Tiffany H.

description:
More like a 3.5 star.  Walked in on Saturday night, didn't seem too busy, but a table for 2 still required about an hour wait.

Ordered the fish "taco", ahi poke salad, dragon roll and some assorted nigiris.  the fish tacos were something different, but definitely something I could've made, nothing too special.  It consisted of seared slamon, avocado and some Mexican salsa.  Ahi poke salad was not what I imagined either.  It was basically just a few slices of tuna sashimi, along with some seaweed salad, definitely nothing special - wouldn't order it again.

We also ordered the spoons of uni and scallops, both very delicious!  

Nigiris weren't anything special, since they didn't have hamachi belly.  

Overall a solid 3 star with average fish.
author: Nancy S.

description: Domo is the best. My only hesitation is writing this review is it gets even more popular than it already is. They have great service, always get you your food quickly, and it's a great atmosphere. Though the restaurant is small, the benefit of this is it never gets too noisy.
author: Stephanie E.

description: Sushi here was great. The restaurant is tiny and doesn't take reservations so it can be hard to get in. Server was nice, but the sushi chef was not. Fish tacos were delicious, loved the presentation with the tempura seaweed. Fire cracker balls were delicious, as was the spicy hulk roll. The other rolls we had were tasty too. However, for the money spent, we were not satisfied with the portions. Also, a couple of us weren't feeling great the next day - think we got some bad fish.
author: David H.

description:
I just love you Domo.  

I am going to take your Fish Tacos straight to city hall and marry them.
author: Rachelle P.

description:
Let's just call my experience, "Domo-forgoto"

While the sushi tasted alright, each roll/nigiri was brought out ONE by ONE, with at least 5 minute intervals in between. It was impossible to even feel remotely full because my stomach had so much time to settle in between each tiny bite.

Take my advice and stick to Sushi Time or Ryoko's.
author: Kelsea A.

description:
This is a Michelin Guide Recommended restaurant - enough said.

Size: This restaurant is a very small and intimate restaurant.  There is only one table that seats 3 people.  Everyone else sits at the sushi bar.  The restaurant comfortably holds no more than 20 people.  There is outdoor seating available (about 3-4 tables), but with the San Francisco weather no one usually sits outside. So this is not good for large groups unless you were to rent out the entire restaurant. This is ideal for a 2-3 person party maximum.  

The Wait: I have only gone for dinner during the weekdays and there is still always a wait (about 20-30 minutes).  My boyfriend and I try to go right after work so as not to wait too long.

The Food:  You really cannot go wrong with anything you order.  The sushi is fresh and the rolls are amazing. 

Since Domo is in the heart of Hayes Valley there are tons of things to do around there.  If there is a long wait you can go to Two Sisters Bar and Books around the corner, you can simply take a stroll in Hayes Valley.  You can also stop for a drink at Absinthe, the Sugar Lounge, wine tasting at Arelequin and if the beirgarden is open have a beer.  So many great things to do afterwards. 

This is a great date spot and great spot to catch up with a girlfriend.
author: Vagabond V.

description: Talk about a hole in the wall!  This place is teeny -tiny! Probably sits less than 20 people at a time, so you will have to wait, but it is so worth it. The fish is so amazingly fresh, everything we tried was fantastic. We sat at the bar so we were able to talk to chefs who were all very nice & helped us make our selections. The host & server were also great! Excellent service & excellent sushi!
author: Melanie B.

description: Domo is one of the many reasons that makes San Francisco a food lover's paradise. My cousin took me here for a lovely dinner over the weekend and I was definitely impressed. We ordered 2 different sushi rolls - the Domo and the Hulk. I like the Hulk more as I am partial to rolls wrapped with cucumber slices than I am to baked sushi rolls. We also ordered 3 appetizers - Hamachi Carpaccio, Fish Tacos and Ankimo Monk Fish Liver. All were superbly delicious and beautifully plated. I wish I could have imbibed in some sake but I had a long drive home after dinner. I will definitely be back here soon, maybe even this weekend!
author: Chi N.

description:
Very small place - no tables, just bar seating. As in don't come here with a group of more than 2-3. Definitely would have walked past this place if we hadn't yelped sushi places in Hayes Valley. Waited a good 30mins last night, but it was worth it. I found my new favorite Japanese beer (!) - Orion - sweet, delicious, not just another Sapporo. Perfect with hot sake.

Reviews are right, they bring out your order as it's ready, so rolls actually came before our appetizers. Hmm. Seaweed salad was light and refreshing, salmon avocado lemon roll was ridiculously fresh and probably my favorite, firecracker balls were deep fried FYI and not at all a "roll", and hamachi carpacchio was actually cooked (pretty sure this should be raw?) but still tasty. Excellent presentation and lots of ginger, which I appreciate. 

Only negative is the VERY fishy smell of the restaurant. As in my clothes still smell today. Would probably go back if I was in the area and had some time to kill.
author: Natalie H.

description:
I've been coming to Domo since I discovered it was down the street.  It's a small restaurant, so you'll need to get cozy unless you're fortunate enough to be seated outside on a nice warm evening.  It's a good value and has great service.

The lunch specials are a great value.  I sometimes pick up two or three for myself and have lunch, dinner, and then another lunch.  

The nigiri is really nice, and they have a nice selection of fresh fish.  The sashimi is great too.  They frequently have butterfish (walu), which is one of my personal favorites, along with monkfish liver and uni.  All worth getting when available.  Definitely check out the specials too, as the hamachi kama is wonderful.

While I'm not a huge fan of sushi rolls, the rolls here are something special.  I particularly love the temptation roll, the dragon roll, and the Domo roll.  While some of them don't wow me, I have enjoyed all that I have tasted.

There is only one menu item that I've tried that I'm not a fan of, and that's the fish tacos.  It's a fusion confusion dish, and while some of the individual flavors are nice, it doesn't quite come together.

While it can be a wait to eat here, they do to-go orders quickly.  If you live around the corner like me!  An awesome way to have a perfect sushi experience at home.
author: Nathan B.

description: Good sushi with a limited menu. The Domo roll was by far the best that we tried but the spicy hulk looked good with cucumber as well. It would be nice if they had sake cocktails and some heat lamps for the outside seating at night.
author: Jing L.

description: I had a party of 3 at 7:30pm and I had to wait for over an hour and a half for a table even when we saw them seat MULTIPLE parties of 2, who arrived after us, at the bar. Why???? Because they couldn't wait for a spot for 3 to open up at the bar? I understand this is a popular date spot for couples, but I was here with my parents and I just wanted a nice sushi dinner in Hayes. I think waiting that long for a small party is simply ridiculous. They need to figure out a way to fit parties bigger than 2 at this place.
author: Derek L.

description: Our favorite place for sushis in the city! Everything is fantastic, service is great.. Try the kobebeef rolls!!! I can't wait to go back.
author: Laurence F.

description:
I am a fan now - the service was quick and excellent and the food was very good. 
Kobe: Excellent appetizer, very fresh and tastes great
Spicy Hulk: MUST TRY - really different and tastes excellent, specially if you want a roll without rice. 
My Friend tried the Temptation and she said it is a MUST Try as well. 

I will definitely go back... 

Note: place is small and not fit for large groups - they only have one table of 4 and the rest is a bar seating.
author: Ed R.

description:
The sushi here is fresh! I have had a hard time finding a good sushi place in the area, but Domo hits the spot! 

Has outdoor seating for a nice day.
author: Amanda K.

description: This place is definitely one of the best places for sushi in the city that I've been to. I think one of the top tips is to get there early because it is a small place (maybe 20 seats tops). They open at 530 -- I recommend getting there right around then.
author: Mel G.

description: This place gets 5 stars because it's the best sushi I've had in the city! As a sushi lover I'm always up for trying new sushi restaurants in search for my new favorite sushi restaurant. This place has taken that spot! I don't think you can go wrong ordering here so explore the menu and enjoy!
author: Leslie S.

description:
I have only been here once, but I seriously see no reason for giving this place anything less than 5 stars. It was INSANELY delicious. A friend and I shared hamachi, the Domo roll and the Fire Cracker Balls which he had told me would change my life. One bite of that fire cracker ball and I knew I had an addiction. The Domo roll is also now on my list of top favorite rolls ever. You should definitely order those two! 

I had hamachi at this super expensive snobby restaurant in Vegas and honestly, Domo's was just as melt-in-your-mouth-super-fresh delicious but at half the price. The prices at Domo are just right. You are eating super fresh yummy sushi in Hayes Valley, so it's not cheap, but it's not so expensive I consider it a splurge either. It's appropriately priced.

Domo is a small place so I wouldn't recommend bringing your whole posse here and yelling "SAKI BOMB!!!!!!!!!!", while twirling your shirt in the air. Bring a friend or two and enjoy the chill ambiance.
author: Liz M.

description:
I've been to Japan and rarely can you find traditional sushi prepared properly using high quality ingredients. I don't know what it is about this place, but they're doing everything the right way!

The place is small, but so are some of the amazing sushi restaurants in Japan. It adds to the charm of the place. My server was incredibly friendly and knowledgeable and had my food out promptly. I order Toro nigiri and Salmon tataki. Fantastic fish quality and flavor! I was blown away how amazing the quality of fish was. The portions were on par with traditional sushi places.

If you're a connoisseur of sushi, this is your place. Great date night place as well.

I will be back!
author: Kenneth A.

description: This place gets busy quick so it's best to come early! The firecracker balls are amazing and a definite must. It's the perfect little bite if you don't want to order a heavy tempura or baked roll. Any of their special rolls on the board will be good. We also ordered the Castro Roll which was yum! We'll definitely be back.
author: Marcia M.

description:
After hearing raving reviews, last night I finally got to try the good food of Domo.

The line was 7 parties deep, mostly couples ahead our party of (2).

7:30PM - we arrived and wrote our # down on the list. We were told 30-45 mins wait.
She suggested we go across the street to the coffee/bar or enjoy complimentary tea.

8:22PM - we head back to Domo, and was told the wait would be another 30mins, "depending on how fast people eat".

Wow. Truly, that means we would need to wait 90 mins for our table. 

I know you want to keep your clients "waiting" but please be honest. If it's not 30-45mins, please tell us 90 mins. You have enough business rolling in throughout the evening and I must rather would have preferred to be eat at 8pm, rather than my very first bite at..... 


9PM.
author: Lee L.

description: After waiting for some time (no reservations) finally we had a table at the outside area. We accepted the table outside even though it started to get cold cuz we were so hungry by then, so we said yes but asked to be seated inside once a place get freed. After sipping miso soup and sake we were still freezing but no luck with the seating. I think sitting inside could make our experience better, but overall I was impressed with the food. The hamachi belly and butterfish nigiri was excellent, the several rolls we tried were all good. The miss was with the baby octopus. I love octopus so I had to give it a go but it was chewy and didn't taste freshly fried and was topped with too much mayo dressing. Pretty awful, too bad I didn't return it. Also I was a bit disappointed that a vegetarian friend wasn't offered something other then the Veggie roll.. I mean, I was kinda sad for her. Will come back for a decent Sushi in a decent price.
author: Mashav S.

description:
Came here on a whim a little before 7PM on a Friday night and was fortunate to arrive before things got busy.  The place seats about 18-20ish with customers eating on high chairs over counters.  Some face the chef and the sushi bar, others face the wall and/or the window.

The small crudos were a rip-off in my opinion--literally two spoonfuls for $5.95.  We ordered the scallop and ankimo.  For ankimo that size, it would probably have been more worth it to pay the $8 and get it as an appetizer.  Taste-wise, though, both dishes were fine.

Unfortunately, we didn't get a chance to try many of the fusion rolls, which judging from other reviewers seem to be a high point of this place, but we tried the sushi and sashimi.  The sunazuri (hamachi belly), which was a fantastic deal at $5.25 for two pieces, was light and clean.  The sake (salmon) was presented as a rose, which is a trend these days, and was smooth and buttery.  Unlike the sunazuri, though, it was nothing to write home about.  Then we tried the tazmanian trout, which was really something.  It was my first time having it and the taste, while similar to salmon, had a bit more texture.  Those who find salmon too 'slimy' might appreciate trout more.

We finished things off with a rock & roll but it was truly mediocre.  I've had rock & roll from a food court in Irvine l that was better than this.  If you want a really good rock & roll, go to Kirala in Berkeley.

Still, the overall experience was pleasant.  My impression of Domo is that it's very affordable given the quality of food.  There isn't an extremely wide selection of fish or sake like there is at, say, Sushi Bistro, but they do have some stand-outs with the sunazuri and trout, which you may not necessarily get elsewhere.  They also have shiro maguro (albacore) which is also a delicacy that not all sushi bars may necessarily serve.  Plus the sake is a super good deal--nice 'small' bottle for $7!  I wouldn't mind coming back but most likely I wouldn't unless I happen to be in the area.
author: Tiffany H.

description: Awesome!  I love the vibe in here.  We sat with a view of the street - got a lot of what they had.  Poke was good, rainbow roll was good also.  I would prob put this right up there with Elephant from maybe a dozen or so sushi places in SF that I can think of.
author: Charles C.

description: My friends took me here for my birthday over the weekend. The place is tiny! They only have a few bar seats. I must say, the food was pretty good, but not as amazing as I had expected. Maybe my expectations were too high. The spoon shots were unique but I thought they were on the pricey side for something you can pretty easily do at home. The rolls were okay. I liked the chicken karaage but I've also had better chicken karaage. haha overall, it'd give it 3stars for okay, pretty good, but okay.
author: Annie Z.

description:
I've come here two times; the first time I ordered the roll that has mango in it? OH. The something fiesta. It sounds good, but it's really average only. I feel like Domo creates a unique menu that is exotic and it's fun to try them. However it's more western-influenced sushi and not so much the traditionally Japanese sushi...and I love traditional Japanese sushi. It wasn't bad, I am glad I got to try such an exotic combination, however I didn't plan on returning again. Their orders are also a little pricey.

The second time I came, I got a simple tuna roll, that was a couple dollars more than I usually spend. The only reason I dropped by again was because it was sort of in the neighborhood. 

Also the wait was really long, like 20 minutes....even though the place it's really small and there should be no reason to take that long because they're not serving a BUNCH of people. Also it's not as if they spend extra time on my food because it's not excellent tasting when it came out.

If the price was more fair, I'd give it a 3.5/5
author: Natalie Charlotte W.

description:
If you love sushi and is very picky about eating sushi like me, then this is the place you WILL and HAVE TO check it out!!

It is really YUMMY!!!! OMG its KILLER SASHIMI!!

Here is the list of what we (2) ordered our check total $80.00 including tip.

Chef special sashimi
spider roll
toro onigiri
tuna poki salad (a bit salty)
fish taco (must order)
Ama Ebi (sweet shrimp)
Red Snapper (onigiri)

Its a nice small place sitting at the bar or outside. Must try if you love sushi
author: Lovetea C.

description: Try several sushi options, including the kobe beef entry, although the crab fried balls are delicious. You will never forget this place.
author: Jesus N.

description:
No Uni, no Ankimo, no special jelly fish, no special Madagascar Amaebi that is on their specials board.  FAIL!!  Started to Yelp this on my i-phone and saved as a two star review just for this.  So why did I give them a 4-star??...

Came here with no reservations (as you can't make none at this small 10-14 seater place)....waited an hour for table for two.  NONE of what I had mentioned above so had to order others....walu, hamachi, toro, albacore, saba, spicy hulk roll, wagyu beef roll, sexy mama roll, and fish tacos...ALL was just a orgasmn to my taste buds~!  However, due to the fact that they didn't have some of the most simple (yet important items) of a sushi spot...I was still going to give them at most a 3-star.  But then....the waiter came to us and apologized about all the items they couldn't serve to us due to them being closed for ten days for the holidays and this was their first day of re-opening.  I then sharply responded "OK...now I forgive you guys"
author: Patrick C.

description: Got their omakase and it was the best sushi I've had in the city
author: Matt K.

description:
I've been to Domo twice thus far and both experiences have been an exercise in freshness,  originality and transparency.  As you walk into this quaint little abode you are greeted by a darkened atmosphere, throw back jam'in rap music and a focused set of sushi makers.  If you happen to sit at the sushi bar (as i did with my astute girlfriend) the sushi master chef proudly engages you and hands over his fish creations to you personally.   We chose two sushi roll options and a seaweed salad.  Our "Alpha" role consisted of fresh spicy tuna wrapped in tender seaweed and soft rice drizzled in a warm asian style sauce.   We topped off our dinner experience with homemade tasting sesame ice cream.  Quite delectable!

If I had any negatives one would be the "hour plus" long waits on the weekends.

Whenever i'm in the Civic Center / Hayes Valley area and craving sushi I'll be back.
author: Robert N.

description:
Went to Domo with a long lost SF friend - reuniting never tasted so good. We had a variety of rolls along with some good sake. The service was great (even when we stayed twice as long as we should've with a long line out the door) - and they made excellent recommendations based on specials and regular menu items. 

Would definitely recommend for a great SF sushi experience in a lovely neighborhood.
author: Megan S.

description: The sushi was fresh and delicious.  The fire cracker balls were on fire and if that wasn't enough,  the setting was pretty romantic.
author: Rick O.

description:
Excelente!
Orion draft beer is very refreshing plus their service is personal and very friendly. Now, the sushi is very very very good. We had the Domo roll which is baked and delicious.
author: Sergio R.

description:
Just finished up lunch at Domo... And can't say I didn't leave with a happy stomach and smile on my face. 
Food:
Crudo- salmon and scallops... The salmon was amazing!!! So deliciously paired with the avocado

Spicy tuna roll- pretty good and not that spicy 

Sweet potato roll- amazing!!! Like French fries but way better!!!!

Hamachi roll- usually love hamachi but this was just okay 

Overall good experience.. Pretty busy for lunch and there was only one server, so service was a little slow but not too bad
author: Tamara D.

description: Domo is WONDERFUL! Sometimes there's a wait, but it's worth it. Cool little space with a couple tables outside. They always have super fresh fish, make sure you ask for/look at the specials. Their butter fish & fire cracker balls are my favorite, but pretty much everything is very tasty!
author: S V.

description: This little place has great nigiri. The fish is always so fresh. Great service and nice atmosphere. It is very small and fills up fast, so get here early.
author: Ashley J.

description:
Love the fireball sushi on the menu!

Solid sushi joint -- casual and cozy.
author: Shivani S.

description:
My lovely wife and I are committed to finding great sushi, at least one establishment in our beloved city that prepares and plates great sushi with only the best ingredients available that day at market.

I would not write that Domo has for us claimed that mantle but we were pleasantly surprised and thankful to the Japanese owner of Cotton Sheep just around the corner who recommended Domo.

We ordered maguro, shake, ikura, taco and hamachi prepared nigirizushi style.  We also enjoyed negitoro and tekkyu makizushi.  On balance the ingredients were good although hamachi displayed unwanted red.

Domo does score big points for serving what I would refer to as a 'traditional' sushi offering that you would find in local sushi bars that serve that nation's families in thousands of tiny neighborhoods across Japan.

We will return with a view to more thoroughly probing Domo's ingredients, preparation, plating and balance of menu.
author: Jay D.

description:
I discovered this place by accident months ago. I looked it up on Yelp and pinned it in my mind to return. Since then, I've gone back a few times, and it's always a quality visit. 

As usual, I start with miso soup. As always, it's delicious. I usually like to split appetizers but Domo's Crudos are too good to do so. I'd tried a few of the special rolls, but most of them contain tempura-ed something or other so I like to stick with sashimi or regular rolls. The fish is always fresh and cut well and the servers are casual and kind. 

The wait can be long, as the place only seats maybe 15 inside but it's worth trying for.
author: Schmoodly L.

description: The poke and the domo roll are very delicious. The hulk is also good. The miso soup is a bit salty though. It's a very nice, intimate spot. They have seats outside too. Everybody is very friendly and welcoming.
author: Stacy C.

description: Maybe this place is good but I wouldn't be able to tell you since they said they were closed when I walked in...it was 9:45 and the door clearly said they closed at 10! I understand it was close to closing time but a restaurant shouldn't stop guests willing to spend money from coming in especially when it  was still packed inside...just wanted drinks and a snack.
author: Krystal G.

description:
Cute little sushi spot right in Hayes Valley.  

Good sushi rolls.  Didn't have the sushi so can't comment on that.

We ordered the firecracker balls, the salmon avocado lemon roll, the domo roll, and the kobe beef roll.  Not entirely impressed with everything except the kobe beef roll.  It literally melts in your mouth.  The other stuff was good, but they kind of drench their rolls in too much sauce.

The service was very prompt.  I will visit again - but next time I'll order other stuff.
author: Grace C.

description:
I skipped lunch so we could have an early dinner at Domo. We were the first two in the restaurant, luckily because there are few seats and the place filled up 15 minutes after opening.

The crudos and fried baby octopus were my favorite items on the menu. We ordered a bunch of nigiri and the one that stood out was the shredded crab. I usually order raw fish and the crab was an interesting change. Our waiter was very sweet and attentive.

Cons: Rice was mushy. The bottle of sake we ordered was not chilled so we had to go with a different bottle. Initially the vibe was very cold and I didn't feel welcome. The only person that greeted us was the waiter. We sat at the sushi bar and the two people behind the counter barely cracked a smile. I felt quite uncomfortable through dinner.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
Domo is a sushi bar to return to.  Forget that it has 15 seats and doesn't take reservations--it's charming with specials handwritten on a mirror and cozy with views of either tree-lined Laguna Street or the sushi chefs hard at work.  The menu is big enough for classics and creativity, yet small enough to not be visually overwhelming. 

My boyfriend let me take the reigns with ordering and, of course, I went crazy.  We began with uni (sea urchin) and ankimo (monkfish liver) crudo (two for $6).  They were beautifully presented on soup spoons, and I couldn't help but compare them to the Spoonfuls of Happiness at Koo (http://www.yelp.com/biz/koo-san-francisco).  Although the crudo here was delicate in flavor and rich in texture, the Spoonfuls of Happiness there were a foodgasm in my mouth.  We also had the dynamite mussels (two for $6)--these were hot, juicy, and flavorful, though I'm still more crazy about the baked mussels at Sushi Zone (http://www.yelp.com/biz/sushi-zone-san-francisco).  

A sushi bar is only as good as its cuts of sashimi, so we had to have some of my favorites: hamachi (yellowtail) and sake (salmon) (5 pieces each for $10).  The hamachi was incredible--so fresh and so thick.  The sake would've been as enjoyable if it weren't so thin.  Where Domo shines, however, is the rolls.  We had the fire cracker balls ($10), the spider roll ($9), and the spicy hulk ($10).  The fire cracker balls were a flavor explosion (no pun intended)--crunchy and saucy with kick.  It was my pick of the three.  The spider was as good as any great one that I've had.  The parties on either side of us ordered the spicy hulk, so we did as well; the spicy tuna in it was delicious, but the ponzu sauce overpowered it sometimes. 

Although I've had better versions of the same things elsewhere, my collective experience at Domo was still nothing short of five stars.  Even with seven items, beer, and sake, the total bill was only $83 before tax and tip.  Yes, it isn't cheap but it's reasonable--the bites were well worth the dollars.

This was the perfect cap to our Sunday afternoon walk through Hayes Valley.  First, wine in the garden of Arlequin Cafe; next, macaroons at Chantal Guillon; then, we scored the last two open seats at Domo without having to wait.  Sometimes the best dates are the unplanned ones.
author: Liz T.

description: I've had quite amount of sushi and must say this place was refreshingly awesome. Loved their unique sushi dishes like Sushi Fish Tacos which I highly recomend.
author: Andy F.

description: By far one of the best sushi restaurants I've experienced. The venue is very small, so the wait can be awhile, even if there are just two parties ahead of you on the wait list, but I think it is worth the wait. Comfortable, warm, and inviting environment. Not good for big parties... this is more of a date kind of place as you are packed in pretty tight and the smaller your party, the higher the likelihood they can accommodate your crowd. Very nice staff and they are open to you making adjustments / substitutions to your roll. Prices are reasonable for the quality and hey, it's sushi, so you can expect to pay anywhere from $10 - $14 a roll. I got the Domo and Fire Cracker Ball rolls. They were really good. I definitely will be going back to this venue and I highly recommend to my friends.
author: Keenya D.

description: Sushi was actually pretty good. Service ok. But one star FOR MAKING ME POUR MY OWN WATER WITH A GIANT HEAVY BOTTLE. Im not a waitress anymore amen so I dont want to pour my own water when I am spending good money in a restaurant. This is a horrible hipster trend. Every restaurant that does this gets one star from me unless they make up for it in some amazing way (Im looking at you Hog Island)
author: Lauren V.

description: Great food and atmosphere. Service was snappy. My husband and I went there for lunch and we ordered the set lunches which were the perfect size (american food are usually very large portions) and very tasty. Mine was 2 tempura shrimp and 4 unagi(eel) with rice and ebi on the side. My husband ordered the sashimi with rice that had 8 slices of sashimi which were all different. This included salad and miso soup, all for $13 per set lunch. Loved the miso soup and green tea. Had the green tea mochi for dessert too which was very delicious. 10/10 will eat again! :)
author: Natasha W.

description: Great location right off of the main drag in Hayes Valley. It was a long wait to sit inside so we snagged a seat on the patio. We had the miso soup and two rolls. Our first roll was the Fiesta which has albacore tuna, mango & cilantro then is topped with black pepper salsa. This roll was a lot of fun. It was married Mexican food flavor with yummy sushi. Dipping it in a tiny bit of soy sauce gave it the saltiness of tortilla chips. Our second roll was the Spicy Hulk which had spicy tuna & avocado, tobiko and was wrapped in a cucumber sheet with ponzu. Both rolls were good. It still can't compete with my favorite spot down in Foster City, but I'd be open to coming back.
author: Kari G.

description:
Domo is my neighborhood (Hayes Valley) go to sushi spot.

The restaurant is indeed small, and only really recommended for dinner for 2, but if you like fresh sushi in an intimate setting this is a great spot to try.

I personally like the Chef's choice sashimi, along with the many different specialty rolls -  all of which will satisfy your tastebuds.

One of my favorite parts of Domo are the daily specials - usually 2-3 rolls and a few larger dishes are created daily to keep the repeat customers guessing and anticipating the next move.

You like sushi? GO HERE
author: Justin O.

description:
One of my favorite sushi places in the city.  It is a super cute tiny restaurant that is a great date place.  The sushi is phenomenal!  

Definitely try the firecracker rolls.  Mmmmmm.....
author: Laleh J.

description: The sushi is pretty good.  We ordered a ton of different rolls and pieces of nigiri so we had a good sampling.  Everything tastes fresh and but I wouldn't say it was exceptionally delicious.  The seating is difficult because the place is so tiny.  Good for a date night but not good for groups larger than 2 (I think there is only one 4-top table).  I'd eat here again if I was in the neighborhood.
author: Jessica K.

description:
Domo is delicious.  Fresh fish, great service, creative menu.  The I.C. and Fiesta rolls are my favorite (Fiesta roll, literally a party in your mouth).  I love the hint of citrus in all of their rolls creating complex delicious flavors. 

 I would have given them 5 stars but for the fact that the menu is slightly overpriced.  But then again, you get what you pay for and the sashimi pretty much melts in your mouth. Nom nom nom.
author: maggie w.

description:
For me, this is a Sunday/Monday night spot (not so crowded or loud).  I usually order a bunch of sashimi and one cooked item.

The uni with quail egg was suprisingly fresh  =D

The last time I came, I think I had way to much sake.....

Easy parking!!!
author: Angelica C.

description:
I think I did something right when I came here.

The same night, I went to a bar and when I mentioned I went here to someone, she exclaimed "yeeeeesssssss!" and gave me a high five. So what I'm saying is, I'm measuring my success in high fives from locals.

Aside from that though, Domo just did everything right. I always grin on the inside when there's music I like in a restaurant, and I entered to A Tribe Called Quest. The mix only continued with more jazz-based hip-hop, then moved into some lighter folksy stuff as my time there progressed. If you're paying attention, I'm sold on the place and I haven't even ordered yet.

I ended up getting the firecracker balls, and the real crab california rolls. That bit is important: real crab. Not enough places do this (read: almost none) and what you usually get is this semi-solid white and red piece wrapped in rice. That wasn't the case here, but I'll get to that later. Firecracker balls! Great stuff. I was really pleased with the flavor and texture. I should have ordered two, honestly.

I had a bite of my friend's unagi which was also delicious, but then came these califonia rolls. Actual crab meat made such a difference in the flavor. I'm used to california rolls that taste like rice and cucumber, and whatever amount of soy sauce I mask it with. This had a prominent crab flavor and it was fresh. 

Not only that, but staff was attentive throughout the dining experience. No hovering, no abandonment, just careful observation. 

The only thing I can't say is how lucky you'll be to get a seat. I was on vacation so I had the luxury of visiting in the afternoon. You may not be so lucky on a Friday night, for example. That's because it's a really small place. It's not cramped, but it's definitely suited for small parties.

All that said, Domo gets 5 stars. And a high five.
author: DeShaun C.

description:
Not worth the wait? We have sushi 2-3 times a week, so we consider ourselves pretty knowledgable sushi eaters. If you have 2 hours to waste waiting outside...cool. Not! We did not have sushi and will not try in the future. There are other great places on Hayes that have high quality sushi and interiors.

.5 Stars
author: Pstephan A.

description: Domo is on the slightly more expensive side of sushi restaurants in the city - however I can't deny the sushi was delicious! We tried a few items off the specials, and were pleasantly surprised. The servings were on the smaller side, but that's okay when it tastes so good!
author: Amy M.

description:
Cute little neighborhood gem.

I wouldn't consider this a traditional Japanese restaurant. They have a bunch of fancy rolls, with plenty of tempura and special sauces. I will definitely say that all the rolls were delicious though (aside from the spider roll, which was pretty plain). Other than that, they were delicious. The hamachi nigiri was alright as well. 

Service was great and attentive. The waitress gave my friend a friendly tip on how to use chopsticks (first-timer). The crowd grew to a short wait as time went by on a Monday night even. 

Great find. Not so traditional. Worth coming back.
author: Elaine H.

description:
D   evoured a delicious uni crudo and a couple 
O   f mind blowing sushi rolls, all
M   asterfully selected, and 
O   vertly enjoyed
author: Jane K.

description:
Would have loved to give this place ZERO stars.

The worst sushi experience or dining experience of my life (we've lived in San Francisco for 20 years and go out at least twice a week).  As for any Hayes Valley residents, there are never a shortage of amazing places to dine just a reach away. Not to mention we are so close to the Mission.  But this place is just around the corner and we've unintentionally been ignoring it for a long time. Finally decided to give it a try and what a huge mistake! 

Called them on our way in Sunday night, the hostess said the wait is around 15 minutes. We walked over and were there five minutes later. Turns out there are about 4 other couples ahead of us as well as a party of 5 (the place is tiny). 

We put our name down. 
We wait for about 45 minutes - the place has such poor ventilation that we both begin to get slightly barfy from the fumes of re-fried oil evaporating from their tiny kitchen. 

Finally we're being seated. Nobody takes our order for at least 15 minutes. The waiter doesn't even bother to give us a friendly smile or apologize for making us wait so long. 

30 minutes after we place our order, still no sign of food and not a single member of the er.. 2-member staff bothers to check on us. 

So to sum it up:  arrived at 6:45PM, seated at 7:30PM, food arrives (but only after I lost my cool and yelled at the waitress) at 8:30PM - RIDICULOUS.  

The rolls and nigiri are just ok, nothing to write home about in the city filled with amazing sushi places.  We left very disappointed and upset. The silver lining was the waitress telling us as we were leaving that she likes some sushi place in the Castro where the wait is usually close to 2 hours but the food is so amazing it's worth it. Well. I couldn't care less where this waitress likes to eat her sushi and at Domo the mediocre food is most certainly not worth the long wait, the rude staff, horrible service and the nasty smell inside the restaurant.  I left disappointed, angry and smelling as if i spent a night working the fryer in Domo's kitchen.
author: alessandra d.

description:
Domo is now officially one of my top favorite sushi joints in the city!  No matter how busy they are (and they are always busy!), the staff never fails on customer service.  

Oh Domo, you make my heart smile!
author: Carmen Y.

description:
So when you go here know that this is not like Katsuya at all.  The menu is very limited in comparison.  This is basically a great place for typical sashimi, rolls and such with one exception unique creation (firecracker balls).  I usually do take out as it is too small to eat in comfortably.

It has nothing like the Katsuya menu with Seared Spicy Albacore w/Crispy Onion, Manilla Clams in Ponsu sause, Crispy Rice w/Spicy Tuna, Crispy Sesame Tuna, Miso Marinated Cod, etc. etc.

A good place but I have yet to find anything comparable in SF.  Seems like a great business opportunity exists for someone that can do the same.
author: Christian P.

description:
Small space but really interesting twists on sushi. My friend and I were eager to try most their Kobe Beef roll, which features a kobe beef outer wrap with avocado and, ginger, and asparagus in the center. The ponzu helped cut the oil, and the kobe beef just sort of disappears as you bite into it.

We paired this with the Spicy Hulk, which had the refreshing cucumber sheet with lemon ponzu and spicy tuna center. It's nice to break away from traditional rice-based sushi to enjoy a set of different textures and tastes all at once. 

We also had the domo roll, which is the restaurant's signature, but all in all, a mediocre warm cheese sushi. I think it was good partially because of the other rolls we had next to it.

Lastly, in order to have a bit of a traditional flavor, we went with the hamachi sashimi, which honestly was one of the best I had tried in a long time. Really fresh fish that could stand alone without the shoyu and the wasabi. It was to appreciate the natural sweetness of the fish alongside the more complex flavors of the other rolls. 

I liked the atmosphere of the restaurant and its location. It's a tad pricey, but overall the food quality was great.
author: Travis L.

description: This place exemplifies the mediocrity and complacency of sushi restaurants in sf and the U.S.  as a whole.  Never have I been to a Japanese restaurant where there are no Japanese people making the sushi.  The crab was ripe and had obviously not been properly refrigerated.  The sushi fell apart as soon as it was lifted.  The miso soup was cold and the vibe was incredibly pretentious.  Don't waste your money or time on fake sushi.
author: Zach H.

description: I tried it again.  The lunch special is solid, but you get to watch them break down the fish for dinner.  This was not very appetizing. I am still not super impressed.
author: Kiki I.

description:
Ordered :
California Roll - 4/5. Good but just 6 pcs for 7$

Will Order Again - 3/5 . Maybe

Food is ok, nothing special, but pricey for what it is worth.
author: Rachit A.

description: Dont really remember what i had but all pretty good. Decent sushi place and decent price.
author: Madelyn W.

description:
My absolute favorite go to sushi dinner spot in SF is Domo every time!  Esp, being that I live a few blocks away in Hayes Valley :) 

Always make sure to order the fish taco appetizer, the specials are fantastic, the saki is great!  Great sushi chefs, neighborhood feeling all together, a small space so good for groups 2-4 max.  

I hope this place stays in Hayes Valley forever otherwise I would be very disappointed! Thanks Domo :)
author: Alison A.

description:
this is a cute and cozy restaurant. i would recommend coming with a small group of people.or with s date. i had the fireball and domo roll. it was good but it tasted the same. I'm going to try the hulk next time. also the spoonfuls of treats was a must have. the creamy sake was interesting.

overall, I'll come back again
author: Dor C.

description:
We were so disappointed.

I told them I was lactose intolerant so I asked for the mayo sauce to be either left out or on the side...but they just made it as usual with only an "oh, sorry". So I traded meals with my husband. Then when we got our bill, they overcharged us for the two starters and I had to point out what the price was on the menu. The whole meal (2 starters and 2 rolls) came to over $50. Way too much, even for sushi. 

I'll never go back.
author: Lia K.

description: This place was very good.  Their sushi creations were great.  The rolls were good too.  Small and no reservations but we cane on a Monday night. Would def recommend.
author: Dan V.

description:
Some of the these negative reviews are retarded. 
Look, this place is small. It's good for four MAX. Great neighborhood sushi spot. Fish is fresh, prices are reasonable for the city and they have some interesting options. The Kobe Beef is pretty, pretty good. We live up the street and come here a lot. Never had to wait more than 30 minutes. If it's packed inside and not to cold, sitting outside is the way to go. Good people watching. I must also say that Raul that waiter is the best. Always in a good mood and has a great sense of humor. 
Plus, they sometimes have to get stuff from the attic space. In order they get to it, they have to boulder up via rock climbing holds. Don't see that everyday.
author: J B.

description: I went to eat here with my lady friend tonight. There was roughly 40 min before closing and we were turned away because there was 5 people before us. The manager or at least who I assumed was the manager was not even polite about it. Smh. Domo, the 49ers just won and it was the last game at Candlestick!!!! Of course people are going to be out trying to eat after a spectacular game. Domo is horrible.
author: Zachariah Y.

description: Probably one of the best sushi places in the city. Long wait but so worth it. Will definitely come back here and get more and more sushi.
author: Claudine V.

description:
Following a recommendation of a local bartender my friend and I wandered in... and boy, was it worth it. the sushi was creative, delicious and will keep us coming back for more. wish I lived closer so I can't get more of the spicy hulk and the scallop crudo.

great ambiance, really fantastic service and delicious food. domo i'll be back soon.
author: diana m.

description: My favorite sushi spot in SF! I love Hayes Valley and Domo only makes me love it more. The fish is always super fresh and the menu is fun and inventive. There are also really good special rolls every day. It's small and almost always crowded, but you can put your name on the list, walk across the street for a glass of wine, and they will call when you're table is ready. The firecracker balls are amazing!
author: Lauren H.

description:
I have been to Domo twice already. My first time was last year, that was June 2013. I was visiting my friend. It was my first time in San Francisco and going out for sushi was something that he said we must do. We were trying to go to a different sushi place but since it was a Sunday that place was closed. We tried Domo instead.
