I enjoyed it. It is a really small place but we had no trouble getting sat by the bar seating in front of the kitchen. It is not that loud so you can actually carry on a conversation pretty easily. We watched the food being prepared while we waited for our order. At one point we had a few questions about a couple of items so the staff told us more about the items. It wasn't too pricey, but it wasn't cheap either. 

My second time was on Memorial Day of 2014. After spending a few days in Humboldt, and then the ride back to SF, I had the afternoon free before my flight back to Chicago the next morning. I remembered how nice this place was the year before so instead of trying out a new place I just wanted to come back to Domo. I ordered a few things I had last time and an additional new item I have not tried. I came in by myself and sat in the same bar overlooking the kitchen. I thoroughly enjoyed my meal. Being there the second time a year later felt like the year before. Service was on point and everything was consistent.

I do not like flashy restaurants, and some sushi places can be. I enjoyed the relaxed atmosphere. My dinner here felt unrushed and enjoyable. I recommend this place if you are looking for fresh and outstanding sushi but also want to enjoy your dinner with a friend or you're just visiting from out of town.
author: Luke D.

description:
Domo is hands-down my favorite hayes valley sushi place. Yes, it is small but I like it that way. It has a nice atmosphere and the staff is always friendly and spot on. The specials never have let me down. They also let you do take out which is nice for those days you wanna grab a roll and eat at home. 

The rolls are pricey but the quality is well worth it. Some of my favorite dishes include the Hawaiian Style Tuna Poké, Spicy Tuna, Spicy Hulk and Fiesta. Make sure to check out the specials board because I've had several delicious rolls from there as well.
author: Joanna V.

description:
First, I love that they let you leave a phone number on the wait list. This is a small courtesy that has a big impact, and it definitely influences my mood when my table is ready (as in, did I stand around making half-hearted chitchat for x minutes, or did I get to take a stroll and pop into a bar for a quick drink). Great start.

Second, the space is very cozy. Some would say small, which is true, but when it is small in a way that feels good, I go with cozy. The great part of a small joint is that the noise level is low, the service is very attentive, and it makes the whole experience feel very intimate (date night!). We sat at the bar facing the street, which I think is the superior spot since you get to people watch yet still have the warmth and comfort of sitting inside.

Third, the food is delicious. We went to Domo because I was having a major tuna and avocado craving, so most of our rolls had those elements. Usually we try to get at least one new thing, and a mix of rolls and nigiri, but this time we focused in on tuna or avocado flavors and stuck with rolls. Our favorites of the night were the fiesta roll and the crunchy California roll. As for amount, we ordered 5 sets of rolls for two small/medium adult appetites, which was about 1 set too much. We also each had a beer.

Overall, the whole experience at Domo was wonderful. We were treated well and enjoyed a delicious dinner, and we will surely be back.
author: Laura M.

description: I ordered the shrimp tempura with eel and salmon sashimi and miso soup. Soup was average. They brought out my entree first before the sashimi. Sashimi should've arrived first since it's the quicker of the 2 dishes to prepare. Salmon sashimi was fine. Came with 5 pieces for $11. Shrimp tempura was not good. I ate it because I was hungry and I don't like to waste food. But it wasn't until I reached the very last roll before I tasted bones and scales from the eel. I spat most of it out but ended up swallowing some. I've never seen scales or bones in a sushi roll before. Needless to say I will not be returning to patronize this place.
author: Max F.

description:
SF has good sushi, so Domo has a lot of competition. Domo's sushi? Excellent, excellent! The wait? Terribly long - 45 minutes. I got some water while waiting, and if you don't mind the cold, you can sit outside. There is the regular menu, and there are also tons of specials. The pace of eating at this restaurant is unhurried in typical California style. 

The small crudos I think are one of the highlights here. We had the ankimo as well as the spicy tuna, both excellent, and down in one or two bites (though we shared)

We sat right at the counter and watched the chef personally craft each role. He was very nice and also told us quickly what wasn't available.

My favorite roll was actually a simple one - the salmon avocado and lemon. I liked the sweet tanginess the lemon lended to the roll. We also had the fire cracker balls and temptation roll, both of which were good, but I don't think the fire cracker balls lived up to all the hype I saw in all the other reviews. Next time I think I'll try coming around 5:30PM or 8PM
author: Shang S.

description:
Domo is currently my favorite sushi place in San Francisco. I like the fancy, over the top, unauthentic rolls with more ingredients than you can count, and this restaurant's namesake roll, the Domo Roll, fit the bill perfectly. It's got everything you might want in your sushi roll all mixed together: salmon, crab, scallops, avocado, spicy mayo, bbq unagi glaze, tobiko & scallions. It's visually appealing and extremely tasty. Oddly, the salmon on top is baked, not raw or smoked, which I was surprised to learn works well.

I also tried one of the specials. I don't remember all the details, but it had a crunchy nutty exterior (crushed almonds perhaps?) and scallops inside. It was nearly as wonderful as the Domo roll. My boyfriend prefers the simple classics; he ordered a california roll and a tuna roll and he liked them both as well.

I'm usually left wanting more after dining on sushi, but I was pretty stuffed after leaving Domo; both of my rolls were very filling. I'll be back.
author: Adam B.

description: Nom nom nom nom nom - Domo makes me happier than a camel on Wednesday! The tiny restaurant is in a great location in Hayes Valley and the food is super tasty. They've almost always got an off-menu special written on the board, but the regular fare is enough to get me in the door. The firecracker balls are very tasty but definitely very fried - I like to pair them with a lighter roll like the Rainbow Roll. Very fresh tasting, and the service is always friendly.
author: Rachel Y.

description:
Ugh, I love this place so damn much. Their sushi is so fresh and their lighting is so baller. When a friend is visiting from out of town and wants impressive fresh sushi -- I confidently reply, "Oh, I know a place."

Thanks Domo for keeping me in the know.
author: May W.

description: Good food.    Fresh , delicious, and friendly staff.     Thank you Yelp for pointing it out !
author: chris b.

description:
To be quite honest, I wanted to come here because of the name. I had forgotten this place was even here, and how I forgot, I'm not quite sure. I love this place! My favorite seats are by the window, overlooking the street so you can people watch whilst enjoying your meal. The sushi/sashimi/maki menu seems a little limited as sushi restaurants go, but they have all the essentials. They also have a large non-sushi menu, for those of you who haven't given in to fully appreciating amazing cuisine that is sushi. They have rotating sushi + non-sushi specials, too. The one thing I can't go without on their menu, though, is the small crudos. Try them, they're amazing.

The waiter let us sit on Saturday around 9PM-ish, right as they seem to be closing the kitchen and sushi bar for the night (DISCLAIMER: Yelp says they're open until 10PM, but seems like they close much earlier on slow nights.) We knew exactly what we wanted, so it was all good! Thank you waiter sir, for not letting my sushi craving linger.

The one thing that score major points for me (outside of their name, good food and good service, obv): Domo is open more days of the week and later than *other* great sushi restaurants in the area. This fact alone makes me think Domo might turn into my go-to sushi place.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Recommended Dishes: This is one of the best sushi joints in San Francisco. Everything I've had here is fresh and delicious. Standouts include the Alpha roll (special roll - not always available) and the Salmon belly nigiri.

Atmosphere: Cozy and clean. They merge the best elements of a traditional sushi spot and a modern restaurant. Not good for groups over 4 people. Great date spot if you don't mind the wait.

Cost: Average for a good sushi restaurant.

Wait-Time: Usually about an hour for dinner. No reservations accepted. Put your name on the list, leave a phone number, and go have a beer in the cafe across the street; they'll call when your table is ready!
author: Katie R.

description:
Domo is quite a charming little sushi joint that offers a cozy yet intimate atmosphere. It's a relatively small and modern restaurant, able to fit a maximum of 20 or so people. I was helping my friend move last weekend and for his last dinner before he moved we decided to hit up Domo. I really didn't know what to expect, but it wasn't like I was going to say no to soooshi! :)
 
Between the two of us, we ordered:
- Three bottles of Sake (http://static1.px.yelp.com/bphoto/VENheXH8mYtgwPrFtMU_Ow/l)
- Hamachi and Toro Sashimi (http://static4.px.yelp.com/bphoto/GT2ksGp2QBhJO19j-w3G-g/l)
- Domo Roll (http://static1.px.yelp.com/bphoto/XByYhTTvoVewW3nd25g0MA/l)
- Crunchy California Roll (http://static3.px.yelp.com/bphoto/MzHL9-eDlchb7xxBK5oWvA/l)
- Omega Roll (http://static2.px.yelp.com/bphoto/OgLyxt4lFEaGnlsIgFvTfg/l)
 
Hamachi Sashimi (3.5 Stars): Fresh Yellowtail, one of my favorites to order.  Not the best I've had, but still quite good and tasty.
 
Toro Sashimi (5 Stars): My other favorite, the Fatty Tuna that was extremely stimulating and scrumptious.  When I devoured the first piece I instantly fell in love.  It seriously just melted in my mouth.  One of the best sashimis I've had in quite a while. I highly recommend this for any sashimi lovers out there!
 
Crunchy California Roll (5 Stars): Tempura Battered California Roll with spicy mayo, unagi sauce, scallions, & tobiko.  Out of the three rolls we had, this was my favorite.  Again, I am a sucker for fried rolls, so I am a bit biased.  The crunchy tempura layer is what does it for me, so exceptional!

Domo Roll (4.5 Stars): Baked California Roll topped with salmon & scallops with spicy mayo, unagi sauce, and tobiko & scallions. This roll was a close second in terms of what I liked between the three rolls we ordered. Full of flavor and packs quite a tasty punch!
 
Omega Roll (4 Stars): This was on their special menu written on the mirror.  Our waitress informed us the specials rolls and what they contained, and I didn't catch everything she said.  I do remember it having shrimp, mango, and macadamia nuts.  This roll was quite refreshing and luscious.
 
Sake - Cream de Sake (5 Stars): This is my first experience of having unfiltered sake and my only question is, why have I never had this before? OMG, it was so good! It looks real creamy and milky like, and tasted so smooth and sweet.  I think I will start ordering unfiltered sake from now on! :)

Summary (5 Stars): A true hidden gem! They have Toro Sashimi to die for, as well as highly addictive and delicious rolls. It all goes so well with their Cream de Sake! I also enjoyed the soft mellow hip hop beats in the background, so faint that my friend didn't even notice.
author: Mike S.

description:
I'm an L.A. resident, and I was visiting a friend in The City. We did wait a while for two open places at the Sushi Bar, and were starving when we sat down. The Sushi chef was intelligent, knowledgeable and full of good suggestions.
 
I seem to recall kickass Toro, which is one sign to me of a good Sushi place. They also offer Spanish style Crudo in little spoons; elegant and cool.

Domo roll? Yes. Fire Cracker balls? yes.
author: Darya T.

description: Everything was very tasty & very fresh! The intimate ambiance and service are wonderful too.
author: Niki B.

description:
Very small, cute and quaint. I like that they have creative rolls, I really appreciate trying something new. Get the spicy hulk, red dragon! Sake was bomb!

Minus one star for uncomfortable seating. I hate high, tiny chairs. And every seat except for one table is bar seating, which makes conversation with your date or friend hard. Dropped $100 for just 2 people including tip and alcohol which was shocking at first but now that I type this doesn't seem so bad.
author: Stephanie W.

description: Favorite sushi place in the city, better than nobu. My favorite appetizers are the crispy rice, tuna tarts, and the crispy shrimp. Everything always comes out amazing and the service is great. Best desert is the green tea crepe! I recommend this place to people all the time! The food is definitely worth the price. Service need little more attention.
author: Chen A.

description:
Overrated, just "good", not great.  The biggest problem I have with Domo is that things are not quite as they describe on the menu.  Perhaps I'm a bit picky, but if a place is going to offer specialty rolls and go to the bother of listing all the ingredients in those rolls, I expect the finished result to match up.  The changes they make on the fly are not trivial... for example, crab which was not in the description, or substituting tuna/salmon interchangeably.  That radically changes a roll, to me.  (I'm not *just* picky - I have really bad food allergies - so essentially they've made my meals inedible).  

If friends insist on going, I'll tag along and stick to sashimi or nigiri, hard to screw up. But I always leave feeling a little disappointed by the quality and selection available for my meal.
author: Heidi M.

description: Best sushi in the neighborhood! Everything's very fresh and well prepared. You can honestly taste the freshness. Crunchy California roll is amazing, as well as the nigiri (yellow fin, and butter fish are my favorite). Great lunch prices. Only bad thing is the size of the seating. Only one table for 4 inside so dress warm to eat outside.
author: Kalani M.

description: Just a point of information: omakase here means the chef picks dishes from the normal menu and just keeps sending them until you say stop. The bill can run up quickly this way.
author: Stan W.

description: Don't go. Terrible customer service. Food isn't worth it
author: Scott V.

description:
So, this was my second stop in San Francisco and my first time trying what I'd now call mildly adventurous sushi. 

Up until tonight, I was completely excited by inside out avocado rolls. But, I decided to try something new and ordered the Spicy Hulk roll ($9.50) and on my friends recommendation, the Crunchy Spicy Tuna roll ($11). We were told the wait was 20 mins so we went to grab a drink but when we came back they had already called our names so we told the guy and he signed us up for the next spot. We were seated another 20 mins later and skimmed through the menu before deciding on the above plus the Sweet Potato roll ($4) and the Salmon Avocado roll ($6.50 I think). The crunchy roll was just about the best thing I've ever tasted. It had cooked tuna which resembled meat loaf, avocado, tobiko and spicy mayo and then the whole thing was battered and fried. I don't really enjoy spicy food but this was nice and complemented the other flavors well. The Spicy Hulk roll was tuna mashed up (looked like ground beef), avocado, a tiny bit of tobiko and all wrapped up by a piece of cucumber in a spicy sauce that was like lemony soy sauce (ponzu?). I didn't like this at all...the texture freaked me out and I felt like I was eating cat food. It also might have been less enjoyable because I had it after the Crunchy roll. I didn't eat the sweet potato or salmon and avocado rolls, but my friend really enjoyed them, especially the sweet potato roll. I'm so happy I came here and went the adventurous route; I would've completely missed out had I not! The only thing I have to complain about is the size. This place is so freakin small and you're basically seated at a wrap-around bar so you don't get to really face your friends and have a conversation. 

Hope I get to stop in again before I leave!
author: Amanda C.

description:
This is a super cute and cozy sushi spot located on a picturesque corner in charming Hayes Valley. The menu has a great combo of traditional sushi and Americanized "sushi," and there is some fun fusion thrown in. As a primarily veganish eater, I had the sweet potato roll and the veggie roll. Both were big and just two rolls are enough for a whole dinner (especially when sharing a beer and sake!) However, one item on the menu could not be ignored, fish tacos! Yes, gorgeous little tacos, the perfect mix of Japanese and Mexican. Lovely, light, tasty, perfection! I ate one! I did. I didn't die. It was great. 

On a beautiful, warm spring night in San Francisco, eat at Domo! Gaze out at the people passing by, or even sit outside!

The only downside to this place is that it is all bar all around unless you sit outside. Thus, it wouldn't be great for a group larger than three (unless you don't converse), and even with relatively thin people, it can get kinda squishy. 

I'm going back as soon as I find a willing and eager dining partner!
author: Valerie L.

description:
Had a DELICIOUS Domo roll here, very filling and only needed one. Flavor was fantastic and I didn't get sick of the backed mayo type flavor.

Got here on a Wednesday around 7pm and there were only 2 other people there. Friend had rainbow roll that was good as well. The ambiance is pretty intimate, and very cozy-esque. There are no tables - just sushi bar style seating. The only downside I see in the restaurant is the wait to be seated -- by the time we left everything was packed.
author: Adele Z.

description:
The smaller the place, the more I like it. I love the intimate setting here, a few tables outside and all counter inside. It has some nice woodwork and a large mirror to lend itself some space. The specials written on that mirror should not be missed. Usually there is a croquette or some seasonal fish on there as well as special rolls not listed on the menu. The service is great. Portions are small, but leaves me satisfied.

I am a fan of the lunch specials. There is a small, but apt selection that comes with miso soup and an iceberg lettuce wedge with housemade dressing. The dressing is sweet, sour, and refreshing. The fish is incredibly fresh. Go with the chirashi or some nigiri. My top pick is the sunazuri when there is no toro. The sushi is innovative and interesting. The rolls are unlike other ones I've had. The Domo roll was baked and tender. The crunchy spicy tuna was not that crunchy, but had a thick layer of tempura batter, which was even more exaggerated because it was sliced diagonally. The kobe beef roll was delicious and juicy. The beef was sliced incredibly thin and it was really tender. The avocado and asparagus inside was good. Same with the cucumber roll, good use of a different type of wrap than the usual nori. I don't like that some rolls are heavily drizzled with a lot of the same house sauce. Some rolls I wish I could taste without the sauce or just with soy sauce. Also, I wonder if they will serve omakase here...
author: Jennifer W.

description: Love this place. Good Sushi, cute spot.  Really tiny.  Great date spot.
author: Lyly N.

description:
Two things:

Firecracker balls.
Fish Tacos.

That is all.
author: Lauren F.

description:
Cute and yummy sushi spot with some excellent people-watching window seating! The rolls and creative and very tasty. The spicy hulk roll is my favorite - basically, tuna and avocado wrapped in cucumber (no rice).

Ideal for parties of two b/c the place is small. The wait can get long, so I recommend calling in to put your name on the list before you get there.
author: Mia M.

description: Had this place bookmarked for a while and finally stopped by for dinner to try it out. Super cute little place, with a decent variety of sushi and sake. Portion sizes were kinda small and left me hungry but the fish was fresh. Wait staff was pretty attentive. Came here on a weeknight so there was no wait but not sure how this place does on a weekend.
author: Queena T.

description:
Domo is definitely a hidden gem!!  I'd like it to remain hidden lol..because the place is so tiny as is and could easily become like 'Sushi Zone' where the normal wait time even on a week night is 45 min and up..yuck :(.  Bar seating primarily and big open kitchen...would not recommend large groups - more of an intimate setting :)

Anyway on to the more important matter - Foood
mmmmmm mmmm good!

**miso soup - 5/5 was perfect to get us warmed up
**Nigiri (albacore tuna, black snapper special, hamachi belly, and ebi) - 5/5, sweet bites of melt in your mouth freshness
**small crudos (the uni and spicy tuna) - 4/5, both were very delicious but a tease - you get to pick only 2 for $6
**spicy hulk (spicy tuna & avocado, tobiko wrapped in a cucumber sheet with lemon ponzu) - 5/5, super creative roll and a total burst of flavor - the spicy tuna had quite a zing and was fresh, the tobiko added the crunch and texture, the avocado was the mild factor, the cucumber was crisp and refreshing, no soy sauce necessary as the lemon ponzu did the job)

A bottle of delicious Nigori to wash it all down!

This is a great sushi bar - delicious food and attentive staff. The only downside is the size of the restaurant - the seating area is as big as their open kitchen.  I do love the idea of open kitchens but unfortunately the smell of cooking oil is not super appealing, but that will not deter me from coming back!
author: Bhavnak K.

description:
awesome place for some innovative japanese rolls!

I haven't been a huge fan of rolls for, mainly, I didn't like that fact that they usually depend on sauce or rice, but oh boy this place made some pretty spectacular rolls which wowed all 3 of us.

we had Spicy Hulk (rolls), Domo, fire cracker balls and some crudos (uni, scallops and ankimo which were all excellent and fresh).

The bill was only 75 dollars with a glass of sake!  

The only problem was that it's such a small place and unless you get lucky you're more likely to wait for a long time to be seated. However we got to sit right away as we walked in!
author: Sung C.

description: I do like their food, but I have not tried their fish tacos, yet. I enjoy daikon sushi and salmon carpaccio, a simple dish but this is what makes me come back to this place. Sushi is good, too. I like their flavors and not too over powering with too many diff kinds of sushi. There's a CON though, a relative who is in the same restaurant industry. He noticed that they don't have dish washer. They clean all utensils, glass wares by hands??? Isn't it even legal in California? Please advise as this is not hygienic or maybe we did not see one? They got high score of health inspection due to the tiny place. It's easier to clean overall, but no dish washer????
author: Clemencia S.

description:
"Domo Sushi is a hidden gem in the heart of San Francisco's Hayes Valley featuring local market-fresh fish and specialty rolls & dishes with creative and varied combinations" says their website. Well, that's true, but I stil think you should not discover this place. It's mine now! =) I actually am planning to come back more frequently.

So, I just wrote a review recently, but my previous trip this weekend trumps my first visit. Ryo is quite superb at executing an exquisite looking and tasting dish. All the flavors meld and sing together. When I came this time, I merely asked him to make me dishes he felt like creating. Therefore, all the dishes I had this time were off-menu. 

For starters, credos! The first one was quail egg, salmon roe, salmon, and shiso. Heaven in a spoon! The second type was avocado, uni, and a touch of sea salt. mmm....

Our salad course was comprised of daikon, arugula, and flash fried baby aji. It was perfectly light and the fish were amazing. I don't just trust anyone serving me whole fish, but I will here.

The next dish was too amazing for words: avocado, thin slice of grilled kobe beef, topped with uni. Each bite just melted in your mouth. I kept waiting to eat another bite or taking a sip of water because I wanted to savor every delicious bite. 

Our final dish was a similar to a crab cake, but it was made from mussels and served in the shell. They were perfectly baked and tasted delicious. Each bite was warm and filling. 

So, here's the deal. Come to domo, befriend Ryo and let him get to know you. After you know him, let him make you food. Although everything on the menu is great in and of itself, the true genius of this chef shines when he was the free reign to create masterpieces with the freshest ingredients he has in his kitchen. 

Ryo, arigato gozaimashita~
author: Brent A.

description:
Domo is a neighborhood gem. Any restaurant that can sustain my appetite for 1 hour when the female patron next to me has inordinately long armpit hair is A-OK with me.

I dined at Domo on a Thursday evening at 5:30p.m.  There was plentiful outdoor and indoor seating. We ate inside as there seemed to be a breeze coming through the Laguna corridor. The interior of the restaurant is very small and there were 3-4 other tables while we dined. 

Here's what we ordered:

-Salmon nigiri: super fresh and sweet
-Scallop nigiri: also, super fresh and sweet 
-Negi hama (hamachi with scallions): 6 pieces served. Good portion of hamachi in each piece. Love the contrast of sweet hamachi + crunchy green onion.
-Crunchy spicy tuna roll: This was just ok. Had I known that this roll would be deep fried, I would not have chosen it. Luckily, it did not feel too heavy and was tasty. 
-hamachi collar: superb! This took awhile to come out, but when it did, it was a hit! The fish was fresh and perfectly cooked: crispy skin, tender meat, and mouthwatering juicy fatty parts. Served with one of the best ponzu/radish sauces I've tasted in awhile. 

Overall impression: very, very reasonably priced sushi for the price in a quaint, neighborhood location with attentive service.
author: Monelle A.

description:
I came here for lunch one day, and it's a cute little sushi spot in Hayes Valley.  We sat out on the sidewalk because it was sunny out, and this place is pretty alright in my book. 

We got a miso soup, spider rolls (not the best), and the firecracker balls (awesome). I was definitely a bit disappointed with the spider roll... it lacked a certain je ne sais quoi. I also LOVE ginger and was disappointed to see that it wasn't as fresh as it should be.

Definitely not the best sushi in the city, but ok to grab a quick lunch.
author: Taylor L.

description: Very nice place, very nice rolls! the only bad part they didn't have  uni :S
author: Tote G.

description:
If it wasn't apparent to my server, I am clearly going through a tuna phase right now. Tuna Poke, Spicy Tuna and Spicy Hulk? YES PLEASE. Oh, and through in some edamame for good measure.

My favorite of this sampling is the poke. The slices were decently sized, all set atop a seaweed salad. As an added bonus, look for the tiny bits baby octopus sprinkled throughout the dish! Yum!
author: Valerie C.

description:
For a "neighborhood joint" feel and a good date night spot, Domo is ichiban! The fish is always fresh and sliced generously and the sushi rice is seasoned properly.  I've been going for about three years, and now that I live in the neighborhood, I go at least twice a month.  And, while I may go alone, I never eat alone.  Ryo, the head sushi chef and manager, is unpretentious, outgoing, cool, and has great taste in music.  It's easy to sit at the bar and engage him in conversation while he prepares you some delicious sushi.  The staff is also very friendly and helpful with the menu. 

I like to recommend Domo as a good date place, especially for dates #1-4.  It's small and intimate with soft lighting, so everyone looks pretty good and you don't have to yell to communicate.  The seating is all counter style so you sit next to one another which can work when you're too nervous or don't want to be forced to face each other, or, when you want to be able to lean in closer or even have a reason to "accidentally" touch.  Finally, it's sushi.  For those fortunate enough to be on a date with someone who likes sushi, it's perfect date food, light, yet filling, allows you to show off your cultured palate and the dinner can be as long or as short as you can handle.  And to help you seal the deal, you can try going off the beaten path from the menu and order dinner from Ryo, omakase (chef's choice).

While they don't have a "kitchen", there are some excellent dishes besides sushi/sashimi that are unique to Domo.  Try any of their Crudos; the Ankimo, monkfish liver pate, is made in-house, fresh, and is great for those who enjoy foie gras or duck liver pate.  The Daikon Salad, served with arugula and bonito shavings; light and refreshing while anchored with the earthy bitterness of the arugula and the delicate saltiness of the bonito and drizzled with a house dressing.  Iidako, deep-fried baby octopus served with a spicy dipping sauce, takes the pedestrian calamari to a different level.  One of my go-to favorites, and highly overlooked, is the Hamachi Kama.  The kama is the jaw or cheek of the Yellowfin Tuna that they broil and serve with lemon and a light soy or temari sauce.  It's always cooked perfectly tender and completely satisfying.  Try the Fish Tacos.  It's a creative take on mexican tacos using deep-fried nori as the shell, filled with a couple different fish and avocado and topped with a house-made salsa.   And finally, while I am not a roll girl, I would recommend trying the Crunchy California Roll, which is a tempura-style deep-fried roll, the Domo Roll, which is a really luxurious baked roll topped with scallop and sauces, and the Jalapeno Hamachi,not nearly as big or as fancy as the previous two, but the juxtaposition of the sweet, soft hamachi with the crunchy, crisp, sometimes spicy jalapeno and sea salt is one that I often crave.
author: Shirley T.

description:
This is one of those places I want to get well know because it is soo good but I also would prefer it stay more of a hidden gem because I already have to wait 30 minutes anytime I visit. That being said ...

Food: Fish is always fresh and the combinations are well balanced on the rolls. I often order off the board just because it is seasonal and fresh. Everyone raves about the fish tacos. I agree they are good but the menu has a lot of other things that are much more interesting so get a little adventurous and order something off the board. 

Service: its a small restaurant so can't be that hard to manage but usually two servers and always helpful and on top of it. They clear plates quickly and bring out courses quickly. Simple concepts but nice. 

Ambiance: its a small spot so not a lot you can do with it but that is also what makes it great. Never more than maybe 16-20 diners at a time eating. 

Sake choices are nice too
author: Adam W.

description:
This review is simply for the service, and not for the food, because i didn't GET to eat here.

I know this place is small, and that is why I feel it should be important to optimize the space that is available.  

As a tip to the host/servers: if most of your seating is bar space, and you have a party of 4 that you are seating, and a party of 4 waiting (myself and friends), and there are two empty chairs on either side of the party of four you are just sitting down, it might be a good idea to have them move down so that there are then another 4 chairs in a row, so that the party of four that is waiting can also be seated.

just an idea.

but even after asking the host if he could do this, and receiving a no in response, we walked out and ate dinner elsewhere. 

see ya never.
author: Jamie J.

description: I am never disappointed with a meal at Domo.  My favorites are the Sake Toro, Domo Roll, Albacore Tetake, and Uni. It's a great date spot; there is usually wait, but it is well worth it.  You can leave your number and grab a drink around the corner on Hayes too!
author: Emily B.

description:
Delicious and artful, while still being down-to-earth. The food, presentation, and service are all great.

Best for solo diners or couples (it's a small place) or sitting at a table outside on a warm evening. 

If you're anywhere near Hayes Valley and dining alone, sitting in the Domo window bar and people-watching cute, little Momi Toby's cafe across the street while you enjoy your delicious sushi is ideal.
author: Dinah S.

description: Great little gem!  Stopped by for lunch and had a great experience. Fish was fresh. Had a good sake  selection.  The daikon salad was a refreshing twist. The best were the fish tacos, very nicely done fusion dish!  Wow!
author: LL L.

description: The sushi here is the best I've had in a while, and I've had some good sushi!  The place is small so be prepared to arrive a bit early and put your name on the list so you don't want to have to wait 30 minutes.  I loved everything I ate here.  And the service was great.
author: Tina T.

description:
Came here with my GF on a Friday night and remarkably did not have to wait.  This was a major bonus given that the entire time we were dining, there were parties of two waiting.

My GF and I split a few items.  I thought the standouts were the firecracker balls and the hamachi sashimi, which was cut nice and thick so you could really get a good bite.  The fish tacos were good too.

So why isn't this a 4 or 5 star review?  The service was pretty bad.  Although the server was prompt in taking our order and bringing out the firecracker balls and sashimi, there were long delays in getting our other dishes.  In fact, the server clearly forgot about us and had to come by and ask if we were waiting on anything else.  At that time, we told him we never received our appetizers and one other dish.  A bit of a cluster fuck.  Maybe it was just b/c they were busy but you would think that checking up on your customers and delivering the food that has been ordered is pretty standard operations.  Oh well, the service didn't ruin the food.
author: Larry L.

description: Decent food. The fish was pretty fresh and the rolls were flavorful. The firecracker balls were okay. Service was slow and inefficient.
author: Tan P.

description:
Came here with a good friend last week, due to the good Yelp reviews. We got there at 5:30ish on a week night, it's a fairly small place and the only table available was for 3 ppl so we were sent to the waiting area (they would have earned 1 more star if they let us seated at that 3 ppl table, not to mention that table was unoccupied the whole hour while we were there). We had a movie to catch afterwards so although it was chilly, we decided to sit outside. 

We ordered Domo, Kobe Beef, Sexy Mama, Temptation, Hamachi and Salmon sashimi and 2 orders of crudos. The only thing that was memorable was the uni and scallop crudos, the rest of the food was ok, no wow factors. I've definitely had better versions of the same things elsewhere but here, the portion was smaller. For the price, I should have gone to Ichi, for better services and food.
author: Lulu C.

description:
Cute little sushi establishment with indoor and outdoor seating. The whole restaurant is set up as one sushi bar with most of the bar seats facing out the window. The place is pretty small so come with the expectation of waiting. I would not recommend coming here with a large party of 4 or more.

We ordered the seaweed salad, the mac daddy roll, and the special cucumber roll topped with salmon and lemon. The seaweed salad was absolutely delicious (5 out of 5!). However, my friend and I were not impressed with the rolls. The fish on both the rolls were fresh but the actual rolls were lacking in flavor and the sushi rice was a bit dry. Also, I was disappointed in Domo's ginger. Not fresh at all. 

The service was excellent. The wait staff was super friendly and attentive. 

In summary: 
Ambiance: 5/5
Service: 5/5
Food: 3/5
author: Hannah N.

description:
This review is really about the service vs the food.  Food would have probably been a 4.  Here goes...

The fact they don't take reservations isn't a big deal. My issue is that they have 1 table that they set for a table of 3. The said table of 3 was behind us on the list and showed up 15 minutes after I did.  My wait went from 45 to 55 minutes.  They didn't call the 3 top or seat them, just left the table until a spot for 2 was available.  The best part about that was two groups were waiting for those 10 minutes for their check.  This was after 10 PM on a Saturday.

To top things off they sat us and the party of 3 at the same time, yet they had drinks and an appetizer before we had a, "Hello".  The hostess finally noticed all of this and finally took our order.  I don't know if this is typical of Domo since it was my first time there, but I won't be back to find out.
author: Ryan P.

description: Great lunch specials and fast service. Enjoyed the specialty rolls and soup. Great place to connect with some locals and learn more about the neighborhood. Just a few blocks away from some nice vacation rental flats.
author: Matt E.

description: Fiesta Roll & Fire Cracker Balls..DELICIOUS! also would recommend the Crudos - but they're bite sized so more of a novelty than filling.
author: Ketki W.

description:
First time here over the weekend.

First, you can put your name and number down and they will call you when your table is ready.  Now you can go to a bar around the corner, or wait it out at home instead of just standing around, yay!

the specials are written on a mirror, so it's pretty hard to read them.  I think a chalkboard would look better with the feel of the place, and just be easier to read, but whatevs - we didn't order from that. 

We got the firecracker roll, Domo roll and the fish tacos. 

firecracker roll was BOMB.  perfect amount of sauce, crunch and yumminess.

The fish tacos were SO FREAKIN GOOD. Would not have ordered these if we didn't see the table next to us drooling over theirs, and SO glad we did.  the fish was ridiculously good, and the salsa they used, along with the little fluffy chip thing it was on was DELICIOUUUSSSSS. I was tempted to just order more of these.

Domo roll was a-OK. The roll kept falling apart and didn't taste any different from your average baked roll at another spot. I would definitely skip this next time, but either way I'm definitely coming back for the above two items.
author: Megha A.

description: Really tasty sushi! It's really small though so prepare to wait but it's def worth it!
author: Ayele A.

description:
Where else can you get 8 pieces of sashimi for $12? It is also some of the best sashimi I've had in the city.

Definitely my go-to sushi place. Great, creative rolls. They pay attention to quality (and therefore they do not have 50 different rolls of various combinations of the same 3 types of fish). Sake selection is minimal but a "glass" is more like a "small jug" and thus well worth your purchase price. Highly recommend the fish tacos, fire cracker balls, and pretty much whatever they have on special. Small space so not the best place for big parties. Just bar seating and one high-top table that will seat 4.
author: Jasmyn M.

description:
I'm a convert! We walked in on a Thursday night at 8pm to no wait - hurray! It's the perfect little spot for an intimate but casual first date: low key, low lighting, delicious food. 

We ordered (and devoured): 

-Spicy Tuna Roll: these were cut into pretty big pieces but included a lot of fresh fish and avocado.
 
-Fiesta Roll: tasty roll with mango, tuna and fresh salsa. 

-Sexy Mama Roll: salmon with asparagus tobiko and lemon. The lemon is really refreshing and makes this roll surprisingly light. 

-Jalapeno Hamachi Roll: This was my favorite. Simple and perfect. 

Prices are reasonable, fish is fresh, rolls are tasty and service is great! I'm definitely coming back!
author: Mel L.

description: The sashimi here is always crazy fresh which , for the price is hard to find. The wait is usually pretty long so get there early and get your name on the list and roam around to a nearby coffee shop or bar to kill some time. It's a small place, but the quality is great. They have some creative rolls and small plates which are really nice to share. Service is great :)
author: Amber R.

description: Real solid sushi joint - definitely will go back. Ordered the sashimi platter, their house domo roll and the miso soup. Not too expensive and the sashimi/rolls were generous cuts.  Prepare to wait (can't call ahead) since it's a smaller place.
author: Sean P.

description: One of my fave sushi place in town. Don't get intimidated by the line and how small the place is, you'll find yourself ROLLing very soon. Don't forget to try firecracker balls!
author: Beril Y.

description: Exceptional sushi with unique rolls! Love this place!
author: Merve A.

description:
WINNER: Best Sushi

My favorite sushi in SF.  I think it's better than some of the popular ones like O-Toro and Sushi-Puzzle.  I love the sea urchin here.  It's creamy and melts in your mouth.  At some places it can be bitter if it's not fresh.  I also love the sea trout.  It very similar to salmon in it's rich consistency, but it's a little bit oilier.  As for rolls, you can go wrong with the Apollo roll.  The crunchy California is also very good.
author: Sue N.

description: 3 1/2 Stars!!  It's in a great neighborhood spot -- parking is not too hard to find out here if you come early enough!  There isn't much variety to their menu, but what they do have is pretty solid.  If you don't come here early you will have to wait, but my friends and I were there before 7 and the wait was not too bad.  I think we may have waited 20 mins.
author: M. T.

description:
Came in on Friday night, 11/12/10 @ 1031pm. We were seated immediately and given water. Restaurant was not busy, no wait and the seats were less than 1/2 filled. Unfortunately we waited 14 minutes before we decided to leave. The waitress took too long to take our order. We obviously knew what we wanted and made that known by placing our menus down and by looking attentively at her and the staff. She continued to fill water and cash out a table of 4 men who asked for the bill to be split 4 ways. I was hoping she'd take our order first before completing such a tedious task.  Cashing out a table can wait a few minutes. As we got up to leave, no one said anything...no acknowledgment, not even a "bye." terrible service this night. Terrible. 

I have been here before and had decent service which is why I am giving this place 2 stars. Sushi is alright. More of an American/Touristy style of sushi. I prefer Sushi Zone or Tataki over this place for sure. Better fish.
author: Tara K.

description: I came back from Japan dreading going back to eating sushi sub par to what I was eating in Japan, but I was craving it so me and my boyfriend chose this place. Average prices, but I was pleasantly surprised. The fish was fresh, and delicious. The salmon nigiri I had was just as good as what I had in Japan. I did not enjoy the spicy tuna roll though, not because the fish wasn't good but they put raw sprouts in it which kind of overpowered everything and seemed random. Overall very good and pla to go back.
author: Milla K.

description:
When places are this bad at providing food, I mark them as great places to lose weight.

The first time here, we put our name on the list and started waiting.  It took 5min to grab the host and ask for a time estimate.  He said the wait was 90min so we should leave.  I was pretty amazed at the blatant suggestion we leave.

On a Monday night, we walked past and there was a short wait list, so we decided to try the wait.  The estimated wait from the host was 20-25 min.  After a 50min wait, we cornered the host and asked for a wait update.  He said that a table that had just gotten its sushi and 4 bottles of sake was nearly done and that the wait would be short.  We walked.  As we left we got a call from Domo - when we answered they hung up.  We gave them a call back and the phone was busy.

While we were waiting we heard the host give one person a 50min estimate for a table of 2 and the next person a 20min estimate for a table of 2.  The wait times are made up, ridiculous no matter what the estimate is, and the list is a suggestion the host has no problem pulling randomly from.

My tip - be prepared to pleasure the host.
author: Boris K.

description:
Martin Luther King Jr. Day Plans: Sleep in, finish Kendra's Sliding Into Home, and lunch with friends. 

But who knew so many places were be closed on a Monday for lunch?! All of my neighborhood spots: Little Star, Eiji, Limon, etc.

A search on Yelp found Domo who was not only open but had lunch specials (sushi rice plates).

Domo is in such a cute neighborhood with cafes, shops and clean streets. Earthbody Spa is right across. 

We opted to sit outside since there are no tables inside. 

We all got a lunch special for $13 that includes a soup and salad. Tea is also free! I got the "Open Face Dragon" that came with two big pieces of tempura shrimp, unagi, and avocado over sushi rice. 

My friend ordered the Fiesta Roll but that just didn't work because its mexican japanese fusion... with salsa and not enough albacore tuna. Should have known better... besides that everything else was good even though its not authentic.
author: Julia T.

description:
Like what most other reviewers say, this place is small and not good for large groups.  Majority of the seats are bar seats, wrapped the windows to the sushi counter.  There is a small tall table in a corner but cannot fit more than 4 people there.  I came here on recommendation by a friend who lives in Hayes Valley.  

I had shishito peppers, hamachi carpaccio, fish taco, aji nigiri, uni nigiri, scallop nigiri, salmon belly nigiri, hamachi nigiri and albacore nigiri.  The shisito peppers were tasty because they were topped with bonito flakes, which gave the dish more complexity in flavors. However, I found it too salty after a few consecutive bites.  The hamachi carpaccio was seared - I guess I didn't read the description in the menu well enough but while I was eating it, I couldn't help but wish that the carpaccio was kept raw and not seared.  The nigiri sushi was good and standard, though a few pieces toppled over after 10 minutes of not eating it right away.  But I am a self proclaimed sushi snob hailing from NYC, so I thought the sushi was fairly average.  The highlight of the night was the fish tacos.  They were delicious, especially the fried seaweed tempura, which was quite literally the backbone of the dish.
author: Kai C.

description:
Firecracker balls.  That's all I need to say, really.  They're amazing, despite that they probably contain a billion calories.  If you're normally a healthy eater and you're having a weekly treat meal, you must do yourself a favor and eat the balls!

Also, our server was extremely knowledgeable about the specials, the sake, everything.  She was kind, and she wasn't obnoxious like when the server comes to check on you so much that you can't even carry a conversation with your friends.

This place is small, so if you're uber hungry I might suggest going elsewhere.  We had to wait only about ten minutes, but as we sat eating our meal, we noticed several people waited quite a long time to get seated.  I'm definitely returning to Domo.  It was outstanding, and I couldn't be more satisfied.
author: Sarah B.

description:
02.17.14 with 1 other for lunch

Domo is a very small neighborhood japanese fusion place, i think inside was about 8 seats and a couple tables outside.

I liked how simple their menu was, the more simple the more focused on what they make for you.

I enjoyed my meal here, i forgot what my dish was called but it was a open faced dragon roll i think with unagi and tempura shrimp on rice with avacado. delish! 

service was also very prompt and our waiter answered all my questions.
author: Jay R.

description:
Really small restaurant with limited seating. Small means coming here with a party of 4 or more might pose a problem for you and them. Sitting options include - outside where there are a couple tables under the awning, inside at the sushi bar, or inside along the window on stools.

That said, I LOVE the small feeling - it's quaint, cozy and yet very post-modern, chic. 

Food was delicious and unique. If you want your traditional sushi this may not be for you. But if you want sushi with a twist then Domo is great. My spicy tuna roll was wrapped not in seaweed but cucumber paper - and it was incredibly tasty. I would also recommend their firecracker- not what I expected but very good. Finally, if you like nutty green tea, their tea is above par. And, of course, there are unlimited refills - I think I had six or seven cups. 

All around, it was an incredibly relaxing, quaint, and positive experience; I look forward to coming back and experiencing the rest of their menu.
author: Kimya P.

description:
Holy Batman! This is some of the best sushi I have ever had. PLEASE GO! It is expensive but WORTH IT!
The place is small and you have to wait. Try to sit at the bar and watch what these artists are doing.
Do not order normal, really go and try something new. The fireballs were great, the Kobe beef OMG! Watching them cook it with the blow torch! The little touches are all worth it.
author: Natasha M.

description: Loved my experience! The jalapeño himachi roll was surprisingly my favorite of the night, along with the salmon nigiri. Adorable inside and worth the wait.
author: Jenna M.

description:
Date & Time:  Friday June 20, 2008 @ 8:30pm
Company:  Michael
Crowd:  Very Friendly & Kewl 20-30 Somethings
Vibe:  Energetic
Decor:  So Cool(love the set up- no tables) and Intimate(place seats 15)!   8 Wooden High-Back Counter-Seating in Front of The Huge Window- Prime Seating for People-Watching.  Two Seats in front of The Mirror where The Daily Specials are Written.  Sushi Bar that seats 5.  The Best Sushi Chefs in The City!  Three Outdoor Tables- One High Tables and Chairs by The Curb and Two Wooden Tables w/ Loungey Chairs that Seats 4 Per Table.   Bench on the other Side.  We Spent 20 minutes hanging out there with Enchico Beers and Chatted with this really Cute Couple that lived in the Neighborhood.  Tiny Lights flicker from Sugar Containers and Test Tube Ones Dangle from the Light Wood Ceiling.
Service:  Very Friendly Waiter & Busboy & Efficient Waitress.  Incredible Sushi Chef(whom I forgot the name of), came by to Introduce Himself during Dessert.
Imbibe:  Enchico Beer & Sake
Devour:  We asked for The Omakase which is All the Chefs Specials until we say no mas.  We had 8 Delectable Courses Starting with Daikon Salad, Poke, Fried Smelt Fish, Kampachi, Spicy Tuna Roll, Sashimi, Fried Firecracker Rice Balls w/ All these Sauces & Black Sesame Ice Cream.  We also got a chance to Sample the Crudo's(definite must) that comes in Spoons.  We had the Uni & Crab.  We befriended our Seatmate Jeff W. & We Shared our Dishes so we got to try even more stuff.  Jeff & Michael had a lot in Common from their Motorcycles to Line of Work. 
Total:  $74.89 A Real Deal for 8 Courses for 3 since we shared our plates!   
Notes:  Write your Name at The Entrance Clipboard as there IS going to be a Wait and Chill w/ a Beer or Wine & Meet the other Cool Patrons. 
Side Note:  This place reminds me of a Japanese Version of Brenda's from the Intimate Space to the Incredible Food,  Daily Specials on The Mirror, Great People & Long Wait, but Well Worth It!
author: Genevieve Y.

description:
One of my all time favorite sushi restaurants!  The fish tacos are unique and amazing - a definite must try. 

The place is small and not really setup for groups.  It's mostly bar seating with only one table that will fit three people inside.  There are also a few tables outside. 

There is usually a wait but for two it goes pretty quick, just enough time to get a drink at the cafe across the street.
author: MK D.

description:
Great little spot to stop for some tasty sushi.  It's designed for "on-the-go" eating, and there is not one table in the place to encourage lingering.  Instead, you pull up a stool and belly up to a counter, either facing the sushi bar, or facing the window.  A server takes your order, and whoosh, you are on your way.

I met Jill K. there for an early dinner last week, and thank God we got there early.  At 6:00 there were seats available, at 6:30 there was a line - on a Wednesday.  Seems that people in the neighborhood were ready for a new sushi place, despite having Sebo just a block or so away.

I loved that they offer "crudos", or little one-bite tastes, served in soup spoons.  We tried the Uni and the Salmon crudo - I could make a meal out of an assortment these delicious mouthfuls.  The uni one had avocado, and the salmon had capers and onions.

We shared a couple rolls, and they were very good.  The Spicy Tuna is VERY spicy, which I liked.  The sushi is fresh and well-prepared, and one of the rolls we tried had salmon, asparagus, tobiko and yuzu in it ("Sexy Mama Roll") - bright flavors which were perfect for spring.  I don't know if I can bring myself to try the firecracker balls as I am loyal to the ones at Red Box Sushi, but I watched order after order go out and they looked decadent and good.

They have a small selection of sakes, and this sounds weird but I really liked the water that they bring to the table.  It's ice cold and served in a lovely glass bottle.

It would be a great stop after a day of shopping or after work, either with a friend or by yourself.  Since you are seated side-by-side, and the place is so small, I wouldn't recommend a group larger than two people.

Nice, friendly service, reasonable prices, great location.  I'll be back soon!
author: Liz S.

description:
I have been here twice now.  

I love the fact that there are no big tables, so there is much less of risk to sit right next to loudly giggling drunk people.  All customers were there in pairs or maybe threes, but the noise level was wonderfully low.  Also, the super cool drum-n-chill music (not too loud either) plus the low lighting and the wood decor, it all helps a lot to make this an imtimate place for enjoying food.

Often at sushi places the staff are super hectic, but not here - lots of smiles and time for you.  Congrats for that.

Food: The first time I had the Také, and absolutley loved the balance between the raw fish and the greens.  The second time I started with the fish taco (4 stars) and then a chalkboard special: fried octopus - awesome!!!   A  I didn't try any rolls in my two visits, but they sure looked interesting as well.

Please note that i am giving it five stars for totally achieveing what this place is trying to do:  if you want a super romantic place or somewhere to show off, this is not the place.  Just very fresh and creative Japanese foods.
author: Pascal M.

description: its a very small place but they offer a great experience. lots of daily specials and the seafood is definitely fresh. You can tell a lot of thought went into preparing the menu with the special rolls. Only been here once but would stop by again to try something new from the menu.
author: Lazylibra A.

description: This is my third time back here in two months and I must say this is my favorite sushi spot in the city thus far. The quality and price can not be beat, and the service had been excellent every time I've come in. Seating is limited and all but one table is bar seating so keep that in mind during peak hours or if you have a larger party. Domo is excellent across the board, you won't be disappointed!
author: Marjorie K.

description:
Came here with a couple friends to celebrate and its just as good as the last time. The Ankimo appetizer needed a touch of Japanese sea salt, didn't taste seasoned enough although the thinly sliced cucumber added a perfect crunch. The Wagyu Beef roll needs a little less avocado and the meat seemed a little on the tougher side - maybe add some crab in the middle and call it surf n turf. The Tacos were surprisingly good, crunchy with great flavors and the salmon was cooked perfect. The Fiesta Roll was refreshing and a interesting take on Mexican-Japanese fusion. Had 2 orders of the Yellow fin Belly, sooooo good. The Butterfish nigiri was super fresh. Sushi is all about the rice and I forget how good it is made here. Keep up the good work Domo. 

Atmosphere: Tiny but they have outdoor seating and usually doesn't take that long on weekdays. Farely Hip. They need to stop putting specials on the mirror cant read it.  
Service: Smiling faces.
Sake: Kinda pricey went with the hot Sho chiku Bai and an Asahi Black.
Cost: $125
Overall Score: 4
author: Sean B.

description:
This gets my vote for BEST SASHIMI in SF.  Extremely fresh, just the right thickness and delicious.  

Domo always executes a tasty time.  Love their cold sake and their awesome sake glasses that come with it (tipsy drunk friendly - I swear theres divots for your fingers!).  I would be happy for life eating their "spicy hulk" roll and sashimi.  

Tiny place, so only bring your honey - or eat outside on their heated patio.  :)  nomnomnom
author: Jana S.

description:
San Francisco has some awesome sushi places, but my experience at Domo was just average. I had been here a couple of years ago, and it was more delicious back then. I came the other night with a friend. Had a seaweed salad (good) and some rolls: crunchy spicy tuna (meh- a little too tempura for me), sweet potato (now this one should've been crispy, in my opinion), salmon/avocado/lemon (gross- the fish just did NOT seem fresh; had two pieces and let the rest go to waste). 

Probably won't  be back anytime soon. Too many other great sushi places that charge the same or less for better tasting fish.
author: Meade G.

description: We went on a crowded night and the restaurant was crowded so we got a table out in front (in the rain!) I have no memory of whether or not the service was good, but none of that mattered because the food was  sooo amazing. I never got the hype about sushi until eating here, and now I'm a sushi convert! We got tons of dishes and each was fantastic as was the sake selection. Highly highly recommend!
author: Becca C.

description:
I really liked Domo.  The sushi was fresh and flavorful.  The Ankimo (monkfish liver) was fresh and clean tasting, unlike most other places I've had it.  Other must tries:

Fire Cracker Balls: crunchy, spicy, addicting
Sexy Mama Roll: lemony fresh and tasty
Spicy Hulk Roll: wrapped in cucumber gives it awesome fresh flavor and texture
Hawaiian Style Tuna Poke: sooo yummy!

Overall definitely one of the better sushi bars in SF. Get there early, it's tiny and theres always a line.
author: Mia L.

description:
Domo is a nice little neighborhood sushi place. I like it and their lunch special is a great deal.

It's very small and I wouldn't recommend going with more then 4 people. Ideally 2. The frontside patio is a bonus on a sunny day or warm night.

I would describe this place as a great neighborhood sushi place for a casual date.
Nothing more, nothing less.
author: Alexandre T.

description: Amazing food! The lunch box option was a great value. The fish items were all super fresh. I wish I lived closer, so that I could return.
author: Cindy W.

description: Fantastic! Perfectly satisfied my SF sushi craving. I am still thinking about the firecracker balls. We arrived at around 5:30 on a Wednesday and had our pick of where to sit. By the time we left at 7:30, there was a wait. Everything we had was great. Service was wonderful. My favorite roll was the domo roll. The poke was refreshing. The crudos were wonder. We just had an awesome time.
author: Natalie L.

description:
The first time I ate at Domo, I did something so terrible that I thought the sushi was "two star - meh - I've experienced better" as a result of my deservedly bad karma.

There aren't a lot of sushi restaurants in Hayes Valley and Domo had just opened and everyone was saying great things about it and everyone wanted to eat there, so everyone was standing outside waiting for a seat.  We put our name on the list and joined the crowd on the sidewalk.  It was cold and windy and the sun hadn't even gone down yet.  By the time it did, I was starving AND freezing.  I can deal with starving better than freezing.  

Finally the hostess came out and called a name. It was the name of my dining companion, but it's a common first name.  We'd been there awhile, but not long enough for her to be calling us at that point.  She was calling someone else with the same name.  She called out a second time.  No one moved.  We looked at each other and both got up and walk to the hostess for 'our' seats.  

Here's how karma kicked my self-entitled ass.  First, the seats that we just jumped ended up being outside (where it had not gotten any less cold or windy.)  Then, in the interest of this being a useful review, the nigiri was small and not very fresh and the rolls were bland.  Domo is a sushi restaurant that's open on Mondays if that tells you anything.  It wasn't exactly bad (no one got sick later), but the color and texture were off and there are tons of sushi restaurants all over SF that are a lot better for the same price. Since 'everyone' was still raving about Domo a year later, we gave it another shot.  We didn't jump in line this time, but it was still cold and the sushi wasn't any better either. 

At least it'll be warm when I get to hell.

***To be clear, this is a 2 star review of the sushi, not SF weather.
author: P J.

description: Ocean trout is a must. Very fresh fish and fun atmosphere. Spicy Hulk roll which came wrapped in cucumber was a refreshing twist on a more typical spicy tuna roll. I would also recommend the Castro roll if you like a variety of delicious fresh fish.
author: Sam B.

description:
This is probably my favorite sushi place in Hayes Valley.  The place is really small but I've never waited too long for a table.  Service is always great and friendly.

I've had the spicy tuna and scallop crudos.  The spicy tuna was great but the scallop was a little bland.

I love rolls so I usually get the rolls at this place.  The firecracker ball and domo rolls just melt in your mouth - my favorites.  Cruchy spicy tuna, spider, and the spicy hulk rolls are also very good.   My least favorite is proabably the Fiesta roll - mango and cilantro with the tuna doesn't taste quite right to me.

They also have a couple of tables outside which is great during spring and summetime.
author: glen o.

description:
I am definitely a fan of this tiny sushi joint.  I am a big fan of sushi rolls (my favorite being Sushi House in Alameda) and this place lives quite up to the hype.  The rolls are a lot less heavy than Sushi House but it's quite good.  

You need to try the Spicy Hulk because it's unlike any sushi roll I've ever tried.  It's spicy tuna wrapped in a cucumber sheet!  It taste so healthy and yet so good!  The Domo roll was very tasty as well if you like warm sushi.  You always gotta try the rolls named after the restaurant, after all.  

The venue is quite small with only bar seating surrounding the insides of the restaurant and one table inside.  There are three tables outside but no one would sit there on a cold SF night.  I can see this place getting busy real fast on the weekends so I recommend going on a week night where there's less traffic.
author: Tori Q.

description: Great spot, good fresh sushi.  Small place, might have a wait, but worth it. Try the sake toro and Saba hit.
author: Jeffery S.

description: Definitely want to try the fish tacos next time.
author: Chandni S.

description:
Ok Domo is hella bomb!
Went here last night and cant wait to go again. This place is SUPER small. So its great for a date. All the seats are bar style around the window and counter. I'm guessing maybe 14 people can fit in here at one time...max. the atmoshpere is energetic but quiet because there are a lot of people in  small space. the service is good too. we sat down less than 5 minuets afer walking in and sat in a little edge on the wall. i think we were both blocking someones  chair but nobody was going any where and we would have gladly moved for someone to exit.  the timing is a little off but the food made up for it. we got our edamame right before the first roll so we didnt have time to enjoy it before we dug into the main event. from there the domo roll took a little long to get out but then again it was cooked may have needed a little more love than the other rolls. 

We ordered the Temptation, Domo, Kobe Beef, and Chef's choice Sashimi

Temptation: everything i always want in one roll!!! i love it! it was pretty small. about 6 pieces but it was delicious!

Sashimi: well it was fresh and it was good but there were only two pieces of each type of fish so it wasnt very satisfying. and i have had fresher sashimi before but that doesnt mean theres wasnt spot on good. 

Domo: Took a little longer to come out. Just the right amount of spicey mayo. I love the baked rolls and the presentation was the best ive probably seen in a baked roll.
 
Kobe Beef:  while everything was super great and yummy we werent quite full yet so we decided to order one more roll. No rice, just steak. Thats just about as americanized sushi can get. it was soo good but i doubt i would get it again. it was nice to try.

overall a great experience.
author: Ashley H.

description:
I think Domo served some of the best non-authentic "fun" sushi I've had in San Francisco!  One thing I always complain about is how San Francisco lacks good sushi.  I'm talking about delicious L.A.-style sushi.  You know, the trendy, fun sushi that you eat at Katsuya while people-watching.  For me, Domo served this purpose... except without the celebrities and celebutantes... 

It was a Saturday night and we had made dinner reservations at a different place in Hayes Valley and were STARVING.  To our dismay, we learned out our table would not be ready for awhile since other diners were lagging, so we decided to walk around Hayes Valley.  I wasn't even craving sushi at the time, but saw Domo and instantly started to think about how delicious it could be.  We put our names on the list and - lucky us! - were able to get seats at the inside bar area within a few minutes!

Please note that I can't speak to the quality of the sashimi or nigiri because we were STARVING so we just shared rolls (more bang for our buck), but the rolls are outstanding if you are in the mood for that!

We ordered the following:

Firecracker balls: 5/5 REaLLy tasty!  Don't expect to really taste the fish and to love the firecracker balls as sushi, but still expect to love them.  They're SO flavorful!  And deliciously spicy.  No wasabi or soy sauce needed.

Spicy hulk:  5/5 One thing Domo does REALLY well is its spicy tuna!  Get as much of it as you can!  I usually don't like rolls wrapped in cucumber rather than rice, but the spicy hulk was SO good!  Again, perfectly spicy and tasty - no wasabi or soy sauce needed.

Crunchy spicy tuna: 4.5/5 Also delicious, again because of the outstanding spicy tuna.  Would definitely get this again.

Jalapeno hamachi: 3/5 Decent.  We didn't love it, but it was still decent.  The chunks of jalapeno were a bit much, I thought.  My eyes started to water a bit.  I wouldn't get this roll again.

Fiesta: 1/5  Yuck.  I guess I don't like mango pieces in rolls.  It tasted a bit disturbing with the fish and I ended up pulling the mango pieces out in the end and dousing this roll with soy sauce and wasabi.  Definitely would not get this again.

Fish taco appetizer:  This dish gets probs for how creatively it is put together.  The taco "shell" is made of seaweed and tempura batter.  I am going to refrain from giving this a rating since I HATE salmon and didn't realize, in our ordering frenzy (don't judge me), that there was salmon in here.  My dinner companion liked this, though, and he's a salmon fan.

Overall, I really enjoyed my dinner at Domo.  We shared a bottle of unfiltered sake, which made for a fun evening:)  

Just a tip:  I don't recommend coming here if you have more than 2 people because I think it's pretty hard to get a table.  This place is TINY.
author: Julie S.

description: Really nice sushi place - small and cute, but good quick service. The crudo were amazing - tuna and scallop. Rolls were pretty stellar as well. Highly recommend.
author: Jeremy N.

description:
Methinks not is right! The worst service I've had in San Francisco. Had a Douche-bag waiter who wouldn't tell me his name because he couldn't stand behind it. I guess I shouldn't have told him that I'd write about my experience.

I was a server through college and understand what (1) a good training program is and (2) that your work reflects your character. 

We sat around 20 minutes without a single check-in. More water? Drinks? Another bite? NOPE. Instead he abandoned us and left with a pile of empty dishes and sake glasses. I couldn't get drunk if i tried.

The food wasn't cheap but good. What a shame.
author: Rob A.

description:
Creative rolls!  I really enjoyed the mexican roll, which had salsa and mango in it.  Fish and a little kick really makes for a tasty bite.

I like that these rolls actually contained different ingredients.  You know how sometimes you just end up ordering specialty rolls that are actually just california rolls with a different topping on the roll?  This place has different ingredients inside the rolls!  

The place is cramped, so small parties are better for this place!  Not bad for a date I think.  Good excuse to squish close together.
author: Anna T.

description: This place is small but memorable.  Everything is fresh and presented beautifully.  The Fire Cracker Balls and the Spicy Hulk is delicious.  All of the small crudos are incredible.  I love sushi, but this takes the cake!
author: Julia A.

description: I never had a shiitake roll before, it was delicious! As well as all the other ones we tried. Loved it!
author: Kathi S.

description:
Food was awesome.  The place is a bit small - however they do a good job of moving people through well.  

We had a spicy hulk (spicy tuna) - which was very light (no rice) and super fresh - highly recommend it, sexy mama (salmon) - has a bit too much lemon zest but still very good and the domo roll (baked salmon roll) - interesting item, however the sauce was a bit too sweet - preference would be too be light on the sauce.  

Definitely - a must go for the sushi yelpers!
author: Bhavin M.

description:
So-so sushi. The menu and the way things are described makes the place sound absolutely delicious. But the actual sushi was so-so. The Temptation roll sounded great, but was just ok. It looked nice but the flavors were not much better than grocery store sushi. The nigiri were all a little fishy, and the salmon had tough sinews in them, which was surprising because even grocery store salmon is usually at least relatively tender.

High hopes based on the way the place sounds and looks, but disappointingly so-so food.
author: J C.

description:
I stumbled upon Domo in a buzz after a few hours at happy hour in Hayes Valley.  I don't know how I got there, but I navigated from Sugar Lounge in my 4 1/2" Michael Kors, up a few blocks, and made a left somewhere and found Domo to my right.  The place just looked small and cozy, with all 15 some odd seats filled up (there is a sushi bar, a counter along two walls, and only one table, if I remember correctly).  Immediately I put my name on the waiting list, party of 3.  There was only one party of 2 waiting before us, so we enjoyed some beer and sake outside until our table was ready.  

The food was amazing; fresh and flavorful.  What I always have to order when I go to Domo is the Spicy Hulk roll - spicy tuna & avocado, tobiko wrapped in a cucumber sheet with lemon ponzu.  It is perfection.  

I love the food, and I love the experience of eating at an unassuming restaurant; Domo is a real find.
author: Sandy K.

description:
Japanese owned and run but a dissappointment.  So I went for lunch and had some nigiri and a few apps.  The fish taco was a spectacular rendition of a Mexican dish. I thought the seared fish tasted a bit like propane but other than that it was perfect.  The nigiri was another story.  I would expect better from a Japanese run place.  The maguro was ok at best, the other fish were small and the rice seemed lacking sake. 

I would say this place is great for a lunch date or for "hip" people. For sushi nazis, this place passes the bar for ambience but falls flat on its face for sushi.

Zannen!!
author: Spanky M.

description:
Domo is just fine. I'm not terribly excited, but at the same time I'm not going to turn away running. We came in on a weekday during lunch, so it may have been a rough time to try them out.

Domo is a good sushi lunch spot. I like the neighborhood and the location is just out of the way that not everyone is going to flock there... but they do. The restaurant was full at lunch, so I guess I should recommend either getting there early, late, or actually making a reservation. My only criticisms is that their outdoor seatings is a breezy spot in the shade, so I was left wishing they would run the food to the sunny cafe across the street.

We had the inari, miso soup, wakame salad, and an open faced dragon roll. All of which was good. Not great and absolutely fabulous that you should kill to have it again. It was good. I'd say that Domo would be my casual lunch sushi place because it does good, presentable sushi without looking like a dirty chain or being overly priced. This is a place that I could make a comfortable neighborhood place to go. A casual lunch. I'm satisfied and will come back.
author: Jay V.

description:
Domo is our local sushi joint. Every time we come here we get our favorite seats at the window facing Moby Tobi's. There's something really magical about these seats - you get that moment of "wow, I live in an amazing city" sense. Really quite the treat. 

Of the near dozen times we've been to this spot, we've only been somewhat disappointed maybe two times. I don't believe their rolls are spectacular (I'd give those about 3 stars) but their fish quality is unbelievable and a really great value. 

Their Spicy Tuna Handrolls make other establishments cry, they're so good. They pack this roll with plenty of delicious tuna and many fresh greens, including some daikon, mint, avocado and cucumber. 

Try their Hamachi sashimi. They generally give you about five pieces and their cuts are generous. 

Their Firecracker Balls are pretty tasty and crowd favorite. 

Cheers!
author: Liliana A.

description:
Cute little place...and I mean little, this place is tiny. It can be very romantic as you snuggle up at the counter but when it is full it is loud and cramped. 
The lighting is lovely, the view onto Laguna street from the counter is very cute...you almost forget you are in Hayes valley, flanked on all sides by ghetto. Oh yeah I hate Hayes valley.  I did not hate Domo however. I actually really really like this place.

We tried:

tuna poki - a creative version of poki with octopus which was very very delicious.
Fish tacos - SOOOOOOOO good. the best thing I ate there.
Sweet Potato roll - ok.
Mac Daddy - delicious.
Sweet Mamma - delicious.
Hamachi / Jalapeno roll - great.

The service was great, we were full and happy ad paid out about $100 for the two of us.  Admittedly this was a bit overpriced especially considering that the seating was not very comfortable and the fish was good but not "knock your shoes off memorable"...I may be back but probably not soon (Hayes Valley issues). 
Still, I would give 4 stars to Domo.
author: Nilu r.

description:
I am officially a regular and I have not been disappointed yet.
The ahi nigiri is off the charts, so is the salmon nigiri.
I love the fact that you can get traditional sushi, or a crazy yummy crunchy roll.  It is my neighborhood staple. I LOVES me some Domo
author: Amanda F.

description:
I like that place.  Kinda hole-in-the-wall but great neighborhood gem.  Sitting at the bar is great.  Cozy and nice and most important the great quality of food.

Rio is the main sushi chef and he rock!!
author: Alex R.

description:
So perhaps the sushi is not the most authentic - in fact, I'm pretty sure its not.
However, if you're a vegetarian and NOT a pescatarian...its terrific. Not as bland as most other vegetarian sushi options...where it seems like the vegetarian options were not at all thought-out and just added to the menu as a courtesy. No, here the vegetarian options are as pretty and flavorful as I suspect the seafood options are (well, I can see that both are pretty, I meant that I am sure the seafood options are flavorful :)  
The veggie roll, with asparagus and shittake tempura(s), fresh avocado, shiso, and pea sprouts is always good. The shittake rolls are a good value and very nice - the shittake is tempured here too. 
The interior is small, cozy, dimly-light...I think they're going for cross between traditional sushi place in Japan and hipster-modern in SF. Its pleasant, but because of the size and lack of seating, the wait can be long.
author: Joyti J.

description:
Just wanted to start by saying that I don't like sushi, but being that most of my friends do, I will go along for the company and I can always find something on the menu that I am happy with. That being said, I was kind of disappointed by how limited the menu was. The fried California rolls were really good, but there wasn't much else for me to order (besides sake). 
As far as the restaurant itself, I really liked the look and ambiance of the place, very small with slightly dim lighting. Came here on a Friday night with two other people and were seated right away. Service was good and we didn't have to wait too long for our food.
author: Christina D.

description:
place is pretty average. however, given the area I can see it being rated higher because there are many other sushi places around. there are tons of other good restaurants in the area tho

I generally get combination plates of sashimi/nigiri and I don't think they had them here. we go spicy hulk and fire cracker. both pretty normal. we also decided to try the crudos. ankimo and uni- both interesting. i would say fairly pricey so probably pick a fish that you like.

small and quaint place. i got lucky and didn't have to wait but i heard there is generally a wait. 

good for catching up with friends. prob not a good date spot unless you want people next to you hearing your convos.
author: Janet Y.

description: Creative menu, attentive service, and of course, great sushi!  Sat outside on a nice evening and enjoyed a long meal.  Arrived right around 530pm and the place was empty but by 6-630, every seat was taken.  Will definitely return for dinner again.
author: Allison P.

description:
