Despite the Postal Service playing, I still took a seat at the bar for my first sushi experience in Hayes Valley.

For my solo dance I chose seaweed salad (obv), one Yelp recommendation (firecracker balls) and the jalapeño hamachi. Of the three, I'd give the seaweed salad a high-five, firecracker balls a meh, and the jalapeño hamachi roll a fist bump. Throughout dinner, I found myself admiring the rolls and bites being prepared by the duel chefs and concluded that I ordered wrong.

The service was swift, ambiance swell, and the music got better over time. I'll return often and venture deeper into the persuasive menu.
author: David A.

description:
We had been eyeing Domo for months after moving to Hayes Valley and finally paid a visit when seeing that the usual crowd on the sidewalk was gone.  

Apparently, hosting is not the specialty of Domo and they insist on sitting every party over two people at the one table in the small restaurant.  We watched helplessly as several parties of two were sat at the bar and no urgency was on us taking bar seats.

After a long wait we finally sat at the one table.  The experience greatly improved as the food was delicious albeit overpriced.  We started with edamame which needed more salt, and then moved on to the Spicy Hulk, Fire Cracker Balls, and Domo specialty rolls.  The Spicy Hulk was the winner for uniqueness and freshness.  Still a little hungry -  three guys eating here - we had a rock and roll to close out the meal and wash it all down with some Sapporos and sake.  Each roll was fresh and nicely presented.

Overall, the place is somewhat pricey and needs to work on preparing itself for larger parties if it wants my business again.
author: Chad S.

description: Sushi place with bar-stool seating only. Nothing on their menu particularly stood out for me although everything was decently good.
author: Thomas C.

description: Domo is great if you just want a few rolls in a semi-hip environment. It's functional but not mind blowing. The sushi rolls are somewhat inventive - the drink menu is actually pretty impressive. If you want to just chill out and have a nice sushi dinner, then Domo will do.
author: Nancy L.

description: Delicious sushi in a cozy atmosphere.  They don't take reservations but the wait isn't too bad.  We waited about 30 minutes at Noir Lounge nearby.  The space here is small, so not advised for groups larger than four (2 is recommended).  The quality of the fish here is great and they have interesting sushi roll options.  One recommendation is to try the Firecracker Balls---crusted, fried balls of crab---delicious!
author: Tanichka B.

description:
4 stars for the experience, 3 stars for my opinion of the food (my bf would disagree and say 4 stars though).

We got lucky and came at the right time on a Wednesday night so we didn't have to wait for a seat.  The place is small but not claustrophobic.  I liked the lighting and the vibe, and it was fun watching the sushi chefs at work.

Had very nice maguro sashimi, good seaweed salad, ok fiesta roll (tuna w/ salsa and mango), and an ok to disappointing seared kobe beef roll.  Veggie croquette was tasty (duh! fried goodness), but my FAVORITE part of the meal was the ice cream!  Black sesame and green tea ice cream :) Loved that the green tea ice cream wasn't too intensely flavored, and the sesame was sweet and unique.
author: Priscilla T.

description:
Got take out here-small place and I mean really small-take out took 20 min
not bad at all. 
Their sushi is small and a bit pricey. id eat there again only bc my friends live on the same block and they have a cute bar style eating area facing the street. very cute location and restaurant.
I had the sexy mama-dynamite roll, fire cracker balls were decent and tasty
the miso is ok ive had better
sea weed salad you cant go wrong with that.

very fresh sushi
author: farah b.

description:
It was about 7:30 pm on a Friday night, we were off attempting to go eat at Suppenkuche without a reservation. Oh hey, only a 1.5 hour wait! I think not... I was pretty hungry already. So we walked down the street and found ourselves at Domo (which also had a slight wait but not too bad). We didn't mind sitting outside so that sped up the process. About 15 minutes later we were seated.

The menu was filled with delicious rolls that I didn't know what to get. We started off with some edamame (perfectly salted!) and genmaicha  (green tea w/roasted brown rice). We decided to go with: Spider roll (finally one sized just right to fit in your mouth), Domo, Red dragon roll, and Firecracker balls! All of which was delicious and probably one of the better sushi places I've ever been to. 

The service was prompt and they did a good job keeping my yummy genmaicha refilled. I'm definitely a BIG fan and craving to go back.
author: Shali N.

description:
Domo, Domo...what happened?

I revisited you this week...and I was perplexed with the dissatisfied feeling of the meal I had.  

The rainbow roll was just meh- average...it didnt taste as fresh as it usually does. I dont know if it was because we were one of the first patrons and the speculation of getting served yesterday's left over fish is a possibility.

The spider roll was good. However, after trying out multiple sushi joints with exceptional prices and quality..., I find the price can seem a bit steep for this roll- since it has only 4 pieces to it.. However, I do realize the geographical disposition you are in... and therefore I wont blame you...it is SF. 

The cruncy spicy tuna roll that I most look forward to? It was like eating fried batter drenched in cream sauce.  Someone in the kitchen definitely has a heavy hand on saucing. 

The service here is average. For some odd reason- the server kept serving our food between love and I. When there was plenty of space to serve it from either side.  Which most restaurants tend to do.  So each time he presented a plate, a cup, our bill to us, we would have to scooch to the side. It just felt awkward and weird. 

In conclusion, Im still going to give you 4 stars because overall, I really do like you Domo.  And I have hope that our next date will be better.  But I have to say... last night was a definite 3.  Don't call me, I'll call you...when I'm ready.
author: J C.

description:
LOVE the food here!
they always have fresh fish, including salmon belly, toro, butterfish! can't get enough :)
You MUST try the salmon belly appetizer. Their kobe beef roll is very unusual mix of flavors - don't think everyone will love it.
Also recommend walu (butter fish) and scallop - very fresh and tender
author: I B.

description:
Sitting at the sushi bar is always fun. It's fun to watch the chef make your order, and hand it over the bar to you. It was particularly interesting to watch the chef use the hand torch to cook meat.

Spicy crunchy tuna roll was sublime, and the rainbow roll was excellent. I could have taken or left the carpaccio. The kobe beef sushi was novel - good, but seems somewhat gimmicky.

A little bit on the expensive side - the specialty rolls seemed small for the price (usually I would expect 8 - 10 pieces rather than 6 for a roll in the $10+ range).

The place was small - would probably be busy on a prime night. You don't want to bring more than about two or three people.
author: Dana L.

description:
We decided on Domo over Serpentine and boy was I happy! I love it when going to sushi surprises and delights.

At first I was kind of shocked at how small it was but was glad we were the first ones there. Small places are fun as long as you're not the one waiting for days.

Here is what we ordered:
+ Rolls: Crispy spicy tuna, Fiesta, Spicy Hulk, Jalepeño Hamachi
+ Nigiri: Shiro Maguro, Maguro and Blue Fin

My friend was raving about the crisply spicy tuna roll but for me, the Spicy Hulk takes the cake. I love anything tuna and avocado so I was immediately interested. When it arrived, it caught my eye. It was so elegantly wrapped in a handmade cucumber shell. It's the perfect meal...healthy, tasty and refreshing! Go Spicy Hulk!

Looking forward to going back again soon.
author: Karlyn N.

description:
Very small but intimate space.  Either a seat by the window to people watch or a sushi bar seat are both great..   Firecracker roll is as good as advertised.  We also had a basic tuna roll that was extremely fresh.  

Service was quick and efficient. 

Our drawback would be price.  You pay a little bit more than a comparable sushi place.   However, we would definitely come back.
author: David L.

description:
Nothing says "I like you" on a first date than exclusivity. In a restaurant the size of most people's studio apartments with seating for about 15 patrons, you don't get more imposed exclusivity than that. It melts hearts, I tell you! And Domo definitely is a great first date dinner for a more adventurous couple of first daters. 

I stand by my 4-stars. My date and I found the portions of the dishes adequate for sharing (as most sushi over the one-roll limit is). The wakame/seaweed salad was moist and the right amount of sesame seeds. The Spider roll was just this side of crunchy with the required bits of crab leg sticking out (I'm not a fan; it's not a tempura shrimp roll, mkay?). The Kobe beef roll was great in theory, but I found the beef to be a little too chewy. The sauce was stunning, however.

It's good to see a Japanese restaurant whose sushi DOES come with a measured serving of eel sauce (the sweet black sauce, for those not in the know). It's a secret weapon that I use for all my sushi requests that brings out flavor in the most interesting ways.

I'm also a HUGE fan of the FIrecracker balls. They are unusual enough to warrant their own review. Tasty, meaty, moderately heavy on the hot/spicy.

In sum, one doesn't come to Domo for an ultra-mod, stylish ambiance or sultry people-watching. One comes for oishi (yummy) sushi, no-frills service, and the satisfaction of being in a restaurant before the dinner crush and not having to wait over an hour to be seated. :)
author: C. P.

description:
My favorite sushi spot in the city!!! The place is tiny and parking is a little hard to find, but Domo's like a jewel box!!! I've had sushi all over the bay from traditional to innovative, and Domo definitely high up there on the innovative side =)

If you want good sushi, you need fresh ingredients, especially fish, and Domo's definitely got that down. A lot of "trying to be innovative" sushi joints I've been to that has 100's of rolls on their menu tend to use too much mayo and sriracha and whatever sauce to cover-up their cheap, not so fresh, low quality fish. But all the sashimi I tasted here were so fresh it's comparable or even better than those high-end Japanese places like Sakae and Sushi Tomi people rave about...  The uni was so sweet and the toro melted in my mouth... everything was just so fresh! 

If you like rolls, try their Domo roll or Hulk roll... Albacore tataki was also very tasty, tuna tartar was delicious, and their hamachi kama was so good I wanted to order one all for myself. 

They also have a great selection of sake and very friendly waiters and sushi chefs =) I'll definitely be back here over and over!
author: tiannaaah J.

description: Very small place, perfect for 2 people - order the Fish Tacos and the Domo Roll!
author: Sara B.

description: Let's make it clear, terrible customer experience! Totally ignored when we were waiting for a table. If the host/waitress doesn't want to deal with people, they would do better by shutting down their business-
author: D T.

description:
I'll admit it. Our first choice for dinner was not Domo. We were originally going to dine at Suppenkuche but the wait was an hour so we started meandering around to find something else. 

Domo has virtually no seating inside so I was shocked that we were able to get the ONE table that they had in the corner (there were four of us).  Everything is bar seating so this is NOT a good spot for large parties. 

The sweet potato roll was awesome. It was fried and all creamy inside. It was pretty amazing how satisfied I was with some potatoes and rice.
author: Julia N.

description: Easily my favorite sushi joint in town. The fish tacos and uni are amazing the fish is fresh and their service is top notch!
author: Alvin C.

description:
Last night was the second time I've been to Domo. We arrived around 9:30pm and it was packed. This was after attempting to try Sushi Zone (probably smaller and even more packed)... Let's all bear in mind, this was a Tuesday night at 9:30pm... why are all the sushi places in Hayes Valley so small? why are they so full on weekdays? I just don't get it!

The sushi was actually not as good as I remembered it. Also, we got the Mac Daddy roll and it had some funky green stuff on it... which lingered... despite our best efforts to scrape it off. The california roll was delicious, fresh and probably the best thing we ordered. 

Price wise and selection wise, not the best. I think I'd rather go to Otoro... it's bigger and I think the food is better.
author: Abbey S.

description:
. 

I really enjoyed Domo! It's a cute little hole in the wall place that serves as a great replacement to my old haunt Red Box Sushi. After learning that Red Box has since been closed, I searched on Yelp for a new place to visit. I found Domo and took Genevieve Y.'s suggestion to give it a try. I'm so glad I did!

The fish was really fresh and though the rolls were not college-style huge, they tasted clean, and really did fill our appetites. We ordered three different rolls (red dragon, firecracker balls, and domo), two orders of ikura and one order of tobiko. The tobiko and ikura didn't taste like they were previously frozen; and the rolls were all accented with delicious sauces. All this delicious food for $68. Depending on your sushi experiences (Todai or Ozumo) that might seem really expensive or cheap, but this cute little restaurant is worth a trip!
author: Angela L.

description: Two words: firecracker balls! Best item on the menu and great portion size. I've been here twice and the sushi is always delightful and they have some really interesting items on the daily special list. The only downside is the small restaurant space. Make sure to get there early if you want a seat.
author: Amelia S.

description:
I loved it!
I brought my sister here and met my bf at the place. He had recommended it.  It was a Thursday afternoon, it was quiet and we were seated right away.  
The service was great, by the end of the meal we all had been chatting with the cook and server about the business.
Now, we eat a lot of sushi, and really enjoy it;
This sushi was fresh, delicious, and they had great rolls to choose from. 
We had yellow tail nigiri (so fresh and light) and a variety of fired, baked, and torched rolls.
All of them were delicious.
The restaurant isn't big enough to accommodate large groups of people, but this is definitely a place you should be checking out on the regular if you live her in the city.
I couldn't believe we hadn't gone here before!!!!
Domo, we will be back.
A lot.
author: Deb B.

description:
Small and intimate, Domo squeezes up modern sushi enthusiasts to fit their capacity of 20 people (the most). Very creative menu, crafty sushi masters, colorful dishes.

To go for: Spicy Hulk, Firecracker Balls, Fish Tacos, Sweet potato maki.
Specials are written on their only mirrored wall, also worth checking it out. 

I don't think they take reservations, but if you have to wait, be patient. This place is worth waiting for. Fish is always fresh, service is nothing to complain about, and overall atmosphere is great!
author: Rika P.

description: Extremely popular place and I really wish I can try to give this a more fair review. Unfortunately, my companion spent half an hour looking for parking and they will not even consider seating me even after I explained that i drove almost an hour to here and we are just looking for parking. So, I watched the restaurant get full and people who came after me take the last few seats at 5:38pm, 8 minutes after it opens. We ultimately still did not find parking, so I had to leave. Looks like this place might be catered towards local residents. It's nearly impossible to find any parking spot, or maybe that's just the San Francisco neighborhood.
author: Wendy C.

description:
Surprisingly good. We had quite a spread of sushi rolls and sashimi and everything was quite delectable. 

Thanks Albert for bringing us here and introducing us to some delicious sushi!

Good deal!
author: Art A.

description:
Tiny and unassuming, you would have no idea that this little sushi restaurant is SUCH a delight! I am indebted to my friend for introducing me to his little neighborhood sushi joint.

A tiny restaurant with an inventive menu - you can try everything from their specials (which are comically impossible to read on the mirror they write on) to their firecracker balls which I think is the absolute HIGHLIGHT of the menu. I don't know what it is but it melts in your mouth and is just so amazing!!

The traditional sashimi and sushi items are delicious and the fish definitely high-quality but you should really try some of the more unusual items that they have the menu!

The restaurant is tiny but on a weeknight around dinner with a party of 3, we probably only waited about 10 minutes. The waitstaff are courteous and efficient and everything from the food to the atmosphere is enjoyable about this restaurant.

Worth leaving your neighborhood for? Absolutely!
author: Liz S.

description: Rudest service I have ever experienced. After being seated, we waited for service for over 10 minutes. They never brought all out food, I had to ask them 3 times to bring me a rice bowl. They then messed the check up. When I complained about the service, they were extremely rude and shrugged it off. The only reason I am giving it 2 stars was because the food was very good.
author: Daniel S.

description:
Sushi is probably my favorite food. I could honestly eat it for every meal, or just all the time without even stopping. But then I'd be broke. It doesn't help that Domo is literally three blocks from my apartment.

I dropped by here with a friend the other night since we've been trying out a lot of the places in Hayes Valley we've never been to. Figured that (A) they have a lot of good reviews, and (B) their menu isn't insanely expensive like some places (i.e. Blue Fin). Both points are pretty spot on.

Be warned, Domo is a sushi BAR, not a restaurant; there's enough seating for maybe 15-20 people at most, making it a pretty tight squeeze if you're looking to bring friends. The atmosphere is both modern and intimate, so it'd make a nice little dinner-date location if anything. My friend and I arrived a little after they opened for dinner (5:30P) and by the time we left (6:20P) the place was already filling up.

Food-wise the sushi is incredibly flavorful and fresh. The two of us split a few special rolls (Spicy Hulk, Firecracker Balls) and I had tried some nigiri (albacore, hamachi), and all of it was good. The portions felt a bit small for the cost though, so don't expect to be stuffed unless you're prepared to pay a pretty penny. Still, the quality is of a much higher caliber than many other sushi places I've been to. Domo also has lunch specials, which I'm eager to try.

Overall, Domo is a pleasant, quaint little sushi bar that deserves the (current) 4-star rating on Yelp. There aren't many negatives to it other than its size (but come on, you can't entirely fault them for that) and perhaps the price-to-portion ratio, and it's worth repeated trips especially if you live in the area. Just... try to come early, otherwise you might be waiting for awhile.
author: Will C.

description:
Okay, I'll give you the bottom line first, because let's face it, we're all looking for shortcuts.  I'm a student, I know.

***Bottom line: I started the evening in a suck-ass mood, seriously wanting to shoot myself...and ended the evening *happily* eating monkfish liver for the first time.***

That's it.  You don't have to read any further, because it'll just get more boring, and I've had a run of long reviews lately.  But if you insist....

----------------------------------------------------------------------
Yesterday was my last day of rotation #9 (yay, me) and my most annoying Caucasian brother (his words, not mine) was in town.  Because I did not have any more assignments to do, nor did I have to wake up this morning at the butt crack of dawn, I wholeheartedly and enthusiastically agreed to meet him in the city for dinner.  However, this involved getting to the city from Napa at rush hour - I kept hitting stupid traffic...bay bridge traffic started way back in El Cerrito...and then again at the Octavia St exit.  And then when I *finally* made it to Hayes Valley, there was no parking AND stupid-ass drivers kept blocking the roads.  To top it all off, I had drunk a gallon of coffee at work, and didn't pee before I left Napa.  This equaled a miserable Kerrie L.

After I *finally* found parking, my friend, his friend, and I went into Domo...where a table for three was miraculously waiting for us.  (I made a bee-line for the bathroom, which was nice, by the way.)  So...apparently, we're all pretty loquacious, which meant we weren't in a big hurry to look at the menu.  We pretty much made our decisions while the server was there, taking a little more of their time than they had wanted, I'm sure.  So - their patience was a high point.

When I finally got around to looking at the menu, my first thought was, "JIVE ASS."  Firecracker Balls, Spicy Hulk, Sexy Mama???  What would Nobu think? :(  I told my companions that I could go for anything...anything except uni and monkfish liver.  Because...well...EW.

But as the night went on, and I drank more sake, I learned to accept the jive ass...even encouraging another order of the Fish Tacos.  Everything was fresh, flavors were strong, and of course, the presentation was very nice.  Finally, one of us dropped out and said he was done, but being the troopers we were, the "bro" and I decided to go for one last dish.  And because I was in such a great mood, I agreed to try an order of UNI and MONKFISH LIVER (you pick two items from the "small crudos" section of the menu).  I did it, I loved it, and now you can't say I'm not adventurous.

Such a perfect way to start my 2-MONTH vacation. :D
author: Kerrie L.

description:
My number 1 sushi spot to go to in the Bay Area.  Reasonably priced and good quality fish.

Best thing about this place is the chill and relaxed vibe and the head chef/manager Ryo.  I've become a regular here and he definitely knows his fish and his technique is impeccable.  Sit at the bar, order from him and he'll take care of you.

For me a sign of a good chef is one that's constantly tasting his food, making sure that it's up to his standards of taste and quality.  I've had the pleasure of sitting in front of the sushi bar and watching Ryo break down the complicated structure of a flying fish, all the while tasting different cuts and making sure they were excellent. Over the next few weeks he refined his marinade and cure for his flying fish to the point that he really brought out its beautiful flavors without sacrificing the fish's great texture.

It's a common misconception that sushi is the freshest fish available when in fact most sushi is aged, marinated, or cured for a few days before serving.  There in lies some of the art to great sushi, and at Domo, Ryo knows how to treat the fish he gets.  I'm a sushi purist.  Give me your nigiri, give me your sashimi.  I don't really care for sushi rolls but I've had them and they don't disappoint either.  Before Domo I used to HATE mackerel.  At other sushi places, the fishiness of mackerel would be overpowering.  At Domo, Ryo prepares his mackerel carefully and in small batches and the outcome is a fresh fish taste and texture.  I love the mackerel at Domo, and I believe that he elevates all of the other fish he receives to a higher degree than most other sushi spots at the same price point.  Along those same lines, a sign of a really good chef is consistency. If I like a restaurant, I'll always return a few times, and when it comes to sushi I'll invariably have bad visits - times when I'll find a bone in my sushi or the fish won't be up to par.  This hasn't been the case at Domo.  I've been several times and it's always been wonderful.

My faves on the menu:
Fish Tacos - Love the tempura fried nori.  I always ask him to go light on the salsa.

Sea urchin crudo - He pairs his urchin with avocado, and it reinforces the butteryness of the urchin while mellowing out the oceany flavor.

Ankimo (monk fish liver) crudo - a simple presentation and take on ankimo and it's really good.

Sake toro (salmon belly)
Sunazuri (hamachi belly)
Ryo has a great way of balancing out the fattyness of these cuts with something bright and refreshing be it a thin, thin slice of kumquat or some pickled ginger.

And again, ask him for what he's got and what's "fresh" Ryo is great at showcasing some of his fresh batches and what's in season.  Some of my faves off-menu have been:

Flying fish - great texture and mild flavor
Half Beak - a firmer, smoother texture than most fish but delicious
Walu (butterfish) - cured well with an almost sweet/buttery flavor
Black Snapper
Red Snapper

Come to Domo, sit at the bar, order sushi, and enjoy - rinse, wash and repeat.  You won't be disappointed.
author: Rodney A.

description:
I really like this place. Its cute, fast, delicious and reasonable. Its not 5 stars because nothing is out of the park, but I would definitely rate it consistently high in all regards.

A few highlights - 
- They have great specials that change all the time, which means a lot of new things on the menu every time I go.
- The lunch special is a great deal.
- When my girlfriend was sick and wanted Miso soup, they filled a huge tupperware for me to take home for next to nothing.
author: Gregory P.

description: Before I went to Domo, I "kinda liked" sushi.  It wasn't my goto food.  I stumbled onto Domo, while wandering around Hayes Valley.  CHANGED MY LIFE!  Their rolls are AMAZING!  The Crunchy California is Phenomenal.  The sushi and sushimi are so fresh and tasty.  The warm saki selection will warm your tummy.  I can't recommend this place enough.  The place is small, so get their right when they open, or be prepared to wait a while.  But it's worth the wait.  Everytime we have peeps in from out of town, this is a must eat.  We even had guests that wanted to eat there BOTH nights they were in town to visit.  I used to "like" sushi, but thanks to DOMO, I FRIKIN LOVE SUSHI!
author: Merrick S.

description: One of my fave sushi spots in the city! Firecracker balls are so good!
author: Marwa A.

description:
Whenever I would think about going out for sushi, I used to get hot and clammy and be that flakey friend that said they had things to do but secretly stayed in eating my Special K sat on the couch. I'd think about a friend who showed me this grotesque picture of a man and tapeworms from her desk while she was plowing down shrimp tempura rolls.  

I refused the flavorful treat that is sushi for so long, no thanks to my Hamachi loving friend and her crappy google find. After a huge drunken debate and careful consideration, I relapsed off of the non-sushi wagon.

I was meeting up with Queenie C. for a foodie night out and we ventured over to Domo to give it a whirl. We sipped our tea and started catching up but got sidetracked by the sexy music playing. Sexy Sushi, yes please.

The inside is intimate and the seats look close together but your personal bubble is big enough to accomodate. The service is quick and swift and if you're lucky to sit away from the main window you'll have a front line view of the chefs working their magic and are not afraid of taking part of photo ops. My favorite roll we ordered was the Sexy Mama. The smallest touch of lemon made that roll sexy with scrumptious desire.

Lovely spot but I know to get here earlier than the later crowd since there could be a little wait.
author: Morgan M.

description:
YUMMM! Just thinking about this place makes me hungry! I love everything about Domo, from it's decor to the food. I've rarely had to wait very long but I usually only come with one other person. There is no room in here for a large group. The prices seem fair compared to other places in the city. 

I always get the sweet potato roll and the firecracker balls. The Spicy Hulk is probably the my all time favorite. I could eat a whole order by myself!!
author: Angel P.

description:
I decided to order an early take out dinner from Domo a couple weeks ago and judging on food alone this place was great.

I ended up getting a Rainbow roll (A+ that they use real crab) and the Kobe Beef roll (I almost never eat red meat but this looked too good to not try).  Both special rolls were very good especially the Kobe Beef which was a meal itself.

The only thing was how uncomfortable it was inside Domo that day, very hot (they did have the door open) but still I would of been very uncomfortable if I stayed and ate at the bar.

Will be going back for that Kobe beef  roll in the near future!
author: Mitch M.

description:
Absolutely loved this place. I cannot believe that I had never been here earlier. If you are looking for authentic Japanese dining (with a strong emphasis on sashimi related food) - you cant go wrong here. Sushi chefs are awesome and friendly. 

By far one of the top places to goto in SF for Japanese

Disclaimer: the venue is very small so be prepared to wait
author: Charles C.

description:
This place is completely out of f*cking control! 

It's so amazing I don't even know what to say........ 
Five star flavor on demand!
author: Calvin W.

description: Sitting here right now writing the review so I don't forget! This place is delicious, quick, and friendly, and I highly recommend it to anyone needing any kind of sushi fix. Today, I just happened to be craving veggies, so both my rolls were meatless, and the sushi chef was kind enough to ask me mid-prep if the sauce they use was ok because it's not vegetarian; so kind! I eat meat, but those who don't can be confident here that nothing is going to slip by. Love it!
author: Shelby W.

description:
I have and will eat at Domo again and again and again. 

I have taken countless visiting friends here and they have all just loved it. 

My first time was shortly after I moved here three years ago. Domo is really the sushi place which saved sushi for me, taught me what it was about and showed me the error of my previous non-sushi eating ways. 

Thank you guys! always worth it.
author: Jason L.

description:
We didn't even know this tiny little gem existed until we tried to have dinner past 10 PM in Hayes Valley. Sushi spot next to Patxi's, closed at 10, Patxi's closed at 10:30 and we walked in at 10:32, Flipper's Burgers closed at 10. It was one of those nights, until we walked a few blocks up the street and found Domo. It was about 10:40 and we could tell they all wanted to close up shop and go home (or to the bar more likely for some beverages and fun) but they were really cool about it. We sat down, ordered quickly and the food came out really fast. Miso soup was very tasty, sea weed salad was fresh and also very good. Then we started to get to the meat and potatoes, or freshly sliced fish and rice in this case. The Hamachi carpaccio was pretty good. It could have been seared less b/c it was a little more cooked than I liked, but hey, might plate was clean so who I am to nit pick we had another roll (forget the name) that was very fresh and really clean. And the academy award goes to..... FIRE CRACKER BALLS!! Let me tell you, we had no idea that this was the best dish in the house and somehow we managed to save it for the finale and hot damn it was so good!!!! A slightly crunchy texture, very fresh tuna and the unagi sauce was money MONEY!!!!! 

Not only was the food good but they stay open til 11 and didn't have a problem serving us just before closing, which really made our night b/c we were starving!! Borderline diamond in the rough.
author: Hector G.

description:
Really cute, pretty little sushi bar, but really expensive! Who charges $14 for a roll of rice, a tiny bit of fish smothered in sauce? Sadly, every place in SF, and I will gladly pay for it, which is why that now that I'm a resident of Hayes Valley and a pescatarian, I'll be hitting up this place probably more often than my wallet would like.

Came here with the boyfriend after we moved in my stuff to my new house. I'd heard about this place and we couldn't find it until we Yelped, and then had to wait about 10 minutes for a spot at the bar. There was one lone 3-person round table that apparently couldn't be occupied for whatever reason as they were seating all patrons at the bar. 

The sushi came out at a reasonable time. I like how our waiter brought our Asahi right away and poured it out into two cups for us. We ordered a spider roll and a spicy CA roll and a sweet potato roll. The sweet potato roll was nothing to write home about, and I liked bf's CA roll better than the spider roll I ordered. Super tasty, nom nom. I like!
author: Cheryl F.

description:
A shockingly good, intimate restaurant in the din of Hayes Valley that makes me hesitant to write a review at all for fear that word will get out.

The fish here is really fresh, and is what I would call novelty sushi. I tried a lot of things here I wouldn't normally find at other sushi places, but the menu would probably elicit a big WTF from a japanese person if they saw some of the menu items (is hamachi plus jalapenos a faux pas? so delicious!).

- Sweet potato maki (MUST GET)
- Shiitake mushroom maki (MUST GET)
- Hamachi and jalapeno (yes, spicy sushi!)
- Firecracker balls
- Salmon Nigiri
- california roll
- black sesame ice cream (I love this, and order it wherever I see it -- which isn't very often)
author: Jenny S.

description: Domo: I liked you. You're small - so only dinner for 2 please. The rainbow roll was the standout, but we had a lot, including carpaccio, spicy crunchy tuna roll, sake nigiri, and the kobe beef. I affirmatively did not like the fiesta roll.  Pico de gallo on sushi turns my stomach. With that said, all the fish was fresh and delicious! The service was bleh - I didn't feel at all valued. It was a little on the pricey side, but that wouldn't prevent my return. I think I'd choose Otoro down the street though.
author: Andrew K.

description: If you're not hungry and don't care about price, this is the place to go. But the portions are oh SOOOOO small. The fireballs are to die for, they are m&m's sized goodness! Yeah m&m sized, seriously disappointing because they were so delish. Very very small place! Better hope it's not busy when you go. But I give it 3 stars because it was some of the best sushi I have ever had, but the portions were the smallest that I have ever had in my life...
author: Danielle H.

description:
I've been wanting a chance to fairly update my review for a while and a dinner date with the bf last weekend presented the perfect opportunity.

Domo is teeny tiny but as they say, good things come in small packages. A good trick to avoid waiting for 30minutes is to call as you're heading out and ask for your name to be put on the list; it's not a reservation but they will gladly do it and by the time you arrive, you only have a few minutes to wait. This time, we were seated upon arrival.

The food is fantastic, as I've said. This time we had the Kobe beef roll, the IC, and Domo, the Shiitake (only place that does this really well) and soup and edamame. The IC was a special roll and I believe last time we ordered a special too, so I would suggest checking out the list on the mirror. The Domo roll is hot and sooooooo yummy. It's like melt-in-your-mouth goodness. The Kobe also had great flavor and I've definitely never seen beef in a sushi roll but it was wonderful. 

I mean seriously, this place is really really good. I would recommend it to anyone looking for a date spot or dinner with a friend. The seating makes it difficult for any more than 2 people really, but the bar style does provide for a sense of intimacy that works like magic for a romantic date.
author: Emilia S.

description: This is our new sushi place! My fiancee and I came across this gem while walking in our neighborhood. We got there early so they place was almost all ours. We sat at the bar and spoke with the very friendly sushi chef (who I think may be the owner?). I ordered the california roll and the crunchy spicy tuna roll. My man ordered a tuna roll and the crunchy cali roll. All very good but I think Ill stick with just the plain rolls. Their fish is so fresh I don't think I need any mayo, tempura or fancy sauces. Their miso was also delish and came out nice and hot (hate lukewarm miso). This place will definitely see our faces often :)
author: Bri R.

description:
It's those random nights when you're a little buzzed and really hungry that you'll stumble upon a gem. After starting the night off with drinks at the Sugar Lounge, skipping the Ramen truck, and getting shut out at Suppenküche because of the crowds, we found Domo. We had to wait 20 to 30 minutes just to get seated, but the time went by fast since they allowed us to order beer and sake while we waited outside.

It's a quaint little place that probably seats about 20 people at the most. The food here is excellent. They had some unique sushi rolls and they tasted pretty good. My favorite part about our meal was the hamachi kama I ordered. It was delicious, and I can't remember if I've even been to a place where it was that good.

It's one of my favorite new spots.
author: Jeffrey J.

description:
This restaurant is pretty cool. At night, they have tealight candles and it makes the place very intimate. Anyway, this place gets really packed. Luckily, we got seated right away. We ordered a vegetable tempura sushi, which was warm and delicious and also a spicy sushi (I forgot the name). We also ordered some hot tea and beer. All of the dishes were yummy :)

The waiter was a busy bee so he was kinda slow. Food was a little pricey. I would love to come back here again for dinner cus it's awesome!
author: Angel S.

description:
Delicious and fresh. The two most important things about sushi. 

I loved the fun rolls...esp the spicy hulk and crispy california roll. 

Get here early...no reservations, and the locals know what is good.
author: Misha F.

description: My favorite sushi restaurant in San Francisco. I love their rolls, especially the Spicy Tuna, the Fiesta, and the Hulk! The service is very friendly. The only thing I don't like is the fishy smell you get on your clothes. But now I dine on an outdoor table! Problem solved!
author: Emilie P.

description:
Let me tell you, I was skeptical.

Right off the bat, we ordered a large hot sake and there was a small dead spider in one of the cups. But they were so nice about it and gave us an extra free large sake.

A friend took us here, telling us its his favorite sushi spot. I already have my favorite down (Koo) but Domo made quite an impression!

The ambiance is extremely intimate - not great for any group with more than 3 people. Besides, the restaurant itself is super small.

We ordered:
- crudos: uni x ankimo - uni sashimi & ankimo, each on a single spoon. Simple and delicious. We had 2 pairs of this :)
- 2 amaebi: the fried heads were very lightly, LIGHTLY fried. Still very good but I wish they fried it more!
- 2 uni
- 1 sake
- spicy hulk: SO GOOD!! Pretty small "roll" but each bite was super tangy and spicy. Loved the ponzu sauce mix!
- domo roll: satisfying! when you're craving something filling, this hits the spot.
- spider roll: meh, it was okay.
- large, hot sake

Yes, the portions are pretty small.
Yes, the owner's Chinese.
Yes, it's priced a little exorbitantly (due to its location).
Yes, there was a small dead spider in one of our sake cups, but they handled it quite well and we could have probably gotten it comped.

This place was really cute, and the food was pretty good - rolls and sushi. Everything tasted refreshing and delicious, except the spider roll (my bf orders that, not me!) and that other spider, but all in all, I really liked Domo.

The ambiance was perfect (so intimate!) and the food wasn't bad either -- highly recommend the spicy hulk! Prices to portions, it's not the best but hey, what sushi place is cheap!!?
author: T L.

description:
The various rolls that I had were all amazing with great flavor. The presenation of each dish was a work of art. The service was good and although the place is small, the ambience was nice. I will definately have to come back and try the other items, especially the special deals.

My recommendations are the domo roll, sexy mama, and fire cracker ball. The small crudos are awesome too!
author: Jeanne L.

description:
i order take out regularly on the way home from work, so it irritates me greatly that they don't take pickup orders on the weekend.  that annoyance= minus one star.  

otherwise, i think domo is much better than a neighborhood sushi joint.  their fish is consistently fresh, and they have interesting rolls, which i enjoy as part of my sushi dinners.  my orders have been packed with 95% accuracy, and i order 2-4 times a month so i can safely say that the fish is consistently fresh.
author: eshwar k.

description:
First...I can't help but sing..."domo arigato Mr. Roboto..." Umm...anyway.

We stayed in Hayes Valley for a while (1.5 months), and this restaurant is right across from Momi Tobi's, so we meant to try it.  We finally did the other night. 

I read a couple of quick tips, and saw the firecracker balls were good.  I read the description, and because it contained tuna (mine and a hundred other people's favorite...), I was in.  Firecracker balls are bite-sized pieces of goodness.  Spicy, and the flavors mix perfectly.  Unfortunately, I don't have the menu in front of me, so I can't say exactly what was in them.  

Jack tried a roll with shrimp--the Red Dragon.  That was also really good, just not as well mixed as the firecrackers.  

And, don't hate on Hayes Valley people.  It's a really cute place, with all kinds of good food, people, and shops.  Shame on you, other yelper(s)!
author: cyndi t.

description:
VERY good. We were looking for a new place to get sushi and followed a suggestion of a friend to come here. We were very happy. it is super cozy and the decor is subtle enough for a date/romantic dinner out. 

Great for 1, 2 or 3 people but there is only one small table for four. 

We didn't wait at all and were seated within 5 minutes of arriving. It was Sunday night so I have no idea if other nights are busier.  Seems like that could be an issue given the size. There are so many places to get a drink or walk around so get your name on the list at the door. 

Everything we ordered was excellent and all of the comments about the firecracker balls are true. they are so good and unique. Also like the standby California type of roll and the ICE roll.  The sushi is creative, but not contrived and the ingredients are fresh. The counters, the sushi case and the bathrooms were all super clean. 

It was all good. We also got rock star parking in front.  Go! This is not your average sushi!
author: Amanda J.

description:
I went here last Saturday on a date with my honey.
The sushi was spectacular!  Very fresh and they are really creative with the ingredients and presentation.
We ordered the Domo Roll and the Crunchy Spicy Tuna... both were baked and super yummy.  A little on the heavy side (since they're covered in mayonnaise based sauces) so I would recommend balancing with a normal roll...
Good beer selection too!  Not just Sapporo and Asahi but a couple others I hadn't tried before.
Only downside is the place is tiny so I'm sure there is quite a wait sometimes.
author: Alisa M.

description:
Definitely not the best sushi I have had.  We went for lunch on our last day in the city and were incredibly underwhelmed. 

I ordered a roll with a spicy mayo sauce but it was saturated.  To the point that I had to not eat the top portions to avoid it.  

Definitely not the best sushi restaurant I have been to.
author: Kate M.

description: whenever the BF and i are in the city ,we always make sure to stop by for some sushi here. It is the best , the rolls are amazing as well as the service !
author: Mel L.

description:
Mmmmm....yummy.

Consistently good, fresh, friendly...a bit small in seating capacity, so don't all rush over there at once.

Nigiri and sashimi - always yum.
Crudos - little bit sized morsels - also yum (scallops are my favorite)
Selection of rolls gives a good variety with some new things you don't see at every sushi place.
Sake selection is very good - oh heaven...
author: M B.

description: Living in the area and having been a loyal customer for the past 2 1/2 years, I was really disappointed by my last two experiences here. Last night my date and I arrived around 8:00 at the restaurant, put our name on the sign-in sheet, and proceeded to wait for our table. After a while I noticed that the round table in the corner was set but had been unoccupied for a good 10-15 minutes. I went in and asked how much longer the wait would be (we were the next on the list). The waitress looked around and said it could be up to 20 more minutes. When I asked about the table in the corner she told us that they would only seat a group of 3 there. When I asked if a group of 3 was waiting or if they were expecting anyone, her response was "no, but you never know." Now, there were several groups of two waiting, and at this point we had been waiting for nearly an hour. So if a group of 3 happened to show up, they get to basically skip the line and get seated right away? This doesn't make much sense to me and really pissed me off as a loyal, paying customer. In the end we did get sat (only once a group of two vacated seats at the bar) and enjoyed the food, but the waiting experience really ruined it for me. Bottom line - if you have customers waiting - seat them. If a group of three happens to come along they can wait their turn like the rest of us. In the end, we were there til almost closing and a group of 3 never showed up. So no extra revenue for them, and they are now losing a loyal customer.
author: Dan S.

description:
Returned almost a year later to the day, relieved to see they're open and seem to be doing well.

Got a seat at the bar and ordered what I recalled were my favourites: firecracker balls and the crunchy california roll.  In hindsight, just order one of those.  The combination of flavours is similar enough and the deep-fry became a little overwhelming.  Regardless, both are still delicious.

Also ordered the Spicy Hulk and enjoyed it.  But it's not going to prompt a craving for me.

Tried the unfiltered saki.  Guess I'm just not much of a saki person.

Not cheap, but still recommended.  Enjoy!
author: Littlefish B.

description: The food is fantastic and amazing value.  It takes a while to get seated -- often between 45 minutes to an hour (two people), longer I expect if you are a party of three or four. (There are no reservations, just turn up and add your name to the list). Well worth the wait though!  If you are trying to decide between Otoro and Domo go for Domo on the quality of food, Otoro if you want to reserve a table and take a little more time over your meal.
author: Rebecca N.

description:
Small and unassuming, Domo turns out average sushi. In a town saturated with sushi joints, I feel you have to do something pretty special to warrant a grand review. 

I liked the selection of small crudos. You can choose any two for $6 and they are similar to an amuse bouche of fishy goodness. The salmon with caper, onion avocado and olive oil was a great combo of flavors as was the uni with avocado, wasabi, soy and sea salt. 

The rolls were the usual you would find at a lot of places and nothing over the top with the nigiri selection.
author: Lee H.

description:
Great sushi at a pretty good price. It's very small inside so don't arrive with a big group, but definitely a place I will continue to go to.

After trying other sushi restaurants, I have to upgrade my rating to 5 stars. The sushi here is clearly fresh and doesn't have the "fishy" taste. The rolls are creative but not over the top.
author: Ryann M.

description: Some friends came in from out of town and they demanded sushi. I'd heard rumors from several friends about the lack of decent sushi in SF, even in areas like J-town. Domo is pretty close to where I live, so we settled on going there. It's pretty tiny and therefore not many people can eat there, but we were there around 9:30 so we got a table for four right away. This sushi was so. good. The Domo roll was just...it was amazing. I've had a lot of sushi in my days, and this place is right up there with the best of them. It's since become one of my/my boyfriend's go-to take out places. Oh man, I want it now. This is why I don't do reviews often, I just get hungry and want to eat at every good place I've ever been simultaneously.
author: Amy S.

description: Great service here. The uni shot on the spoon was bombbbb... all the sushi is really good. price is very decent too.
author: Cindy L.

description: If there's raw fish, it's masked with lemon. The wait might be a while, but they have a list, and your number can left so you can wander in the meantime. A few touches better than typical sushi restaurant fare overall.
author: Kyle S.

description:
Domo was good. The place is very small. We were lucky to get two seats along the window but would have waited a while if those weren't free when we arrived. There is only one table, so this is not a place where you can easily eat and look at your dinner partner. 

The sushi is good. We ordered the Domo (because you have to order the roll they name after themselves) and the fire cracker balls. Both were good and a bit indulgent. 

The reason for the three stars is that we left smelling horribly. There must be bad ventilation in the restaurant because we wreaked of oil and "kitchen" smell -- even the next morning I think I still smell. Eww.

I recommend coming here for takeout, but I won't got back and eat in the restaurant.
author: T G.

description: The only great place to have real Japanese sushi besides Ariake, which is amazing, but is Korean owned.
author: Claudia O.

description:
Chose Domo to avoid a long wait at Sebo.  Generally, Domo is ok if you're hungry, craving sushi, and you're not trying to impress that new date you met on Match.  This place is more fitting for married couples or relationships where making an impression is no longer a goal.  

But back to the food.  We ordered

-Firecracker: Good if you think Chipotle is authentic Mexican food and Sarah Palin would make a fine President. 
-Chef's Choice Sashimi (Albacore, Maguro, Sake): All pretty good except that the Albacore was fishy. Points off for that. 
-Uni: Decent. 
-Toro: Decent but I've had better. 
-Bonus points for serving dark Japanese beer.  I've only seen this at another Japanese spot in Berkeley and it's a nice addition to the usual trifecta offering of Sapporo, Kirin, and Asahi.
author: Vina H.

description:
Love this place!  But, please don't go - I don't want to have to wait in any longer of a line to eat here!!  The fish is super fresh and they have innovative creations if you're a little more adventurous.  LOVE the fish 'tacos' and hamachi carpaccio.  Prices are very reasonable for SF.  Parking is hellish but that's just good ol' SF.  

This is a small place with only one small bar height table that would seat 3 comfortably.  Otherwise, it's just a U-shaped bar that runs the perimeter of the small restaurant.  A keeper in my book!!
author: Consumer X.

description: Domo - another overrated sushi restaurant in San Francisco. Small menu, small portions, big prices and the desire to be 'unique.'  It is by no means bad sushi - quite fresh - but I just wasn't that impressed with it. Our server was nice, but forgot part of our order and then took forever to give us our check but he was on the floor alone so I understand how he can get side-tracked with the needy douche bags that come here. Unfortunately I probably won't go back - sorry Domo I wanted to like you but my taste buds yearned for more.
author: S. M.

description:
It is a solid sushi joint.  I would come here again, just not anytime soon given the plethora of sushi options in the city that I would like to try first.  

Bf got a $60 omakaze which was fresh, delicious and creative.  Def got $60 or more worth of deliciousness.

I got their fire cracker balls and domo roll, which were good, but a little overdone in terms of sauce and such for me.  I prefer the more simple maki sushi.

When I come back, I'll be ordering the omakaze.  Skip the overly ornate maki sushi and order the more simple things in life.
author: Kristine B.

description:
Oh, gosh, was Domo delicious. One of my favorite things about San Francisco is the prevalence of sushi bars- little restaurants that seat maybe twenty people with one or two waitstaff that serve everyone. I can imagine that it'd be crowded on busier nights, but we had no problem finding seats as soon as we got there.

Highlights:
-Sweet potato (or Idaho) maki is generally a big indicator for me of how much I'll like a sushi place. It was definitely in my top five, which is a pretty impressive feat.
-The firecracker balls and california rolls were really good too- the ingredients felt fresh, and a lot of the rolls were eight pieces instead of six (which made us more easily parted with our cash that night).
author: Zach Y.

description: Pricey and crowded. Good though
author: Michael E.

description:
This review is for lunch only

I wasn't that impressed with my lunch experience, given the rave reviews.  We shared an ebi shrimp roll which tasted just fine, but was nothing out of the ordinary.  Shrimp that was batter fried with some avocado, rolled with sushi rice and dotted with teriyaki sauce.  Nothing to call home about.  I ordered the sashimi salad lunch special, and since it was technically a salad, they didn't bother to bring out a side salad to accompany my meal, which my friend commented on.  While the few sashimi pieces looked to be good quality and tasted fresh, the salad was unimpressive.  A small heap of square cut green lettuce with a smattering of seaweed, topped with a gingery-soy sauce and carrot salad dressing.  It was refreshing and light, but I've thrown together a better sashimi salad at home.  If I check it out again, I'll clearly have to order something else.

Other than that, the service was nice and friendly, and it gave me an opportunity to stroll around in Hayes Valley which I don't often do.
author: Janet L.

description: Walked in early on a Saturday around 5:30.  Amazing weather so asked to sit outside.  Server asked if we could sit inside since he was the only server at the moment.  Having spent a decade working in restaurants, I'm usually very easy going about such things.  We told him not to worry at all about us, take his time since we were in no rush, but that we really wanted to enjoy the weather outside.  I was given a cold look and handed the menus as he turned around and walked away.  AWFUL.  Left the menus and walked out the door for another restaurant.
author: Justin R.

description: A small little sushi bar in my favorite neighborhood Hayes. Is perfect for a relaxing dinner a weeknight. Has some fun and simple rolls, like my favorite salmon, avocado and lemon. The lemon really adds a fun twist to it! It is small and has nice staff. With a perfect sized bottle of unfiltered sake it can't go wrong.
author: Linn L.

description:
Given the many sushi choices that this city provides, sushi is a difficult battle to settle. I am a quick walk from Japantown, which would assumedly have the best sushi I've encountered, but instead it was nestled in Hayes Valley. With wide windows and meager space, Sushi Domo proves that minimal Japanese food can be done inexpensively and tastefully.

Had the $12 lunch special, totally delicious! Chicken karaage, California roll, and a salad, staples taken to the next level.
author: Peter H.

description:
Lunch at Domo is a very pleasant.  The fish is fresh, the ambiance is nice  and it's wonderful to be in Hayes Valley.  The Chirashi is bountiful and presented beautifully.  I love it that we live so close by to such a find.

But I must warn you, don't EVER order take out.  It's a supreme ripoff and everything good about Domo goes out the door.  The portions are noticeably smaller and the prices are somehow higher and they don't apologize about it.  If you have to order Japanese takeout let me recommend Mikado in Potrero Hill.  I think they deliver also.
author: Maria L.

description: Oh man, this place is absolutely incredible. It's small, so either come early or plan on waiting for a spot. But it is worth the wait. Every time I come here, I leave completely amazed at how good their sushi is. Seriously. Go here.
author: Kate H.

description:
A and I headed to Domo for my 2nd birthday dinner.  He wanted to make sure I had sushi for my birthday because I love sushi.  We found parking in Hayes Valley so he let me choose between Sebo and Domo.  He'd just been to Sebo the week before and neither of us have ever been to Domo, so I decided to go here.

It was totally empty when we got there a little before 7pm, but it filled up pretty quickly.  Although that's not really hard to do because it's tiny.  Very small seating capacity.  

I don't remember exactly what we ordered.  I know we ordered the Firecracker Balls.  They're so wrong because it's so not sushi, but they were so good!!!  We also ordered the Spicy Hulk roll, which was actually quite good and I'm not into spicy stuff.  I think we also had some kind of Dragon roll.  I can't remember.  Oh, and the chef's choice sashimi platter.  Anyway, everything we ordered was really good.  

I'd go back just for the Firecracker Balls.
author: Kris L.

description:
Do you ever walk by something so many times that you kind of forget it's even there? I've had this phenomenon happen with work deadlines, boyfriends and laundry, but this time, wow, there is a sushi place here? Sweet.

After being turned away from Absinthe due to lights out and "oh yeah, duh, they are closed on Monday," we decided to try Suppenküche. Then after being seated at a table right by the cold drafty door and factoring in the fact that it was way too crowded to even hear ourselves guzzle beer or slurp egg noodles, we decided to give Domo a long overdue go. 

We were seated facing out the window immediately and with the rainy night, it made for some fun people watching. Since we had been drinking wine for a couple hours prior, we decided to stick with that and ordered the only red they had, a Pinot Noir, and I can say with a large amount of certainty that, yikes, it wasn't very good.

We then moved onto the fishies and tried the hamachi belly, the scallops and the seared albacore. All were totally tasty and definitely melt on the tongue succulent. We also tried the firecracker balls and they were good, but not great. They weren't very spicy at all and since I've only ever had them before at Red Box Sushi in the Loin, I would say they weren't as good as RBS. 

Overall, it was a decent little snack and affordable. The service was quick and efficient and I would pop in there again if I was in the neighborhood. Would I rush to it? Nah, I'd sooner hit Sushi Zone on Market or Warakabune on Church
author: Stephy S.

description: We moved to SF in Jan.11, and have been trying every restaurant we can, but no Sushi has compared to DOMO! Tell me a place, I will try it and then I always run back to DOMO!  They are so friendly & accommodating with a 4yr old. The only downside, it is very small and I don't like eating at the counter. So, they need to get heat lamps for outside, because there are 3 tables and we don't mind eating out there. And yes, portions are small, but do we really need to over eat? I am craving some DOMO NOW!  Enjoy!
author: Kristie H.

description:
I so very much enjoyed my meal at Domo last night. And the gallon of sake we drank. And the Sapporo. But not so much the hangover this morning...

This place is tiny. It really doesn't suit large parties of people. Four of us showed up and we had a seriously long wait to get a seat along the wall (when I say along the wall, thats really the only option bar one table in the corner). Seeing as the couple occupying our space were on the way to an adventure of the horizontal sorts, it took some time to get us seated. On the upside however, the waiter was clearly embarrassed to have us waiting on the side. I like it when I see that people really care about me and my feelings. 

So once we were seated, we got to the menu. We ordered (along with a nice ginjo): 

salmon and spicy tuna crudos - tuna - very spicy. Its the first time my food has been served in a soup spoon... and I feel like I have gone up the world
firecracker balls - delicious and worth every rave review
sexy mama - I love any roll that uses lemon. This one did not see me wrong
dragon - its a dragon roll. You can't go wrong really. 
jalapeno hamachi - 3/4 members of the party gagged on the power of the chilli. I, however thought that the flavour of the hamachi and the jalapeno worked really well together. For me, a win! And I got the last one as a result :)
fiesta (special) - this was delicious. Mango, shrimp, roe... and other stuff. It is a party in your mouth. 
wasabi peas - enough wasabi for flavour, but it wasn't overpowering
edamame - good edamame. Nice edamame. Still crunchy and flavourful

All in all, there wasn't a single part of the meal that I didn't enjoy and for that I have to give it the full five. It was definitely well worth the wait. I just wish it was a little bit larger. There is outdoor seating, which can work for larger groups but when its windy and SF is still recovering from Winter, it's not so appropriate sans outdoor heaters.
author: Catriona C.

description:
This is amazingly delicious sushi. Melt in your mouth good. Everything is really fresh and they have some interesting roll selections too, all wonderful.

Place is tiny, so be prepared to wait a long time for a table if you come with a group. 

Worth every penny.
author: Roxane W.

description:
Good things in this establishment. Me and my flower-backed associate ate raw fish here. The fishes were good. Here are the fishes we ate.

Yellowtail - Delicious
Albacore - Pretty Good
Crunchy California Roll - Delicious 
Kobe Beef Roll - not that good. I don't think the asparagus worked well with the rest of the stuff. It did, however, make my pee smell like asparagus. (*asparapiss?)
We also consumed Ed Money (aka Edamame) - Cold but still good. They are served cold, I don't think it was a mistake. We ate some other shit too but I forgot what it was. Also, Olie Flowers ate Sea Urchin like a dumbface. I bet it tasted like the ocean. 

I would eat here if I were you.
author: N S.

description:
SOOO YUMMIE!!! I had the fire cracker balls -to die for and trust me I like some good balls in my mouth but these were exceptional! 

Only lost a star because of the size, very intimate good for a date or small party (3 or less). Lovely relaxing atmosphere and good music. 

Service was wonderful. We had the only table in the place and they didn't rush us at all, even when another party of 4 came through the door. 

And the prices were very fair - $9 for the fire cracker balls (again so good) and $4 for the sweet potato roll (also delic). I would def go there again!
author: Ka C.

description:
More negatives than positives for Domo ...

We sat at the bar and watched the chef in action. I'd have to say that he was very chintzy on the portions. The uni nigiri we ordered was unfortunately the worst I've ever had. I saw him spoon up the liquid scraps of sea urchin, place it into the small seaweed opening, and called it done. For $6.95, I could have bought a whole super burrito. Come on ... give us a real piece of uni!!! The albacore tuna nigiri was also dollhouse size, miniature (looking at the posted images ... our portions were no where near what is shown).

To add, it was pathetic how they, a Japanese restaurant, could run out of hot sake. Before our eyes, the waitress tipped the cardboard box sideways and squeezed out the last sake droplets. 

A positive was the restaurant's simple format allowing for a warm, and cozy ambiance. Although, I'm on the fence with liking the bar stool seating, and literally being elbow to elbow with other patrons. Another positive was the Spicy Hulk roll - very nicely done, great, refreshing texture and flavor.
author: Kimbalee W.

description:
I've been coming here for lunch on a Friday afternoon for a couple of weeks now and am very favourably impressed. 

The lunch deal is amazing value, with a good order of sushi for $12 and $5 big bottles of Sapporo. The saba is also excellent and service is polite and fast. 

If I was coming in the evening I'd get there early because it's a small bar, with around 15 seats inside in a bar format and a couple of tables outside. But it is worth it - this place cares about its sushi and it shows.
author: Iain T.

description:
A great spot for a quick dinner, but don't bother if you have more than 2 or 3 people.  There are maybe... 12 seats in the place, and all of them are bar seating.

Ease into eating with a crudo, served on one of those flat plastic "asian noodle" spoons.  The uni crudo, garnished with avocado, hit the spot.

Try the hulk roll.  It's wrapped in cucumber, instead of rice.  It just feels healthy eating it.
author: Jay M.

description:
Kua and the guys at Domo take already great food and make it fun, and isn't that the point of eating out?  

I really can't say enough about this place.  Seriously.  The food is ridiculously tasty, well-proportioned, reasonably priced and created by guys who put everything they've got into everything their knife touches.  You can see AND taste it.  

My fave is the "uni-in-a-spoon".  Of course that's not what they call it but after eating about a thousand of them I think I'm entitled to a little poetic license.  (Disclaimer:  Don't eat the spoon.)

They serve nice big chunks of sashimi and you can taste the quality; two things that are unfortunately scarce at other snobby or cheap restaurants. 

The relatively new outdoor sidewalk seating makes a warm evening in SF just about as good as anything can get and the staff is.... awesome.  I've been there on super packed nights and they still treat you like the place is empty and you've got all the time in the world to ask questions about the menu to find the perfect thing.  

One thing I'm a fan of is just asking them to surprise me.  When you see Kua behind the bar bust out a torch and a grin you know you're in for a treat.  

I seriously can't say enough about this place.
author: Ted T.

description: Domo is an interesting beast. They have a tiny one-page menu that has a few crudos and roll combinations, and while the sashimi plate I ordered was absolutely delicious with lovely cuts of fish, I was disappointed that I wouldn't get to have the fish in simpler permutations. No hand rolls, for example. That, and the bill was pricey for what we had. I'll go back if I need a Hayes Valley sushi fix, but for the most bang for your buck walk a few more blocks over to Lower Haight and hit up Sushi Raw.
author: Lisa P.

description:
Domo is one of the cutest little sushi restaurants out there. I think it seats about 15 people total, and it's always packed with my hayes valley brethren, watching passers by from their big windows overlooking Laguna. It's just made for intimate conversation between friends or lovers.

The sushi itself was great, but not superior. I'm a big hunks-o-raw-fish sushi kind of gal, so of course my favorite is always the sashimi. We ordered the sampler to get a little taste of everything. They didn't have butterfish, but the albacore was absolutely melt in your mouth orgasmic heaven.

I was excited to see they had crudo on the menu, but to my disappointment, the fish was mashed into a spoon and not altogether innovative in its preparation. I much prefer crudo served as fresh sashimi, and I think they could get a little more creative with their flavor combos.

We also ordered the fire cracker balls that are so popular on Yelp, and while I normally don't like my sushi fried, these were an exception since the spicy tuna came through with a fun crunch and the plate was presented beautifully.

Oh, did I mention I came here AFTER consuming 12 dozen wings at the Yelp all-you-can-eat night at Double Decker? That's how I roll.
author: Nicole G.

description:
I originally had plans to go to Sobu, but after reading some reviews on Yelp which mentioned Domo, I decided to check this place out instead. The place is very small, but you don't feel cramped. We got there at 7 on a weeknight and there was already a waitlist, but the server came out while we were waiting outside and offered to take a drink order which made the wait go by a little bit faster. We ended up being seated at the bar, and I swear that the sushi chef has got to be the fastest, most efficient chef I have ever seen. He never even broke a sweat and the food came out quickly which was great because we were starving! The staff was super friendly, and I really liked the lighting there which was not too bright. 

We order the firecracker balls, which were tasty, but I really enjoyed the nigiri sushi. Everything we ordered tasted really fresh.  The entire dining experience was very pleasant and cozy. I am looking forward to coming back here.
author: Jade L.

description:
One of the best sushi places I've been to. The sushi was fun, tasty, and surprising. The fire cracker balls were very good. Actually, all of the rolls we had were delicious. I think there was a sexy mamma roll on there, too. Hard to choose a favorite. Can't wait to go back!

The restaurant is small. I wonder if they could fit more than 10 people in at a time. But totally worth trying.
author: Heidi L.

description: Great sushi but rude service, try any of the sashimi and the firecracker roll
author: J F.

description: Monday night around 7 and it wasn't too crowded.  Got an Orion (actually imported from Japan, unlike Sapporo which is from Canada), Rock N Roll, Fire Cracker Balls, and some salmon/avo/lemon rolls.  All were done well, and I thought price was fair.  Firecracker thing was good, but definitely pushing the notion of sushi.  You basically can't tell any fish is inside.  Bathroom was very clean and had good quality paper towels and a nice sink.
author: Marc S.

description: Just moved to Hayes Valley and this was the first restaurant I tried. I love love LOVE the sushi here! Get the firecracker balls, they are amazing!!
author: Erika S.

description: I liked everything that I ordered! SF has a lot of mediocre sushi joints, but this place is definitely getting added to one of my go-to spots for my sushi cravings. Everything was fresh and tasty! You can't go wrong. Can't wait to go back and try more!
author: Nadiyah S.

description:
I can't believe I've lived in Hayes Valley for 6 months, right down the street from Domo, and it took my friend from Italy to show me this place. I'm downright disappointed in myself!

My favorites are: domo roll, the spicy hulk, fish tacos, and this yummy potato appetizer-y thing (but I don't know what the name of it is).

I've only eaten here on two occasions, both at lunch time. All the other times I've gotten takeout. 

My staff is super friendly and attentive. The only two concerns are that the place is very small, so not the best place to go if you want to have a meal where you can talk (it's only side-by-side seating), and definitely not for a group of more than 2 people. Also, the sushi is a little pricy (I think it's 13 bucks for the domo), so I don't get to come here as often as I would like, but I think the prices are a little pricier than other places because the fish they use is very fresh.
author: Radha S.

description:
This is the best sushi experience I have had to date.

I used to live a block away, and for some ridiculous reason never tried it, but I'm so glad I made it finally. It's small, and doesn't take reservations and you definitely have to wait awhile to be seated. But you can drink outside and think about all the delicious sushi you're about to consume.

The people were also so friendly and fun! We sat at the sushi bar and Rio, the sushi chef, was super engaging and fun, not to mention a sushi ninja/artist. He drank sake with us, and a merry time was had by all. He also gave us the spiciest sauce ever, upon our request - which was made of a mix of sriracha and ghost pepper (literally the hottest pepper known to mankind). Not everyday that someone responds so accurately to a request for hot sauce that is actually spicy.

We went all out - here are some of the highlights, all of which was accompanied by cold sake and Sapporo:

-Sashimi - sake, butterfly fish, hamachi, and one other special
-FISH TACOS. These were innovative and shockingly good. Albacore and salmon sashimi on tempura fried nori, with some other delicious ingredients and sauces.
-Firecracker balls. It's debatable whether these are actually "sushi", but they're delicious so who cares?
-Hamachi carpaccio
-Some special roll Rio conjured up for us - it had salmon on the outside. Not sure it's on the menu.

Will definitely be back! Many a time!
author: Lina L.

description:
Sushi places are a dime a dozen in SF but it's always great to find a good one that's also fun and close to home.

Domo is a tiny little place situated on Hayes and Laguna, across from the hipster-esque Momi Toby's Revolution Cafe & Art Bar and by tiny I mean TEENSY!  If you don't want to wait I would suggest getting there right when they open.  As a party of three, we arrived around 7:30 pm and had to wait an hour.  It seats maybe 20 people but probably less.  However, if you're in the area it's definitely worth it.  

A particularly delicious dish was the Firecracker Balls...essentially spicy tuna sushi fried balls.  Just the right amount of spiciness.  For those who know me, I also judge sushi places by their seaweed salad...it makes no sense I know, yet I do because it's one of my favorite things in the world!  Theirs was excellent.  

The service was expedient and good and the only reason I'm not giving it 5 stars is because of the wait and the tight seating.  I think people would enjoy their experience more if they took one or two seats out of the bar facing the window, but then I suppose that means a longer wait.  Overall though I think it's a great little joint for a great little area!
author: Melanie N.

description: Went here last week on a vacation trip to San Francisco and it was yummy.  FISH TACOS is all I have to say.  I must warn you if you like "sushi" and are strictly roll type person, this may not be the place for you.  Don't get me wrong, their rolls are great but the rest of the menu kicks butt because I didn't stop eating.  Then I finished it off with mochi ice cream!  The staff is really nice as well so that's always a plus!
author: Katie G.

description:
FIRE CRACKER BALLS. Think about the goodness that those three little words could implicate and throw that into delicious sushi popcorn bites. YUUUUM! They're not tiny, but their small enough where you don't have to look like a hamster while munching on them. And, don't worry - you get more than 6 pieces. The presentation and sauce are perfection on a platter. This is the only thing I had cuz my friends only wanted 1 roll to themselves, and I didn't wanna seem like a fatty and order more, but I'd DEFINITELY come back to try the others rolls. 

1 less star for the following reasons: 

The place is small - all seating is bar-style, so don't come w/ a large group. Parking looks like a nightmare - but we walked over from our office. What we ended up shelling out was a bit more than I care to spend for lunch, but it was a special occasion. 

The staff seemed cool... quiet. One of them referred us to the Mediterranean corner market down the street for some delicious ice cream for dessert.  All in all, good experience, and I'm definitely coming back for 2nds... 3rds... you get the picture.
author: Courtney C.

description:
Everything was veeeeery tasty. 
I had the himachi jalapeno roll, very good.
Also had the firecracker balls, and some fish taco's for apps.  Fantastic.
My lady had the sushimi platter.  The butterfish is especially fantastic.
All in all, there was a decent wait, kinda spendy, but the flavor is great, and they have giant beers for consumption while you wait.
Definitely worth a look.
author: N O.

description:
The layout here is very strange. If all the seats were packed, the people in the corners would be sitting on top of each other or would be stuck in their chairs unable to move. No bathroom break for you! I know, they're just trying to make the most out of the space. Luckily, when we arrived on a Sunday evening for dinner, it wasn't too packed, and the people on the same corner were on their way out.

We shared the: 
Kobe Beef + Asparagus Tataki
Firecracker Balls: Like a fried spicy tuna roll, but in ball form

He ordered the: 
Nigiri: Toro [fatty tuna], Sunazuri [Hamachi belly], Hotate [scallop]

I ordered the:
Sashimi Combo: Hamachi [yellow tail], Sake [salmon], Maguro [tuna], Albacore

The fish was fresh and tasty. My friend only had good things to say about the nigiri he ordered. He was treating me to a belated birthday dinner, but both of us left ready for a second meal. Perhaps we should have ordered a bowl of rice on the side. Or maybe we are just pigs. 

It's just okay unless you plan on getting some jive ass rolls [http://www.yelp.com/biz/jive-ass-roll-san-francisco].
author: Tinna H.

description:
by far, our fav sushi joint!!  seriously, we get the same order every time, it is that good!  

ok, let's get to the goods... highlights:  

fish taco (don't think baja) it's a delicious square of nori tempura fried with fresh nigiri and homemade pepper salsa. dude, i don't know what's up with that combo, but it is amazing!!!  

sexy mama - OH the holy grail of rolls for me.  i'm particular with rolls, the whole too much rice, shove anything in there, i mean cream cheese people?... but this one is a culinary masterpiece, the flavors all compliment, the crunch of the asparagus, fresh fish, and viola that lil' slice of lemon is heaven.  seriously, it is one of my all time favorites.  

spicy hulk - love it! no carb, a la no rice, but wrapped in crunchy cucumber (they use to slice it thinner, which we liked, but it's still good) and the spicy tuna, total staple, but the "juice" it's in is so yummy.  my man loves to use the leftover juice to add to the shoyu for further dipping.  so good. 

jalapeno hamachi - jalapeno more for the crunch, not really for the heat and fresh hamachi, simple, but delicious! 

sake - oh man, i can't think of the name of our usual, but it's katanaba (yikes) or something like that, but my all time favorite sake, reasonable price and a good time.  ;) 

beer - orion, always!
