note:  we explored a couple of times in the beginning with some of the other items, def not worth veering from our usual.  didn't care at all for the "baked/warm" rolls.  

enjoy, cheers, kumpai!
author: J P.

description: Had dinner with friends here last night before going to the ballet (which was terrific - Copelia).  Everything was great: the rolls, the sashimi, service was fine.  It was a comfortable spot and didn't seem too expensive for sushi.
author: Kevin M.

description:
Firecracker balls continue to deliver.  The crunchy spicy tuna roll was also noteworthy and large (a good value).  The tasmanian trout was awesome.  It looked like salmon but was more flavorful and less fishy.  

I wish they had more than 1 sake available for less than $40/bottle.
author: Aaron T.

description:
Usually packed little spot- great sushi, cool atmosphere.  Pretty much all bar seating, good for people watching.  Not a good place to go with a group of people- or a romantic first date.  

The hamachi with jalapeno is divine.  My (real crab) California roll was delicious.  The kobe beef wrapped around asparagus and avocado simply melts in your mouth.  

Service was good, I had a great experience here.
author: Sarah F.

description:
First off, beware of the parking situation, in this area, it sucks.  After 25 minutes of driving around, I kid you not!, I valeted at the restaurant on the corner of the block.  

This is a small place so it packs in fast.  I think there was only one tall round table for maybe 4.  The rest is counter space and the counter/bar type space lined up against the wall/window.  I think the place maybe fits 15 people tops.  But that's okay because we came right at 6pm and beat the rush.  

The rolls are creative and the little bites (in spoons no less) are seafood themed and creative and yummy.  I don't even remember what I had but it was good.  Firecracker balls were spicy but not overly which is good for me.  And the fried CA roll was a nice twist, not the first time I'd seen it but it was yummy nevertheless.

Service is good, and people watching from the window always makes good dinner conversation.
author: Denise B.

description: Domo is a nice little find in the Hayes Valley where you wouldn't expect a good Japanese restaurant to be. Domo's food is so unique and artistic that it is an experience to remember. From freshness to flavor, texture, creativity, everything about their dishes are really executed well. Each plate I tried did not disappoint. The only thing I could possibly complain about are the portions which are on the tapas / smaller end. The place is very small so seating is hard to get especially in prime time.
author: Ed L.

description:
What a pleasant surprise! My S.O. and I planned to attend a party in Hayes Valley last night, and I asked a friend for places to eat dinner before the party in the neighborhood. She recommended Domo b/c her husband had eaten there before. Sold! This was the perfect spot for my "congratulations-on-finally-getting-a-job-as-a-librarian" dinner with my S.O.

We arrived at 7:30 PM, put our names down, and only had to wait about 15 min. And those 15 min. passed quickly thanks to the cold unfiltered sake that we shared while waiting.

We were seated in the corner along the window, which was a great experience. I don't know about you, but it's rare that my S.O. and I sit next to each other while dining, unless we're eating on the couch and watching TV together. I would definitely recommend Domo for couples and not larger dinner parties, as it would be difficult for more people to talk at the counter together. There is only one round table in the corner, and all of the other seats are along counters or the sushi bar.

Here's what we ate:
- edamame
- salmon nigiri
- hamachi nigiri
- ikura nigiri
- sweet potato roll
- rock & roll
- spicy tuna
- and a small bottle of inexpensive cold sweet unfiltered sake

All I can say is Wow. The fish melted in our mouths. My S.O. usually measures sushi restaurants by the quality of their ikura, and so we've sampled it at a lot of different places. The ikura here was by far the best I've ever had. Clearly fresh, it lacked the fishy taste that we've experienced at other restaurants. I measure sushi restaurants by their spicy tuna, and while the taste wasn't exactly the same as my favorite place in Boston, Domo's was good in its own right. Fresh fish, spicy!, and crispy cucumber all did a little dance in my mouth. Best of all, we we were both surprised that the total bill wasn't more expensive. No, please don't raise your prices or shrink your portions!

I wish I could give Domo 4.5 stars. It doesn't earn a complete 5 because it took about 10 minutes for our server to take our order. Also, it took us about 35 minutes to find parking, but I guess that's expected on a Saturday night in Hayes Valley, so I don't really fault Domo for that.

We'll definitely be back for an intimate evening at Domo. There's a lot of charm and delicious food packed into a small space.
author: Wendy K.

description:
This is one of THE best sushi I have tasted in San Francisco.. hands down. Too good since they are a block from my apartment. Too bad, they opened right before I moved to New York.. nevertheless, I had 3 glorious back to back occasions of eating here before I left.

The ambiance is great - it's small, but packed. Great deep house music on the set. If you are by yourself, try one of the seats facing the sushi bar : the owner will chat up with you. If you are in a drama mood or with some chick - take the Laguna facing seat. The windows are large and look right towards Moby Toby. The food is excellent - the toro will melt in your mouth.. the miso is tasty and the rolls are not just great, but extremely fresh and filling. The rainbow roll had 8 peices.. all fresh. Prices are quite economical. If you were looking for a sushi place in Hayes Valley and Sebo didn't cut it -- you are in luck with Domo.
author: Sav B.

description: Pretty good. Tasty but I've never had the fish chopped finely and put into rolls, is this a real style or a way to get rid of fish that doesn't look nice? Good miso. Good pairings of veggies I've not had with the fish before. Messy presentation of inside out rolls.
author: Caro H.

description:
Ok let me set the scene, the main squeeze and I are sitting in a bar post Tropic Thunder enjoying a beer. The bartender hears us discussing the different dinner options in the Hayes Valley vicinity and downloads a 20 minute diatribe on how AMAZING Sebo is and how we HAVE to go there NOW and enjoy the Sunday small plates, blah blah blah.  So SO and I get all excited and race home and run over to SEBO and guess what, it's closed!  Yayyy for private events, yayyyyyy!  

So now we have no choice, I mean we're on a sushi mission and if we don't eat it we will just DIE.  We hop on over to Domo and grab two seats at the bar.  We are excited to nosh at this place cause every other time we'd walked by the lines had been out the door and it has been crammed full of people. 

We started out with the seaweed salad, very yummy!  The really big surprise, however, was the two crudos for $5.95.  I got the uni and the scallop, they both come sitting in their own spoon. with tasty accoutrements, WOOOWWWEEEZOOOWEEEE.  Seriously good people, wow. 

We followed these tasty treats off with a spicy tuna roll and a spider roll.  My spider roll was still warm from the sprimp being fried and the uni was magnificent.  Seriously, I'm leaning towards five stars on this one! 

The only set back was the fact that we found most everything to be a little too salty.  I mean, salt is sooo yummy that it was almost good salty...is that a weird comment?  Anywho, I will return again FOR SURE and give it another go.  Great atmosphere although I could see how on a weekend night it could be a nightmare. 

Great local joint, the uni crudo was seriously off the chain. Do not run, walk, at least on a week night, to Domo.
author: Claire C.

description:
Excellent fresh sushi with some inspired rolls. We ordered a Sexy Mama roll which was absolutely perfect combination of ingredients with flavors that slowly shifted as I ate it. The Kobi beef roll while not exactly sushi was equally amazing. The hamachi belly nigiri melted in my mouth.

The food is a solid 5 stars but the bar chairs are uncomfortable. I guess people with long legs might be ok but my leg circulation was cut off. Also, it is fairly pricy -- expect to drop at least $60-80 for two person meal.
author: Colin F.

description:
Domo is a cute little place just out of the Hayes Valley center.  And when I say little, I mean it.  The place probably sits 15 people at two bars and a table.  

I've been dying to find a good sushi place in SF; I've been so surprised that the sushi here doesn't stack up to what I became used to in Seattle.  Domo might fit the bill.  The menu, like the space, is small, but if the fish is good there really isn't a need to get all fancy-pants.

Miso:  I've found that miso usually a good indicator of the meal to come.  Theirs was really quite good.  Not tons of tofu (which is good in my book) and the broth was fantastic.  Not watery, just light and flavorful.

Albacore Tataki:  Lovely seared pieces of fantastic steak-like fresh albacore.  The sauce was a tiny bit bland, but it was hardly needed since the fish was so good.

Unagi Nigiri:  Thank you for serving pieces of nigiri I can fit in my mouth in one go!  I'm so sick of places serving humongous "mouthfuls" that wind up as messy pieces on my plate.   The perfectly cooked and tender eel rested on just the right amount of rice to make the bite sing.

Rolls:  I think we had a rock 'n roll (unagi) and one other with tempura shrimp.  The unagi one was a bit bland (surprising considering the Nirgiri was so good) and the tempura was fantastic, but really, can you go too far wrong with something deep fried?  I think not.  Again, well put together and the pieces were not too big.

Service:  The waiter hadn't tried everything on the menu yet so had a couple "I don't know" moments.  We did go without our water filled for the last half of the meal, but I think all this is pretty excusable for day two.

All this with a bottle of Nigori sake - yum yum.  Still, maybe not as great as my favorite spots in the hometown, but definitely catching up!

I can't rate higher just because I didn't get more Nigiri or any Sashimi to REALLY test out the freshness.  Just wasn't in the mood.  The real test will be next time I'm feeling like ODing on raw fish.  Then I'm all over this place.
author: Pamela J.

description: Service still provided with a friendly smile but overall experience was underwhelming. Sushi quality has definitely gone down hill compared to a year ago. No longer worth the wait and the money :-(.
author: aj s.

description:
I have to admit, I was pretty messed up.  It was a thursday.  It had been a long, long week.  I was in class 8 hours a day, and that particular day, I'd been in class for 9 hours.  There was just no end in sight.  There was no stopping the relentless beating that accompanied my chosen path.  And to top it all off, my BF was having an anti-going-out-to-eat phase.  I hate it when he does that.  

In a daze, I somehow stumbled off the bus at the requisite stop.  I wandered down Laguna looking for the same blue and white scheme as on Domo's website.  Well, don't because that's not what's out front.  It's a tiny red neon sign in slightly psycho-killer handwriting "domo."  Inside, it was lines with high, bar-bistro height seating, at the sushi bar and then wrapped around the perimeter.  In one cozy corner was an equally high bistro-height table with some chairs.  

I looked at the menu.  I looked for a server.  I shyly asked if they did takeout.  The guy looks at me, I look at him.  We had an understanding.  A spark.  I order the hamachi, the uni, amaebi, sake, and the ankimo appetizer (very good value).  It was about a tray's worth.  It included the fried shrimp heads.  and it cost $33.  I scarfed that tray down and nearly licked the grooved plastic.  

On the taste and freshness:
Freshness - not bad.  Nothing suspicious or smelly about it.  The things were tender.  The hamachi was a strange color though, it looked more like kampachi and not hamachi.  It was not as fragrant as hamachi usually is.  I'll let this one slide and say that the sushi chef misunderstood.  
Taste - also not bad.  Not as fragrant as it could possibly be.  The uni, while not offensive, did not have that sweet, briny, ocean taste.  Usually, uni makes my heart sing and my spirit fly.  This time, my heart merely whistled "Dixie" and my spirit leaned over the edge of the Titanic.  

Portions were smallish.  The rice was small (but I like that), however, the fish was not as mouth-full-of-feel as I would have liked it.  The setting was really cute, but I get more satisfaction from sushi boat.
author: Christina C.

description:
I just returned from Domo after my second visit.  Definitely a sushi place that prides itself and knowing its fare and keeping their customer happy.  They are driven to please you, whatever you want, you can have...but some say otherwise. So I'm not sure how open they are to suggestions (what you don't like, or; what you do like) and having them create something special for you.  However, the service is always great, the atmosphere is serene for a date or with a couple friends (this place is TINY, so not good for more than 2 people).

i highly suggest ordering the butter fish sashimi which is not on the paper menu, but you'll find it on the hard-to-read mirror menu on the northern wall of the restaurant.  it is one of the few sushi places (that I know) whic carry this fish and the only place I will order it.  always a slight cool and definitely fresh, i sometimes have three orders.

as for their rolls, always go from the cucumber wrapped spicy tuna (Spicy Hulk) and the soy sauce they use just makes it much more enjoyable and my brother's favorite; the (light) deep fried firecracker balls.  they are always an order for me each time i go, so good and bite size.  i've also had the opportunity to try to domo roll with friends, while delicious, i always tend to go for the mercury laden tuna in my rolls.  i'll never learn (maybe when my fingers begin to curl into my palms) then I'll learn.

the ambiance is always on the quite side since it is a smaller venue, the lighting always dim and the seating mostly bar or window bar with one lone table that seats up to four guests makes it a perfect evening with friends yet you can still feel intimate with your date (however, one time I heard the depressive story of a girl and I wanted to tell her to shut up).
author: Boho H.

description: With the constant wait for this place I expected great sushi but was disappointed with the standard average sf sushi for slightly higher price than the other average sushi places in sf.
author: LT B.

description: Great food - fish is very fresh. Service with a smile, and a nice intimate atmosphere. Menu selection is small due to location, however 'Specials' menu is rather generous.
author: Taylor J.

description: This place is super. The Kobe beef is...let's just say we ordered another one. Yum.   Make sure to check out the specials, butterfish and wiki wiki very goodThe ginger and wasabi provided a perfect balance between orders. Service was great with a view of the chiefs we should see 'our' order being made and as it walked past us to another eager diner, we waited with anticipation as the next order was made. Not a long wait at all.  The miso and seaweed salad are wonderful appetizers to start a cozy taste sensation. Enjoy every bite as the favors unfolded.
author: R. S.

description:
I have been putting off rating Domo for awhile now. I think it's because I am intimidated somehow. I mean, I really could find no disparity between what they offer (fresh fish, great service, cozy atmosphere) and what they deliver (fresh fish, great service, cozy atmosphere).

They have a rotating list of specials, which I consider to be an excellent sign for any place, but def for a sushi place. They also highlight their new rolls, which is nice for people who have been there before.

I have had endless, fresh nigiri and sashimi, with nary a misstep on presentation, cut or taste. All the rolls are creative, interesting and daring - and so well pulled off! I hate when you try an interesting sounding maki roll, and it tastes terrible - like the chef did not even taste it. Not the case at Domo, each roll works and it is a great place to experiment with new kinds of fish and flavor combinations that you might not have put together yourself. Don't miss the Spicy Hulk! Somehow replacing nori with cucumber works, and you don't even miss the rice!

Their sake menu, while limited, offers a variety of tastes for a variety of price levels, which I appreciate. They also have a fine selection off beers.

Some may complain about the cramped quarters or long waits, but that's what happens when a place is this good! They never rush you out, and the helpful staff seems to encourage the practice of ordering food as you want it - not all at once - which I really like.

Domo is an excellent spot in Hayes Valley, and I can highly recommend taking someone here that you want to impress with some great food for a pretty reasonable price.
author: Melanie D.

description:
This place is like a small va-geen.  Its tiny and tough to get into, but once you're in - OH MY GOD!  

In all seriousness, I love this place.  The sushi and service is very good.  The prices are reasonable.  And, as you can tell from the opening I love the small venue.  

Bonus - they'll give you sake or beer to tide you over during the inevitable wait for a table.  Drinky make Jason happy.
author: Jason S.

description:
Domo is located in the perfect area nestled between cafes and boutiques in Hayes Valley. The sushi is good and the menu may not be long, but it is impressive. They don't take reservations and if you are not in a hurry it is worth the wait to sit at the window.  

Starters are super affordable and executed very well. The edammame (a staple of mine) was perfect and the seaweed salad was good. At $3.50 each you must try a few. After starters don't skip the small crudos section. You can pick 2 types of seafood and they come out on individual spoons with wasabi and avocado. Fresh and spicy! 

Sushi is what they are best at. First, I really like that even if you are ordering 2+ rolls they come out on separate dishes. It really bugs me when sushi places plate 4 rolls together. We don't have to share if we don't want to ha! The veggie roll was great with cucumbers and asparagus. My date had the Domo roll (baked California roll with salmon on top and spicy mayo) and it was also delish. 

Edammame, seaweed salad, two rolls, 3 Sapporos = $56.00. Domo is deff worth checking out and I will be back.
author: Theresa T.

description: Delish! Rio, sushi chef/manager is the man. Their food is awesome, always fresh and really good quality fish, I usually skip the rolls because the nigiri and sashimi is so good by itself.  It is a small place so expect a wait on Saturday night, but there is a bar across the street where u can entertain yourself and trust me it is worth the wait!
author: Karina N.

description:
YAY, what a perfect addition to Hayes Valley!

Dumo's is a cozy modern spot with a small sushi bar if you're lucky enough to get there in time. They played Naked Music in there, which made us want to take our time and linger over our beer/sake and sushi bites.

Rolls were all very good! The musts are the Firecracker Balls (fried, but worth the extra 20 minutes on the treadmill), The Hulk (so fresh, spicy, made w/o rice)... the other rolls and nigiri we ordered were good, too, but the 2 mentioned were the ones that really stood out. 

Soooo happy we have an easier sushi spot and will definitely be returning (you can actually order TO GO without it being looked down upon by... ahem...)

Highly recommended if you happen to be in the area!
author: Nenette Y.

description:
Sushi Domo consistently turns out sushi and nigiri with market-fresh fish and creative combinations.  Two brothers, one specializing in sashimi and the other in rolls.  They have the standard sushi rolls (Rainbow, Spider, etc.) and some of their own creations.  There's a good selection of sake, available both hot or cold.  The decor is slightly dark with mellow music and nice accent lighting - good for both a casual meal or a date.

The pricing is very reasonable and the portions are generous.  Sushi Domo gives the infamous Alameda Sushi House a run for the money without the insane waits and Bay Bridge trip.

Highly recommended.
author: Andrew C.

description:
We came here for dinner on Sunday and had a great meal.  The restaurant is small but had a nice interior. The service was attentive.  We sat in front of the sushi chef and saw him prepare the rolls which is always a treat.
We ordered some sake and beer to drink while we waited for our rolls.   Our food came out quickly even though the restaurant was full. 
We had the following:
fire cracker balls-AWESOME
spicy hulk-Very GOOD
spider-GOOD
spicy tuna-good but i didn't expect it to be deep fried.  I'm not a fan of fried rolls... I guess it was my mistake since I overlooked that.

We definitely will return to try other items on the menu.
author: Lizete S.

description:
We went to Domo on a whim Saturday night (intending to go to Suppenkuche next door, but scared away by the crowds...) There was a bit of a wait (half an hour or so) but really, not too bad for 8 PM Saturday night.

The placed is tiny, but casual and very cozy. Very interesting sushi -- not your standard fare... We had an interesting hamachi carpaccio appetizer (which, unfortunately, didnt arrive before the rest of the sushi...) Then, we had the kobe beef-wrapped asparagus. Good, but not memorably excellent. However, the deep-fried choices were a different story... the crunchy california roll was excellent, and the firecracker balls are a reason to go back to Domo all by themselves. Amazing! 

All-in-all, very delicious (& accompanied by lots of tasty, fruity sake...) Sadly, the service was a bit spotty -- but it *was* Saturday night. But, a very good, casual drop-by sushi choice  (and a happy discovery for us.)
author: donal c.

description:
OK, this place is good. True to its reviews, I think the fish here is of great quality. 

The steak tataki was impressive. Very flavorful, great presentation. The uni, which I always judge to be a good indication of the quality of the restaurant, was one of the best I've ever had! Uni (sea urchin) is my favorite, so that definitely made the night. Their Amaebi (sweet shrimp) was probably the best I've had in the city, and I have definitely frequented my share of sushi restaurants. It was impeccably juicy and simply melted with the rice on my tongue. Their two crudos for 5.95 was also a great item on the menu - that's where I was able to try their uni and scallop, each on their own spoon. Reminded me of spoonfuls of happiness at Koo! 

I also recommend the house roll - good serving size, great mix of sauces and fish. Overall, I notice that their portions are not stingy and should make you fairly full...unless if you're like me, and the better the food is, the more you want to eat of it. I seriously need to exercise some portion control. But along with a slew of nigiri and some rolls, I also went for their hamachi kama , which was also top notch - meat fell right off the collar bone like it should. There's a real consistency here through all of the dishes and the quality definitely came through, at least for me. 

This is a tiny place so I would try to get here early or on less busy nights. It's all practically bar seating..everyone is sitting on high chairs. The service was great and we got good recommendations on dishes from our waiter. I don't know if there are any other better sushi places in Hayes Valley - this is the place to go.
author: Nebula H.

description:
mercie beaucoup monsieur robot!

I don't really want to give you 5 stars... I really really really want something to be wrong with you... Why? Because I am a bastard. 

We strolled in at mid 7pm's, and you sat us right in front, the nice long counter at the window gave me so much to look at. Your lights are simply cool. The "votive"s you have as old salt shakers... neat! The dishes were even simply cool,I especially like the little water jug you gave us, Why? I don't know.  

We ordered edamame(sp), seaweed salad, the spicy hulk, the fire cracker balls, and the crispy cali rolls. Um, Umm, Ummm, UMMMM, UMmmm... I like the fire cracker balls more the the crispy cali... You are tiny, You food is just the right size and best of all, you are speedy... and even more best of all, all that food came out to 40 bucks... That's pretty good compared to some other places. I will definitely come back again. I had a dantastic time here!
author: danny e.

description: My favorite place in the neighborhood. And it does have outdoor seating!
author: Sarah D.

description: Ate outside with a high school friend last night. Ordered a sweet potato roll and a dragon roll, which comes with shrimp tempura, cucumber, eel, and roe (hold the avo - unfortunately, it doesn't agree with me). The sweet potato was so yummy and topped with some kind of sauce. I've never had eel before and the dragon roll was amazing. We shared edamame which was properly cooked, and my friend had several pieces of nigiri and a temptation roll. Great service. Great green tea - it's the nutty kind, I can't remember what it's called.
author: Alyssa A.

description:
So I found myself working in the neighborhood, and lo and behold
there's an adorable little sushi place at the foot of my street!!
Toro, uni, ankimo - all my favs representing. 
I've become an uni aficionado and this is some of the creamiest
melt in your mouth i've had!!

My paycheck is as good as gone.
author: Sandrita R.

description:
She wanted the Fire Cracker Balls (spicy tuna roll with spicy mayo, unagi sauce, scallions & tobiko).

He wanted the Sexy Mama (asparagus, tobiko topped with sliced lemon & salmon, yuzu cucumber). 

We both wanted the Domo Roll (baked california roll topped with salmon & scallops with spicy mayo, unagi sauce, tobiko & scallions).

Everything was absolutely delicious, and I'm still thinking about the brilliant pop of lemon in the Sexy Mama.

Equally impressive was the Kobe beef roll. We didn't actually order it, but watched in awe as the chef cooked the beef with a propane torch. It was so very, very awesome, and so very, very on our items to order next time.

Service and decor were the perfect mix of friendly, inviting, warm, modern, subtle, sophisticated. All comes without breaking the bank - a reasonable bill became a steal after learning the salad and edamame were on the house. 

Go and enjoy.
author: Jason B.

description: one of the best sushi spots you will find in the city. The domo roll is out of control. Always packed so get there early for dinner..
author: Alder H.

description:
Highlights were definitely

the firecracker balls (similar to the ones at Red Box Sushi)
the spicy kick on the spicy tuna rolls
special order of umeshiso maki
beautiful water bottle sans ice
the huge window lined with bar-like seating for us lovely people watchers
the ability to go solo and chill
the really sweet wait staff

A less expensive alternative to Sebo, but the sushi is not necessarily earth shattering nor are the prices band aids to stop the wallet hemmorage in this pricey neighborhood.
author: Cathy H.

description: This might be the easiest review I've ever written. This place is fabulous and easily the best sushi I've ever had (and I've been referred to in close circles as the Madonna of sushi) What can I say, I don't discriminate. yeah Sabo been on No Reservations and is virtually around the corner but its just too overpriced, overcrowded and over-hyped these days. take a short walk over to Laguna and you'll find Domo. The rolls are creative, different and worth the extra calories! Grab some Crudos to start and enjoy the people watching from the wrap around bar. The prices are extremely reasonable and the parking sucks. The projects a couple blocks up offer inviting spaces (even for the worst of parallel parkers) and a nice gamble (that your car will even be there when you get back) so leave your valuables in the trunk or roll dirty in a beater to throw off the scent.
author: Ryan M.

description:
The fish quality was fine, however TOTALLY non traditional... Like not even a little bit. Actually I've begun to feel that restaurants like this should call their food California cuisine, and the raw fish that they serve should be carpaccio (cuz thats what you're getting... jalapeno roll my ass). 

I'll admit that I feel strongly about my sushi. I feel even more strongly about paying 50$ for my sushi and still being hungry. I don't pay 50$ for carpaccio...
author: Matt C.

description:
Update ~

I've been a bunch of time,  always delicious. 

The firecracker balls are sinful. Super good, but like anything fried they do induce a twinge of guilt.

I live in the neighborhood and it's nice to see a place open up that doesn't sell baby clothes. And even though it's on the tiny side, I rarely have to wait to be seated.

Me likey.
author: miss L.

description:
Seriously??? the average rating for this place is 4 stars?

I'm not sure how to best explain this. It's just.. there are so many better places for sushi in San Francisco. Their rolls are average.. their sashimi.. hmm meh. I just think their rolls are comparable to the ones you find in grocery stores.
author: dub m.

description: We managed to get bar seats on a Saturday night without reservations. The waitress was super friendly and efficient, so I hope I get her again next time. The hamachi, salmon and toro sashimi were excellent, as well as the spicy tofu salad. We also liked the asparagus wrapped kobe. The miso soup, however, was way too salty.
author: Eva G.

description: THIS. WAS. THE. BEST. SUSHI. EVER. If you dig California style sushi, look no further. Worth every effing cent.
author: Dave T.

description:
Finally a good sushi restaurant in Hayes Valley!  I've been waiting ages for this to happen.  Next project for restaurant owners: please create a yummy burrito place.  The neighborhood seriously lacks one and I'm not talking about that one place that tastes like uninspiring vomit. 

Onwards for Domo:

Their assortment of sushi is small but incredibly delicious.  It's all the wonderful things that good sushi should have.  Their ingredients are fresh and each roll is done with love and care.  They give you ample portions of seaweed salad and the miso soup is pretty decent.  They also have a list of creative sushi rolls which I will be back very soon to try.  

Seating is very limited in this small restaurant but the ambiance is cozy, charming and comfortable.  It's a Modernist's vision of the perfect sushi parlor complete with knick-knack, DIY light fixtures, something you'd find in an early 20th century science lab.  

Also, I commend them for their great music selection!

They don't take reservations so it's best to arrive early (before 7pm) for seating.  The service is attentive and efficient.

This place is already a neighborhood favorite!
author: Hellyn M.

description:
Yes please. 

Hamachi and jalapeno roll?  Yes please.
Spider roll?  Yes, please.
Poke?  Yes, please.
Nice service, clean and friendly?  Yes, please.

Thank you.
author: Erin M.

description: Hands down, best sushi I've had in the city!! Service is as good as the food, must go!!
author: Yuly M.

description: Great quality fish in a small intimate setting. Had the Chirashi Sashimi with rice which was great but sparse. About six slices of different types of fish. Good quality, just wish the portions were larger, but hey, it's sushi. And good quality at that.
author: Rajiv S.

description:
I prefer izakaya and cooked foods over sushi-only, but I was over at TrueSake on Hayes stocking up on a Sunday afternoon back in Jan/2009.  Domo was a short walking distance around the corner and the earliest to open so I popped in with a fresh bottle of Wakatake Onikoroshi daiginjo.  I was actually 15 minutes early from opening time, but they told me to go ahead and come on in - my kind of place.  I thought both the nigiri and sashimi servings were very fresh and satisfying.  I rarely order rolls and can't comment on these since I didn't order any.

For San Francisco the price relative to the quality was surprising i.e. a good value, less expensive than I would have normally expected.  I sat at the bar and found both the owner and staff to be polite and friendly.  They made me feel comfortable and good conversations ensued.  The service was prompt and efficient.  

I would definitely come back when in the area and wanting sushi.  I'd like to see some izakaya items added to the menu.  Several items were close; the fish tacos and asparagus wrapped in kobe beef, then flame seared with a hand held torch.  I don't have any complaints or dissatisfactions.
author: Mark S.

description:
Took a friend there for her birthday - we enjoyed it immensely.  Service was good, even if we were talking too much to have anything selected the first time the server asked. Food is yummy, and good portion sizes except for the nigiri (there is only one place I can justify nigiri - w********e).

Nice sake list, great ambiance. We got there early, so no wait but I know that the wait after we left was kinda long (and it was a Sunday).
author: Michelle R.

description:
Tempura California Roll!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
devine.
a friend introduced me to this place and i use visiting him as an excuse to cross the bay and eat Domo.
the guys who run the place are great, and even let us in though they were technically done accepting new orders. 
the sushi is delicious, the sake gets me tipsy, and i like the intimate hole-in-the-wall atmosphere. 
yay Domo!
author: Raquel C.

description:
This place is quite dainty and is pretty much like the small spots in Japan. Although its Taiwanese owned, they make authentic sushi.

Location
I recommend getting there early as it does not seat many and you may get caught up in a line to get in. Parking will be a challenge but its worth it.

Food
The sushi are the right size and not like other places where they make these ginormous rolls that you can barely take with one bite.  I grew up in Japan and it was a nice and refreshing to get great sushi that resemble what I ate when I was in Japan.  The fish is fresh and very flavorful.  

Ambiance 
As mentioned above its quite dainty, but you get an intimate experience. There's one table and rest of the seat is on a counter that wraps around to the sushi bar. They write their daily specials on this black board in neon pen so make sure to take a moment to check out it out.

Service
The Sushi chefs are fun and great to converse with, like any sushi place don't forget to offer then some sake and beer! There is a waiter if your are unlucky to get a seat at the small sushi bar, but he's a cool kid as well.
author: Sid E.

description: LOVE THIS PLACE!!!! if you are in the neighborhood its a must try .  always fresh and creative . i have been herer several times with no complaints xo domo
author: Ruca R.

description:
Tiny intimate sushi joint that has a nice feel to it. It's most bar seating unless you are willing to sit outside (1 inside table for 2). Intimate. 

The sushi was good. This is really a "roll" place. The nigiri was really mediocre or even worse bad. I always tend to get some hamachi, sake, and seared ahi nigiri. The ahi was the best nigiri I tried there. The Hamachi carpaccio was the bomb.  The crudos were also quite nice, particularly the uni if that is your thing. The famous firecracker is a great blast of flavor that is a must, at least for 1st timers. I wouldn't order it again though. The flavors are bit too familiar.

The sequence in which we received everything was totally wrong. All the most flavorful items came first so we had to do a lot of palate cleansing. I'm sure the rest of the rolls are also good. There is a little too many spicy tuna type combo rolls for me though.

I don't think we will come back. I would though recommend this place a friend to try out. Maybe come back for that carpaccio. I suspect that the quality of their fish is just OK, judging from the nigiri. Overall good food, not great. Lots of others places to try in the city by the bay.

In any case, it was a great evening.
author: Jeremy K.

description:
Domo is a good neighborhood sushi place.  It's very small and the selection of fish is not wide ranging.  Ask what's good and order it, because it will be good.  The chef steered us to excellent kampachi and iwashi. The Ankimo appetizer special we had and the crudos were probably the best parts of the meal, but some of the fish that should have been spectacular -- hamachi belly, toro -- were only good.

The atmosphere is nice -- bar all around -- and intimate.  But why do they have a menu from a Chinese restaurant tacked up on the wall?  Prices are fair.
author: Paul H.

description:
Great fresh sushi.  Not as much selection as many other places, but thats what makes it great.  Ask the chef for suggestions, and he'll give you different cuts of a fish, or whatever is best that day.

Small place, great for catching up with people and sharing a few beers.
author: Evan B.

description:
First Ill say Im so excited to finally have a sushi spot right next to my house. My dreams.....oh someone has heard my cry!  While mourning the loss of No Name Sushi last week and walking to the coffee shop I discovered that Domo had opened.

 Signal grabbing of boyfriend for dinner. 

We took a walk over here on one of the hot nights last week for sushi snacks and sake sipping. I really enjoyed the starter sushi sampler as it was playful and fun. Truely enjoy when my dish comes with all my favorites but not in the traditional way. 

The rolls were delicious and my salmon skin was crunchy and flavorful. Everything tasted fresh and looked well put together, and despite the fact that my boyfriend eats about twice as fast as I do and I was chopstick fighting my way to the saba dinner was great. I love the window seating and the heavy wooden wall decor. Staff was awesome and friendly and didnt even blink when the boy started ordering most of the menu. 

The only thing missing here is a smiling japanese hostess. Other than that...top notch place to unwind and watch the hayes valley street traffic.
author: Charlie B.

description: Awesome sushi and experience all around. Had to wait a while for a table but we just went into Hayes valley And got a drink. I'd recommend Domo to a friend!
author: Richard S.

description:
Small and clean place with tasteful decor.  Sat at the bar and had a variety of sushi rolls and some nigiri.  Yup, the firecracker balls were so awesome.  I came out very very happy and satiated with sushi, ready to go to the Glay concert that same night.

I'm not sure if this place is Japanese-owned, since I did hear the chef speak some Chinese.  But he totally could've passed for Japanese.  I mean, Chinese people just don't look like that.
author: L Y.

description:
My first time here and we had to wait 45 minutes before getting seated. Luckily my friend and I had some catching up to do.  A small sushi restaurant (sits about 20?) with dimmed lights and mostly bar stool seating.  

We tried the kobe beef roll, spicy tuna, spider role and the cucumber spicy hulk.  The Kobe Beef roll took forever to come out.   The bill came to about $25/each. 

Not my favorite sushi restaurant but the first sushi joint I've ever eaten in the Hayes valley area.  

A place that is good for dates but not so good for families.
author: Jboogie L.

description:
Came here for a quick dinner on an airport run.  The place isn't too big, but we were able to easily get a spot before the place got a bit more packed.  We ordered 4 different rolls, all of which were pretty good.  

The service was excellent, and we were in and out of there pretty much as fast as we had hoped.  I'd definitely go back for a less rushed dinner and try out more of their food options.  The rolls were good, so I imagine the rest of their fish would be just as good.
author: Amit M.

description: Intimate dining, good service. Small place, but we haven't been there once and not been able to find seating. This has become our new "go-to" sushi spot in the city.- a guaranteed satisfied belly. Firecracker Balls, Temptation Roll and Crunchy Spicy Tuna Roll seem to be our favorites.
author: Jenna L.

description:
Cute hip atmosphere and really nice staff.

Bottom line: half the dishes were good.

edemame were undercooked and no salt or spice to be seen.

albacore tataki was dry and overcooked and totally skippable despite all the kick-ass reviews.

"fire balls" special of the night was the hands-down highlight. spicy tuna with tempura batter, hot sauce, creamy sauce, tobiko and scallions.

everything else was fresh but not put together in a way where I can remember what it was.
author: Melanie C.

description: I checked this place out cuz it has the coolest name Domo after my favorite Jap character Domo Kun. Unfortunately it didn't have the same punch or charisma as Domo... We ordered the dragon, omega, and the recommended crunch ball roll as well as my staple spicy tuna hand roll and toro. I would have to say the cuts were smaller than most sushi places I have been to and heavy with the rice action. The only saving grace was there sushi fish tacos which were pretty decent, hence the two stars. Makes Domo Kun mad!!!
author: Minh V.

description: Wonderful neighborhood sushi spot!  The sushi is solidly above average with some very tasty and innovative items.  This is one of the few sushi bars I've been to that reliably has fresh walu.
author: Justin W.

description: I checked this spot out on a Monday night with my girlfriend.  We didn't have to wait because we just beat the crowd as we arrived around 6ish 7.  We ordered 2 of the uni crudos, domo roll, hamachi kama, and one of the special rolls.  I thought the uni crudo was just okay.  I don't think I'd order it again next time I go.  However, I loved the rolls and hamachi kama.  I would love to check out the lunch menu sometime.  $12 for fresh delicious sushi.  I'm in!  :)
author: Vicky C.

description:
Domo arigatoo Domo!

I actually like that it's this small, it makes you wanna come here all the time and take up all their space.  You have this overwhelming desire for them to do really well as a business.

How pleasantly surprised to see my old friend Kua here as Executive Sushi Chef at the new restaurant.  I used to work with him at Blowfish, and knowing how awesome and fun he was to work with, I was excited he would be my new neighborhood sushi man.   The service is great, patient, hospitable, personable.  The fish is fresh and rich in colors.  The ambiance is super modest, which makes you want to love it even more.  

No pretentiousness in this location, like some other sushi spots tend to be.  Sushi places tend to be too trendy, too minimal, or too mainstream.  This place isn't anything like that.

Worth the wait!  Menu is small, but the quality is worth it.
author: Annster L.

description:
Solid Japanese food at a great neighborhood joint. I've been there twice and really like the crudos, especially the crab crudo. I usually get some yellowtail or white albacore nigiri as well to start off, and then top it off with some rolls, like the mighty Temptation roll. The sexy mama's pretty good as well. I'm not a big fan of spicy food, so I stayed away from the firecracker balls, but people tell they're worth it. 

I've eaten there twice, once on a Saturday night that surprisingly had no wait. Well worth a try...
author: Keyvan R.

description: The Hulk Roll is outstanding! Also loved the Saba Hit, and the Salmon Citron. The fish is some of the freshest I've had in the city! Try the Chef's seasonal choices under Sashimi!
author: Marissa P.

description: Hands down my favorite sushi place in SF. The fish tacos, ankimo and sake sashimi are my go-to's. Quality ingredients are used in each carefully crafted dish by Rio to please your palate. This place is small, but the friendly and attentive staff make the wait fly by (so does the sake!).
author: Rachel S.

description: The "domo" roll and the creamy sake were amazing enough that I won't count the grouchy waiter against them (but really dude - was there somewhere else you wanted to be?).  Best sushi I've had in a long time. The place is small though, and all seating is counter + high-chair style so if you're going on a date, maybe make sure it's at least the 2nd or 3rd.
author: Joanne S.

description:
Intimate place, not more than 20 seats: all along the walls/windows & bar. We sat at the bar, and it was an great experience watching the chefs & servers working efficiently in what seemed like 50 sq. ft :)

- Firecracker balls: hot tuna crusted with panko breadcrumbs: a whole lot of deep fried goodness
- Domo Roll: Usually not a fan of baked rolls, but this restaurant namesake roll hit the mark!
author: Aditi K.

description:
I heard somewhere before that the chef at Domo actually started Blowfish, so I was slightly hesitant on giving this place a lot of credit.  

No hate, just being honest.  Blowfish didn't blow, it was just ... you know, okay.  Like sushi purgatory.

Anyway, Domo was a really nice surprise.  The venue is a little small, so DO NOT try to bring a big party or you'll have a big fail moment.  I like the temptation roll, which was crispy and filled with unagi-goodness.  The fatty tuna was good but didn't seem as fresh as other places, and the other fares were also delish like the seaweed salad, firecracker balls, etc.

If you're up for an intimate date place, this is a good choice.
author: Shay F.

description: Love the chefs and staff here. Fun menu with a lot of variety, they had a really good roll that looked like a taco and was very creative. Good quality fish but still a bit pricey for what you get. Kobe beef was decent but not as good as I've had from other places.
author: Andrea B.

description: lunch specials are a DEAL. everything is amazing! me and my brother ordered a sashimi salad and I asked to sub something (I think it was octopus) with avocado and A+ for that. We also ordered a chicken karaage and croquette combo and it also came with half an avocado (randomly, but awesomely). Everything came with miso soup and salad and everything was just delicious.
author: Jess C.

description:
This new sushi place, competing with Sebo in Hayes Valley, has a contrasting laid back vibe. Domo seems like the kind of place you could stop in by yourself, belly up to the sushi or window bar, and grab a bite.

Domo only has one 4-setting table and even then, one person is going to be sitting strangely in the path to the bathroom/kitchen. The rest of the seating is bar and window rows.

The interior design was superbly done. All of the walls are covered in a fragrant pine or oak, I'm not sure. But the place smelled like wood. 

The fish and service was pretty standard. We ordered two 5-piece dishes of sashimi, 2 rolls and some edemame. First we got a roll, then the edemame, then another roll, and ended with the sashimi. The order was a little strange.

Over all it has a great vibe. I enjoy returning to this place regularly.
author: George M.

description:
Oooo so nice lunch today ... I like the wood slat interior, cozy and clean for Hayes valley. The valley needed a new sushi spot and this place is perfect. Great for lunch or dinner for two.

The sushi is fresh and they have a bunch of rolls, although a lot of the rolls are similar containing Unagi and something ... great if you are a eel fan, but I think a little more variety is needed. They have Asian styled crudo which looked appealing but I didn't have any, as I was looking for something more for lunch, but would be great to get with sake in the evening.
author: Michael S.

description: Alpha Roll - a special roll that hopefully makes it to the menu. Incredible mango, avocado, unagi and spicy tuna with roe that pops in your mouth and topped with pickled jalapeno for a slight kick. And for dessert, the black sesame ice cream - amazing! Think healthy peanut butter or a toasted nut ice cream. I hope to be back.
author: Angel-n-Shannon D.

description: Probably my fav sushi place in SF! love the intimate seating and great sushi and roll selections. Friendly staff.
author: Patty P.

description:
I'm so happy a sushi restaurant moved into my neighborhood. 

The firecracker balls were very tasty and I like the feel of the place even if there are no tables.

I'll definitely be back.

I've went back last night and had the Hamachi Kama. It was so tasty.
author: Amy W.

description: Rad had awesome sake and the fire ball sushi is perfect
author: Haley R.

description:
OMG i can have sushi for lunch now?!?! it's my dream come true, really. 

until now i have been limited to these food groups for lunch. salads, burgers, sandwiches, soups, crepes, the occasional falafel, and even more salad. but no more!

i haven't had the chance to eat in yet, but their ready made bento boxes are yummy yummy in my tummy. it changes everyday and it's fills me up with sushi goodness for the incredibly low low price of $10! 

the last time i went they were out of bento boxes but the sushi chef was nice enough to make me one on the spot! i asked the cute waiter what time they opened, he said 12, and i told him i couldn't believe they had already sold out. it was only 12:45. he told me to call ahead next time and he would put one aside for me. swoon!

hooray for cute waiters and sushi for lunch!!
author: kristy s.

description: Stumbled into this place by accident since we couldn't find our original destination.  Pleasantly surprised at the quality of the sashimi.
author: Amelia C.

description:
OMG, they are so going to have to knock down the walls and take over the space next door. Really, it's too magnificent to be so small! Thank God they are open for lunch.
I'd dare say they have the freshest, most dissolving-the-moment-it- hits-your-tongue yellowtail I have ever tasted. 
BONUS- Shochu, oh yea.
author: Colleen B.

description:
Meh.  Okay, okay, I fell in love with the firecracker balls and will go back for them.  If you're into fish, go down the road to Sebo and pay twice as much to get twice as good stuff.  I was slightly disappointed in the toro which was not cheap, yet slightly chewy.  Chewy + toro  = sad Aimee
Mesch and I were also underwhelmed by the saba.  Like sex, any saba is good saba, but still I say "meh" and that it's nothing to write home about.

That being said, it's a cute neighborhood place, small and packed with lively pescophiles by 7pm on a Thursday night.  Mesch and I sat at the bar but it's not too interactive so next time I'll get seating against the windows facing out onto Laguna for some good people-watching.
author: Aimee B.

description:
Domo is worth the wait.  I've  been here twice, and each time I've savored the rolls and grooved to the beats in the background, all the while emptying a couple of bottles of nigori sake.  The selection of rolls are tasty, but not much different from other trendy sushi spots; however, they are rolled just right with sufficient amount of rice and content.  I liked the firecracker balls that were filled with flavor and surrounded by crunch.  Just judging from the rainbow roll, since I have yet to try the nigiri sushi, the fish is fresh.  I really enjoyed the spicy tuna roll and the other rolls that I had which were mainly with hamachi, my favorite fish.  

I will definitely return to try the small crudos, nigiri, and for more of the nigori sake.  A side note: there was outside seating on the street the last time I was there, which is always a treat to me.  Also, Domo's ambiance is very suitable for dates.
author: Linda P.

description:
The Toro.

Oh, the Toro.

It's the best $2.13 a bite ($5.25 a piece, $10.50 an order) to be had in Hayes Valley. (This goes along with the best $0.25 a sip at Absinthe, the best $0.50 a nibble at Citizen Cake, and the best $4 a skewer at Hayes and Kebab.)  It made a great closer after a tasty negi-hama roll and a fresh, bright Sexy Mama roll (aspragus, salmon, and tobiko, topped with lemon and yuzu).
author: Joe G.

description:
Pretty good sushi place. I secretly like their lunch special with nigiri better than the rolls I had tonight. Very small, we sat at the bar. Nice staff.

My dining experience was peppered with the two pairs who flanked us at the bar. About the most ignorant and arrogant conversations I've heard in a while.

Guy and girl next to me start snidely questioning why I'm not scooting over to make more room. Um, do you not see that we're ALL shoved together at this bar? If you really have a problem, you could ask. I was this close to firing back something equally rude when I heard this gem come out of the girl's mouth:

(to the server) Is the fish (in your special rolls) cooked?
Puzzled look from server.
Girl attempts to clarify, with raised hands to demonstrate "cooked": I mean, does any the fish get "cooked" at all in the rolls?
More puzzled look.
Girl: Because I can only eat cooked fish. Oh I guess I'll get tempura.

Who goes to a sushi restaurant and makes a fuss about fish being cooked? It was hard to tell what this lady's definition of "cooked" was. Perhaps she meant warmed, or steamed, or fried the hell out of it. Whatever she meant, I learned later that night that she 1. has never eaten at a bar (so confirmed to her equally lame male partner) and 2. only orders tempura when she goes out. What a waste of fish.

This was all trumped by the conversation going on the other side of us.

Another guy-girl pair. Guy asks the server, "I want to see your most sustainable fish. Whatever fish you have that's most sustainable."
(I feel bad for the staff at this point. These aren't diners, they're arrogant elitists)
Server leaves, confused.
I can't tell whether the female patron is believing this, or if she's just going along. Out of her mouth comes: "It's so nice to have a fellow diner who's...um...you know"

No, I don't know! I wanted to know what she meant.

Who is this guy? Sushi = killing fish to feed the mouths of people like you. I doubt that anything you're eating tonight is going to be marketable as "sustainable." It's people like this who give San Francisco a bad name.

Other than this eavesdropping, our meal was enjoyable. Will come back soon.
author: Sarah W.

description: The sushi here is amazing!  Definitely now one of my favorites! The place is tiny, so it's a perfect date spot if one wants to be intimately close.  I've live in the city for a year now, and am slowly finding out there are so many more fantastic sushi places outside of my neighborhood... I love SF.
author: Myra M.

description: "best sushi i've ever had" is one of the most bold and audacious statements one can make - and i'm not about to make that claim for domo. but the mere fact that it crossed my mind makes me believe they're doing something right. what they're doing right is taking a night out for sushi from 'let's go out for sushi' to experience that rivals an earth moving experience. i say experience because it's not just one great roll, or that they impecable service, or even the hip ultra local feel to the place but the combination of all that combined. i've always said what separates decent middle of the road sushi from the cadillac of all sushis is their sashimi. nothing else to mask the freshness or raw flavor of the fish - and i can honestly say domo's hamachi and salmon was like buttery, silky candy that seemed to melt in my mouth the more i let it savor on my tongue. super excited to go back.
author: Kristy M.

description: Sit at the bar, enjoy the music and order a custom Walu hand roll with spicy yum yum sauce, you won't be disappointed.
author: Ricardo B.

description:
Great Sushi.
Great atmosphere.
It can't sit many people... it suits better couples or small parties.
author: Marco P.

description: Yes this place is A-MAZING! We didn't realize how small is was going to be inside, and of course it was super crowded, so we decided to grab one of the outside tables. Yes, it was cold due to SF's wonderful weather, but the Creme Sake and the hot miso soup helped us feel toasty in no time.  The seaweed salad was really good, and the rock and roll (roll) was yummy too. However, the firecracker balls were rockin! The flavor was intense and wonderful, unagi sauce added the perfect touch, and there was a mild spice that made them taste better than any sushi rolls I have ever had. I could literally eat them all day long if I had the option! I must come back here again soon! Next time though I will go earlier to get a table inside!
author: Sonya D.

description:
2nd TRIP: "Really Freakin Bad!"

God I must have been drunk when I wrote the last review or when I was there cause I have never been to a sushi place that did such a 180-degree turn that it would go from 5 stars to 2 stars! Serious case of inconsistency.

2nd trip was with less spectacle and the party was just my GF and myself. We loved the sushi last time! Even the fried rolls, which I usually can't stand anywhere. We ordered the similar rolls from last time including the sexy mama, spicy tuna crunchy, ST handrolls & firecracker balls. 

Everything was crap...handrolls had 1/2 the amount of fish, rolls were drowning in spiced mayo to the point we couldn't taste the fish or finish the roll & the rice wasn't prepared correctly as it was too soft and fell apart on all rolls.  Service was not pro like the 1st time...the busboy from last time served us. This was one of very few times where we have left a personal tip for the chefs that was to tone down on the sauce.

Your inconsistency has disgraced the family Domo! 1 last chance left due to the close proximity and a once proud 5 star rating. We will likely return in a couple of months to see if they have shaped up. Domo Domo.

*******************
The last entry was actually from months ago, just wanted to divide it out from the original. 

The last time we tried Domo it came back swinging. Gone was the mayo-o-plenty and the firecracker balls were made right. Everything was fairly good so averaged with the last rating it's now moved up on this update to 3 stars.
author: Nick V.

description:
They have some great flavor and texture combinations.
salmon crudo - bite size scoop of salmon, avocado, olive oil
spicy hulk - spicy tuna, avocado, wrapped in cucumber
fish taco (japanese version) - seared salmon and tuna on fried nori (tortilla)
author: Kumar D.

description: 3.5 stars. The sashimi is the star here, as is anything they have on special. Baby octopus kara age served this weekend was seasoned and sauced well. Pricing and overall value are the issue, not quality or execution. Skip the crudo (not worth it) and the firecracker balls (too heavy).
author: Brian C.

description:
Good Sushi.  Pretty tight space but the fact that it is small means that it is fast.  We got in and out in under 30 min on a friday night. Maybe not the best for date night because of the bar seating all around.  But in warm weather they have seating outside that is awesome.

If you live in the neighborhood you can't ask for better. 

However, they should change up the menu a little here and there.  There are 10 million combinations of sushi rolls so to not vary the menu is kind of lazy. Other than that it's fresh, good and fast.
author: Jackson D.

description: I was worried we would have to wait a really long time since we were a party of five and there's only one table in addition to bar seating. Luckily, we only waited ten minutes, at the very most and then we did our best to fit around the table with all of our water glasses and plates- it was a tight squeeze, and our waiter did his best to accommodate our group. We ordered the Hamachi Cappachio to start and this was my favorite out of all the sushi we tried- it was very fresh and the flavors were great. The fiesta roll sounded interesting because I like tuna, mango and cilantro, but it's actually kind of weird to have salsa on your sushi so I'll never order that roll again. We also ordered the spider roll and one other that I forget the name of; I liked both of them and found that everything tasted fresh with a great mix of spices and flavors. I can't wait to go back and try some of the other rolls!
author: Natalie M.

description:
This place is small (and when I say small, I mean REALLY small) so if you want to eat here I'd recommend getting there early if it's a Friday or Saturday. 

That being said, if you can get in and get a seat you'll be in for some great sushi! Everything was very fresh and super tasty. My only complaint is that one of the rolls that we ordered, the Hulk roll, was pretty small for $10. It was delicious but I was expecting a little bit more. The Dragon roll was really good and unusually large(there were about 10 pieces) and the seaweed salad was one of the best that I've had recently.

Overall, the service and food were good, the decor was nice, and the bathroom was surprisingly large. I'd definitely go back but maybe on a weekday so that it'd be less crowded.
author: Amanda R.

description:
yummy yummy yummy! 

I came here for dinner last night w/ the bf and was very satisfied. We ordered 3 rolls: Temptation, Rock n Roll, Spider Roll, and also ordered the Sashimi combination. I loved how everything was very tasty, wasnt too bland or anything like that. Their tempura was cooked perfectly, not too little or too much breading, but just perfect!

The sashimi was soooooooooo fresh, it felt as if it was literally melting in my mouth.... MMmmmmmMmmm :) 

The space is quite small and was filled throughout the entire night. I am a bit bummed that I would only be able to come here with 2-3 people and not as a huge group. They definitely used every inch of space to the max! Our waitress was super friendly and business was excellent. This place is definitely a great addition to the neighborhood.
author: M W.

description:
I AM OBSESSED WITH DOMO!  

My guy and I went about a month ago for the first time, and we were in heaven!

As everyone here has mentioned, you must try the firecracker balls- they make your mouth come alive!  Domo roll (which is tasty but does kinda fall apart) and the crunchy California roll are special- the dragon roll is the best I've ever had.  Fully satisfied, we started plotting our return.

Two weeks later we decide to bring a couple with us.  We got there just in time to snag the single table.   The daikon salad was savory and an excellent starter.  Then the owner Kuohwa and the waiter recommended some rolls for us- and the fatty tuni nigiri.  WOW.  Each dish presented to us was sampled, and we'd break out in applause.  It was that good.  It didn't hurt that we had some delicious unfiltered sake flowing at the table!  Our friends Heidi A  and Glenn C said it was the best sushi experience they've ever had!

We had to go again.

A couple of weeks later, we had something to celebrate- my guy had gotten a promotion, so we decided to go to one of our two fave restaraunts: you guessed it, Domo.  What followed is an experience every sushi lover should have: I HIGHLY recommend it.  After greeting us  back effusively, Kuohwa asked if he could order for us.  

Seriously, if you have never tried this before: indulge, at least once in your life. 

Crudos: monkfish pate and seared scallops.  Both melt in  your mouth.  Probably my favorite.  Tataki- asparagus wrapped in slightly seared Kobe Beef.  Spicy Hulk roll.  Fish tacos (even better than Umami- really).  The only thing that I wouldn't have again was the deep-fried Spanish Mackeral skeleton- but it was an experience and I'm glad I tried it! 

Kuohwha knows his sushi.  Yes I wish it was bigger- but give them time! They've been here less than a year.  I cannot wait to go back.

Best sushi EVER.
author: Trisha F.

description:
Tired of your sushi favs in the City? You know, Sushi Groove or Tokyo Go Go ... but are still hungry for decent sushi in a spot w/ a trendiness factor a knotch above the average sushi joint? Try Domo. 

Cute little place with seriously about 15 seats total - tucked away in Hayes Valley. Fish is pretty fresh and there are some innovative items like the tartar appetizers. Sake is a flowing and service ain't that bad either.

Make sure you have time (or a beer in hand) for a wait to get in the door. Once you're in, though, you will likely enjoy your experience. Good for a date or dinner w/ a friend (note the singular friend).
author: Deann M.

description:
I just moved to Hayes Valley a few days ago, and I am thrilled that there is a fantastic sushi joint right down the street from me.  I've been there on a couple different occasions so far and I have to say that I've been super pleased.  I love that they have tables outside so that you can dine al fresco when the weather cooperates.  Otherwise, the seating indoors is definitely a tight squeeze. 

The seaweed salad is perfect!  Meanwhile, the Spicy Hulk Roll seems to be a bit of a misnomer.  It's spicy tuna, avocado, tobiko wrapped in a cucumber sheet with spicy ponzu sauce.  It's not much of a hulk, but rather light and delicate.   

I tried my friend's crunchy California roll, and that was over the top! A smidge too much indulgence in fried tempura and mayo for my liking.  I could only eat one piece of it before feeling bloated.  Don't get me wrong, it was very tasty, but just a little excessive for me.  I thought sushi was supposed to be healthy! 

The service is generally pretty quick, but sometimes they forget to give you chopsticks...making it challenging to eat the seaweed salad!
author: Evelyn K.

description:
I'll start with the good things and then work my way down.  
*Nice cozy place and atmosphere in a hood surrounded by other cozy restaurants.  
*I thought the service was good and attentive.  The waitress said they were running out of hot sake but managed to squeeze out two bottles out of the box for us.
*The Spicy Hulk was actually spicy, cool, and refreshing...our favorite of the night.

The specials scribbled on the mirror were hard to read...we constantly had to bobble our heads in order to see what was up.  One of the specials was the Fresh Ikura so we asked for it.

"We're out of it."  Ok, how about the not-so-fresh ikura?  
"We're out of that too."  

Okey, on to the others: uni (sissy portions), the uni/monkfish liver sushi crudo combo (more sissy portions), seared albacore nigiri (came to us non-seared, equally sissy), and the $14 sashimi salad (We got what looked like one expensive head of lettuce compared to the amount of sashimi in it, and the dressing was bland).  The way they hold back on the portions I was surprised they would be out of anything...from my experience most Chinese-owned sushi shops are rather generous with their portions but this joint plays this neighborhood.

$.02
author: Ken W.

description:
Stopped in this place unexpectedly because of their great lunch specials.
clean, cute little place. Lunch hit the spot with salad, soup and a few rolls. Can't say it was the best sushi I've ever had, but it hit the spot.
author: Nichole D.

description:
Domo is a great little neighborhood sushi joint---if you live in Hayes Valley. I don't think I would make a special trip for it, but after Symphony, it's a good choice that's close by without having to resort to giant chocolate desserts at Max's or something. 

The decor is much more hip and nicer than the pictures on Yelp. By 6pm on a Sunday, it's already filling up very quickly. The seat arrangement surrounding the room probably doesn't optimize the space, but I kinda like it. It's like everyone is on their intimate little date. You are so close to your dining companion your knees brush against each other's, but if you ever get bored with your conversation, you can always check yourself out in the mirror or look outside the window for more exciting potentials. 

And did I mention it's dim so everyone looks good? 

Music is hip; waiters are hip. Menu is also less traditional, featuring crudos---spoonfuls of delight that would normally serve in an appetizer dish. But now they appear even tinier, almost big enough for one bite, but oh, those spoons so cool and hip. 

My husband and I had a bunch of nigiris: tuna, hotate, hamachi, aji, and uni. It was good that we ordered uni last, because they were good enough for me to bump this place to 4 stars instead of 3. The rest of the nigiris were good, but not memorable. Rice kinda falls apart a little too easily. 

We also had the crudo with crab and ankimo. Both delicious; both really small. But we should have expected that with the price being only $6. Rock N Roll was very decent. Not overpowered by the sauce like a lot of bad sushi places tend to do. 

$40 for 2 people; a great little gem for dates if you arrive early. Otherwise prepare to wait and test your date's patience.
author: Candice B.

description:
Kua and his team deliver a fun and tasty environment for you and your date. The sake and beer selection is among the best you will find on a menu that list only four of each ... The Orian beer from Okinawa is great!

With no reservations, plan on either grabbing a beer across the street at the Cafe and Art Bar or at Supenkuch for a tasty stein.
author: Christian G.

description:
I've been twice in the last week and i'm a big fan of this place.  Very cozy, great sashimi and spicy tuna roll. They have these great firecracker balls that are fried (obviously) with spicy tuna in the middle...so good.
And it always helps to add sake to the meal.
author: shadi m.

description:
Can I just say.....HELL TO THE YES????

I've lived in this neighboorhood for too damn long with only eating Flippers, Patxi's, and the occasional Hayes Kebab!  It was time to expand my horizons....and my wallet.

This place is rad. Its OOOOBER tiny but I went on a week day right before they closed and it worked out perfectly. The server was super attentive and nice, the sushi....oh my god...the sushi. The best sake sashimi I've ever had. And their rolls? Super fresh with amazing sauces to compliment (I'm a huge condiment fan so when you put sauce on sushi, I'm prob gonna orgasm),

Domo arigato mr. roboto....and this place rocks.
author: Stacy L.

description: Finally tried out this place. Came in on a Sunday evening as soon as they opened at 5:30pm. The reason being is because this place does get crowded and I'd hate to wait. So my hubby and I opted in for an early evening sushi. First thing first, this place is tiny. Bar stools by the sushi bar and by the window. Total of perhaps 20 stools inside and 4 tables outside. It's up to you if you want to sit outside. It's cold in San Francisco. I didn't notice whether they have heater outside. Call me weirdo, but their bathroom was pretty nice and clean. I don't like dirty bathrooms. It's a reflection on the kitchen. So now let's talk about their food, DELICIOUS! Excellent. We truly enjoyed it. Except our my miso soup, it had a hint of dishwashing soap taste to it. Didn't bother to tell the waiter because it was too late, I've ingested the entire soup. We ordered the following: toro nigiri, monkfish, salmon, domo rolls. Everything plus tip came out to be $70. I have no idea why people rank this as $$. We didn't order much and as you see the bill was pretty up there. So I ruled out the $$ to more like $$$. People need to be enlighten on how much $ should be put on there. Lastly, service was good, facilities were clean, parking is terrible. Take the cab here or something or walk. You will never find parking.
author: J C.

description: Lunch specials are not crazy Godzila big, but if you're not starving or obese you'll probably be satisfied with the portion, which is Japanese sized (two items included 3 slices of sashimi and one 3 bite triangle of spicy tuna all over some of the most well prepared rice you'll find in SF).  Iceberg salad was exceptionally plain, but Miso was fresh and tasty. We'll be going back--most likely for dinner so we can pig out, order a bunch of stuff and drink sake without having to go back to work needing a nap.  More to come later....
author: Nobody M.

description: You know that scene in My Cousin Vinny with the "two utes"? Yea, that has nothing to do with Domo. But Domo has good sushi and a relaxing vibe.
author: JimmyDworski o.

description: My favorite neighborhood sushi around. With amazingly fresh fish, great variety, and a quaint atmosphere, Domo is the place to go for sushi. This small restaurant feels cozy and welcoming with it wrap around bar seating and side table for 3.
author: Ryan M.

description: consistently in my top 5 sushi joints in SF.  Everything I've eaten here was excellent.  The wait isn't anywhere near as long as (the-place-that-shall-not-be-named-lest-I-incur-the-wrath-of-fellow-locals) a few blocks away.
author: D D.

description:
FAN-FREAKIN-TASTIC!

The plus: some of the best sushi i've had, feels cozy if you can get a seat at the window, the food, the food, the food, and oh yeah...THE FOOD! 

The minus: requested the hawaiian tuna dish without the squid, brought it with squid, asked for replacement, caught the chef picking it out - NOT COOL!

Try the shitake rolls...loved them. 

Definitely coming back. 3 stars instead of 4 because of squid.
author: Vido E.

description: Fantastic sushi, and sake.  Go here when you want a great neighborhood spot with amazing sushi.
author: Mike W.

description:
Domo sushi was pretty good. The sushi was nothing specatular, but it was fresh and well presented. The space is charming and has a full-capacity of about 17 people (or 20 for wee-tiny people). And for such a small place they had a respectable sake list - YUM! I like that they will be open for lunch - good sushi is hard to find at lunch time. 

I would definitely go back. My recommendation is to try it out for yourseflf, but if you encounter a long wait, take a raincheck (it's not all that) - unless of course you were interested in sampling some sake before dinner =)~
author: Kimberly N.

description:
Domo was my first sushi experience in San Francisco. I've attempted to walk into Eiji and Ino Sushi several times, but they're tiny and always packed. It's been so long I nearly forgot how comforting the smell of a Japanese restaurant is with the fresh fish, green tea, and wood. Mmm, I could eat here every day!

It was lunch time, and I ordered the chirashi which came with an excellent miso soup, and seaweed salad. Overall the fish was very fresh and tasty, although the tuna was fairly low-grade and very fibrous. Since tuna is my standard sushi-ya bellwether I'm wavering between 3 and 4 stars. However Domo's prices were very reasonable, service was great, and they served very high quality green tea. The fish selection was very typical of American sushi restaurants, but Domo also serves more modern "crudos" with interesting combinations of ingredients and sauces. I'd definitely go back, but not before I try Eiji and Ino Sushi.
author: Will A.

description:
Lazy sushi!! Sushi I go to when I am too lazy to go to a better or cheaper place. 

Most of the fish is really quite good. I would advise against the salmon skin and recommend anything made with eel. I also like the small bites and wish that I could make a meal out of those guys. Tasty. The wait is somehow never too long and you can drink a beer outside while waiting. The service is efficient and friendly. 

I go here once a month or so...mostly because I too am lazy.
author: Allegra F.

description:
Miki and I always say we love this place mainly because it's a block away and so convenient. We say that if you were headed to this area to get sushi we'd choose Sushi Zone, but because Domo is right there and there's not the ridiculous amount of wait we often encounter at the Zone, we're very happy. 

For a time Sebo was the only sushi option on the Hayes strip, but that's not an every weekend sushi place. Domo is.

Come by Domo for decent sushi. 

Prices are good.

Generous pours of sake (cold options a-plenty)

and some unique dishes (sexy mama roll!)

Thank you Domo for setting up shop near my house.
author: Timothy P.

description:
This is a really fantastic little sushi spot in Hayes Valley.  Our favorite was the spider roll.  All of their rolls are very inventive and beautifully presented.  We especially loved the generous helping of ginger (some places can be so stingy!).   Their melon mochi is so good!

The place is really, really small.  If you have more than 2 or 3 people, you will probably have to sit outside which could be cold.  We were able to sit right away at a window seat on a Sunday night, which was cool.  The decor is awesome, and the window seats are great for people watching.  And they played really good music in the background.

The service is fast and effective.  Couldn't ask for more.

The price was standard sushi price for the city.  Two hungry people spent about $75 and were well satisfied.  I would come here again.
author: Kimberly H.

description: Whooooaaaa fish tacos, small crudos, and the apollo roll-- how have i neglected you?? Went in last night after a dance class in serious need of caloric restoration; Domo delivered. Fish tacos were incredible-- a first for me on the japanese take: grilled salmon, avocado, salsa, crisp seaweed on tempura platform. The small crudos were elegant spoon-sized bite of sashimi and spice. The Apollo roll-- enormous textural mosiac, topped with perfect grilled scallops. This is the neighborhood joint for us, topping Sebo which for all its organic elegance can't quite fill a belly. Domo shines, after the next round of latin dance i'll be back..
author: Rachel S.

description: Pretty solid sushi - good for a quiet night with a friend. I got the sashimi plate and the sashimi was fresh and quite generous in portion. My friend and I read that the firecracker balls were good so we got those but I really didn't love them. They're fried to such a crisp that you can barely tell what you're eating. My friend pointed out that they taste a little like shu mai or pork dumplings and I've gotta admit, I kind of agreed.
author: Alli J.

description:
After months of having sub par sushi, I finally found my favorite neighborhood sushi joint. 

Sebo? Overpriced and totally not even worth it

Domo? Ecstasy in my motherfreakin' mouth

We started with a couple of crudos -- the crab and the spicy tuna -- more on those later. 

Firecracker balls and spider rolls followed. The firecracker rolls were so good that I almost stabbed my boyfriend with a chopstick when he tried to taste one.

Then we turned our attention to the wall of specials.

The boyfriend ordered grass shrimp -- yummy little fried shrimp that I could just imagine sitting in front of the TV and popping them in my mouth like potato chips. 

I couldn't resist a couple of pieces of fatty tuna nigiri which was amazingly fresh and so buttery. 

Oh but I wasn't finished yet. 

Remember that hella good crudo? I went back in for two more pieces of crab and spicy tuna. 

Screw dessert, just gimme more sushi.
