And after all the sushi I ate and sake I drank, it helped that the place is walking distance from my apartment. I rolled my overstuffed self down the street back to my apartment where I fell into a happy little food coma.
author: Monique W.

description: Urmmmm fire cracker ballz fire u up with goodness and some sweet potatoes roll... A very cute Japanese spot, make sure you go early or else u won't find any sit :)
author: Elsa K.

description:
Sebo is pricey, so Domo is a good alternative for sushi in Hayes Valley.  The sushi/sashimi is fresh and the staff and chefs are friendly and attentive.  The only drawback is the space, it's extremely tight for larger groups but works well for 2-3 people; most people need to sit along the full-wrapping bar. 

There is one larger table inside that can accomodate 5 people. . . but I implore you to leave if you see a group sitting there that looks like the female-version of the "A-Team." One night we headed over there and the women were finishing up.  The waitress kindly let us know that we could have the space as she dropped off the bill.  We waited. . . we waited. . . and we waited.  I have never seen five people take so long to settle the bill. . . they each took out their cellphones to use the tip calculators and divvy up their portion.  The bill went around the table 2.5 times.

No kidding. . . thirty minutes.  Mind you, these were not seniors at the early bird special; they were five young professional women (none of them accountants I presume).  Unless someone ordered a sushi boat of bluefin tuna and did all the drinking, why don't you just split the bill evenly?

Reminds me of the time a co-worker and I went out to lunch and he said he owed $13.22.  Even with the economic turmoil and my current job in the balance, why don't we just each throw in $13 and call it even.
author: E L.

description:
I've got a few staples I use to test a new sushi joint, and Domo executed nearly flawlessly on all of them, as well as having new and wonderful dishes I'd not heard of before.

Their saba, one of my favorite nigiri and a great test of restaurant and chef, was impressive. Soft, lightly acidic, with excellent rich mackerel flavor but no heavy oily fishiness that can happen so easily. It's obviously cured in-house, and quite well. Their ankimo is tasty and the presentation is lovely. It's not too much, either, which is nice for what should be an appetizer. Their hamachi kama is delicious and very generous with the fish. Huge hunks of creamy salty goodness and a piquant dipping sauce. They had hamachi toro, which was fun to try but not as good as bluefin toro. They also had salmon toro baked in salt, which makes for a crispy skinned rich fatty morsel, smoky and salty like pork belly but with much better mouthfeel. Definitely eat the skin right along with the fish. Good rolls with inventive combinations, although a bit heavy on the deep frying.

Service was fast and informative, and the price was right. We three dined well and left full for $95 without tip, including a few beers (no Asahi, but the Asahi Dark was a nice complement to the fatty foods we ordered.)
author: Sean B.

description:
Great, cozy little place with fantastic service and yummy fish! We went to Domo on a Friday night and although we had a 20 or 30 minute wait we just jumped across the street and grabbed a drink there. They took our cellphone down and just called us when the table was ready

What we had:

nigori sake
seaweed salad
raw oysters on half shell
nigiri: hamachi and saba
Rolls: firecracker (yum), spider, domo

We ordered another firecracker at the end because they were so delicious. Also got a free daikon salad from the ultra nice sushi chef. Will definitely be coming back here!
author: Maggie K.

description:
It was one of those typical San Francisco spring days, blue sky, sun shining, wind so freaking cold you might as well be in the Arctic. Luckily, I happened to stumble on Domo right before the hypothermia set in. 

The place is small so I wouldn't go there with a group, perfect for a meal by yourself or one other person.

I had some typical miso soup to warm me up from the above mentioned below zero winds. 

I quite enjoyed the  small crudo and the spider roll. The firecracker balls were good, though I like the ones at Red Box better.

All and all a great addition to the neighborhood.
author: Tara A.

description:
The sushi?  Pretty good but not quite amazingremarkablemindblowing sushi.

The small crudos were tasty and fun, a good choice to for a nice mouthful.

A nice little place, and it's right down the street.
author: Stef A.

description:
I gave Domo five stars not because it was the best sushi I've had in the city, but more because for what it was it was fantastic. And maybe the second best sushi I've had in the city.


My roommate loves this place, says the sushi chef is "cool" and "loves whiskey" so I was sold. Walking in there was great because it reminded me of what I love about good Sushi places, where the bar is the centerpiece and best seat in the house. The second thing that told me I was in for a treat was the specials -- Toro, Aji, and Hamachi neck (a first for me) among others which demonstrate the chef's willingness to pick up exotic yet delicious fish which a place like Sushi Rock may avoid.

Needless to say, the fish was all great. Very fresh, not horribly expensive (Sebo anyone?) and well presented. There were lots of interesting rolls (like the fire cracker balls, a must) and old standbys like their delicious salmon skin roll that made the entire experience a great one. 

For the record, we went at 6:30 and it was empty. We got some one on one with the chef, and the food came out quick. Later on around 7:30 was when it really started to pack in, so I highly recommend getting there a little earlier than usual to avoid a wait. 

Five stars for a classy joint like this one, with great fish, a great atmosphere and great prices.
author: Jeff G.

description:
Yes, they have now fixed the over-flowing sewage pipe that destroyed sidewalk dining for months...

Is Domo great for vegetarians? Not really... The menu is so small! But they more than make up for it in sake and friendliness (two things that often go hand in hand).

I have a great story to share involving the owner and my friend's bed, but I fear Yelp is not the most appropriate venue for such sharing...
author: Trey F.

description:
If I had to find a worse place near Hayes and Laguna Streets; I couldn't do better than Domo for humiliation, terrible attitudes, service and costly meals!  I'll never go back there!  We were in that neighborhood, going to walk over to Van Ness Ave.  I had a friend with me because we were going to the opera and we wanted a fast bite to eat before it would start.  
Domo had wheelchair access, so we went in at 6:10 pm on a Wednesday evening.  (1)  I knew as a wheelchair user I wasn't going to sit at their Sushi Bar, but they moved their cash register a bit, gave me a space of nine inches by 18 inches and put me sideways as if I can eat turning and with my left had when I'm right handed and sideways!  Well, I said in a loud voice, "I'm not going to eat, I'll just have hot tea."  My partner was seated at the left-end stool at their bar. (2) The wheelchair was really disturbing movement in-and-out of their customers, but they made no effort to move us to a table when one was available.  So, I received dirty looks like, "Why did you have to come here?"  I didn't have the time to protest the treatment because of the opera appointment and continued to sit to the left of my partner's stool, like a dog, looking up while they ate. 
(3)  The tea was served in a tall clay-like mug or glass and it was too hot for me to even hold.  At the time to leave; I hadn't even had one sip of tea, so, I asked for a container to take it with me.  I had the plan to sip the tea from a paper cup on the way and before the opera.  No such luck!  Domo has no paper cups and gave me my hot green tea in a clear plastic container; you know, like the ones used for potato salad at the Deli!  I looked them and then at the container:  I saw a doggy-dish which had plastic leaking toxins in to my hot green tea, and I again felt so insulted.  
The Kobi Beef was fair, just ok, nothing special, my guest said.  
One meal with white rice and two teas, close to $30 dollars and filled with contempt for disabled customers!
author: Corinne d.

description:
My husband and I have been back to Domo a few times since May, we live a block away. Each time confirmed my original review. Our fourth trip surprised us both-it was really good!! The fish was fresh and the rolls were tasty. It was like a different restaurant. It was on a Friday night- maybe they get fresher fish for the weekends? Anyway, I will definitely be back!

So....we've been back on various days of the week several times since the update, and I wanted to confirm that it is has been consistently very good. Also, the waitstaff is efficient & friendly
author: Susan D.

description: The good reviews is what tempted me to try this place; However, my experience was terrible!! The chef is not open to suggestions or changes to the menu. The service was terrible- our waiter did not bring us any plates, chopsticks, or menus for at least 10 minutes - we had to wave him down. Then when i asked to add avo to my roll the chef and waiter were not pleased. They charged me an extra $2 dollars. I may give this place another try, but not anytime soon.
author: Harvinder K.

description:
pretty good, domo.
i am very happy you are only 2 blocks away. 
i will nom my way back to you very soon.
author: Michelle K.

description:
i have walked and walked pass this place many times and tonight i finally had dinner there. i have to admit that it's [nigiri] FRESH and yummy. the crudos [salmon] are heavenly but too small! the rolls [spicy tuna and spider] on the other hand ... i could pass. the spicy tuna had too much rice and wasn't that flavorful. i've had much better at other places. 

it's a tiny little place -  seating is very limited. 
the rating is a 3.5 star due to the rolls. i lot Redbox Sushi a whole lot more in the TL.
author: Jocelyn T.

description:
Freshness is all that matters when it comes to sushi.  And Domo has fresh sushi.   

I'm taking away a star because even though the place is  swanky it is tiny.  We were there early, like around 6PM, and there was no wait.  But I'd probably go insane and cranky if I'd have to queue to get in.  Domo also has mostly counter seating and there's only one tiny table that can seat four.

Oh I forgot to mention... definitely try their crudos.  They were very appetizing and tasty.
author: Jun B.

description:
Look on the north side mirror for the daily specials, and if they're serving it order the Aji Tataki.  And you really must eat the deep fried skin and skeleton.  One of the prettiest and tastiest sushi dishes I've ever had.

Decor emphasizes clean lines.  Darker browns surround the properly lit dining area.  One window allows you to watch the Hayes Valley crowd wander, if you don't want to watch the chef.

Went on a Saturday and the place got packed by 7:30.  Great music, too.  Downtempo lounge.  I'll be going back.
author: Bryan R.

description: we came here as a party of 2 on Saturday we put our name in at 6 p.m. Were told that I would take 20 minutes to BE seated. we sat down at 730 expectations were too high given the wait yes the food was still very disappointing the butter fish tasted like its been sitting at room temperature for 3 days the chef at a garnish to try to hide how old the fish was the yellowtail was questionable and 2 hours after the meal my stomach seems to agree this place should be avoided
author: Ryan F.

description: VERY small but definitely worth the wait. We grabbed a beer across the street while we waited for a few seats to open up.  Everything we ordered was delicious!  Firecracker balls, sexy mama roll...you cannot really go wrong here.  Cute spot and looking forward to going back!
author: Emma A.

description: Inventive sushi, cute place, cool staff!  One of my favorite drop-in sushi spots.
author: John H.

description:
This place is small. We're talking one table that fits 3 max and about 8 seats at the counter. However, what it lacks in size it makes up for entirely in its cool factor and fresh and delicious rolls and sashimi. I couldn't believe I didn't know it existed until recent weeks because I only live 3 blocks away! I am STOKED to have a neighborhood sushi joint that is as good as Domo. It's a welcome addition to Hayes Valley! 

The firecracker balls are SO yummy!
author: Arsie J.

description:
one of the best sushi places i've been to -- and also one of the smallest (the bathroom is almost the same size as the restaurant). all bar seating (either at the sushi bar or facing the plate glass window that looks out onto the street.)

came here with a friend who had passed by but never been, and well, that was my first time really in hayes valley (what a cute area!). they have a good variety of rolls (nearing the point of overwhelming, but only because they all sound so good!) and they are priced well for the portion size you get. 

we had the seaweed salad, the domo roll, the salmon skin, the fire cracker balls (not as spicy as you'd think, which is a good thing), the kobe beef, and one more that i can't remember. all tasted incredibly fresh (i don't know sushi very well, but you could just tell). the main reason i'm not giving it five stars is that there was a slight overwhelming taste to everything. for most of the dishes, it was salty. for one of the rolls (again, forgot which :( ), it was too cilantro-y. i'm thinking it was just me, though, as just thinking about these again, i'm salivating (and not because i'm imagining salt!).

that said, however, i would gladly go again -- and go out of my way to go again. service was excellent (maybe because we got there at 5:30) and fast. very cute, warm space.
author: Jonathan K.

description: Wow. Exceeded expectations and highly worth the 30 minute-ish wait outside on a crisp San Francisco spring evening. We were a group of 4 and enjoyed a lovely table for 4 in this cozy place. I think the rest of the seating is bar seating. Every roll and sashimi plate we had was better than the last. Awesome sake, great service. Perfect meal. Those sushi "balls" are a must, by the way. Not cheap, but worth every penny.
author: Anne Y.

description:
Domo makes such good sushi--and if you live in the neighborhood, it's a best bet for sure. 

It's a little small, like most of the reviews point out, but they do takeout.

I recommend the rainbow roll and spider roll, but I've had almost everything on the menu and it's all so good. You can't go wrong!
author: SF I.

description: Loved the crudos.  Nigiri tasted really fresh, as did the raw rolls.  I wasn't so down with the signature roll (Domo), which was baked with a very sweet teriyaki style sauce.  Lots of interesting looking rolls on the menu to come back for, including one with American Kobe beef.  The restaurant is almost completely bar seating and thus probably better for singles and groups of two.
author: Erika H.

description: great sushi, small place, chefs & staff are super nice
author: Yury T.

description: Super DISSAPPOINTED in this place. I came here for dinner around 6:30 and put our name on the wait list. The lady told me to write my phone number on the list. I clearly wrote our number down to call us when a table was ready. Waited out in the cold for over half an hour in the freezing cold. We come back only to find our names crossed off the list. We walked in and the lady looked as us then literally gave away two seats right in front of us. She then proceeded to say she called us and no answer. I showed her my phone and the lack of calls. They didn't care. There was a table open, but only for three people. So two people you just overlooked didn't matter? They told us to wait for the next table like it was our fault we had to wait in the cold for a call that never came. We went to the One Sushi and Lounge, great sushi and service. Just a couple blocks away. My recommendation goes there. People who don't appreciate the customers don't deserve them.
author: Luis P.

description:
If they had 1.5 I would grant.  I eat at a lot of sushi places and usually only write about very good or very bad.  This is the latter.

If you frequent Sushi Zone don't even walk in.  You will only leave angry.  Unfortuntly I had high hopes for this place and dont understand why people like it.  It's about as bad as sushi can get in SF.

Issues:

1) I asked to see a Sake list and was told it only came by the glass.  I asked if they had small 300 ml. bottles but was told no.   As I'm eating I see people being served small bottles.  What gives.

2) They didn't have any sushi combo - I'm usually not a big fan of the Sushi Combos but typically they are a good deal are represent a sushi joint well.  Thus I got a Rainbow Roll.  Big mistake.  It was one of the worst I'd eaten.  It literately tasted like a caned Tuna Fish sandwich on Wounder Bread.  Tons of Mayonnaise and fish parts. Yuck.

3)  I order a few pieces of sushi but the portions were micro.  Secondly much of the fish was pre-cut in the display case.  Thats always a troubling sign.   I have never seen such small cuts.  The fish was fresh but the sizes were about half of must places and about 1/3 of Sushi Zone.

4) Service was fair at best.

Bill $70

I'll never go back
author: David C.

description:
I loved their rolls! Couldn't get enough, and my friend and I ended up ordering 3 rolls, and 3 different Nigiris. To start out, we had the hot sake, always a must, when chatting about dirtbag guys and catching up with friends.  Then came the edemame, which were always a plus. Edamame is always good when they aren't overcooked, slightly crunchy and mildly salty. On to the rolls. My favorite was definitely the spider roll, it was so light but incredibly flavorful. Next on my list would be the crunchy california roll, which was great! The roll was a little hot when we received it, so we let it cool down for a minute, but then.....nothing but a fiesta in my mouth!
Our third roll was the Spicy Hulk...a variation of the spicy tuna roll. It also was delicious, but a little big to eat in one bite. More like 3 bites. Ok, so finally we got around to the nigiri, because we were still hungry after the three rolls. We ordered the scallop, salmon and tuna rolls. They were all really fresh, which is what makes or breaks the whole experience. It's easy to spot day-old fish, and there was none of that here. Loved the little bar facing the street, and the music was really great. Even though I was talking and talking with my friend throughout the meal, I paused and enjoyed the great mix of house/lounge-esque music in the background.

The waitstaff were really nice, and patient as it took us a while to decide what we finally wanted to order. Definitely coming back soon!
author: Alyssa G.

description: I tried the jalapeno hashami, and the salamon avocado lemon rolls. They were both delicious! Their take out is also extremely quick, and seems to be a good alternative especially on busy nights. Definitely planning on coming back here to try the rest of the items on their menu.
author: C P.

description: I really love sushi.  I loved the fish here.  Just really, really delicious really, really fresh fish.  I also love sunomono with tako and most places over cook it, but not Domo.  People who think they don't like octopus often dislike the very chewy texture, but if it's done well, it's not rubbery.  Just sayin.  One other thing, they didn't have fresh wasabi the night I was there, but the waitress said to ask for it b/c frequently they do have it.
author: Emily T.

description:
went here on a first date... i have this sneaking suspicion that almost half of the success of that date can be attributed to Domo. the sushi was some of the best i have had in a long time. even though it's a small place it doesn't feel cramped. it's a quality place without all the hip nonsense you can get in hayes valley sometimes.

edit: spicy balls make it 5 stars.
author: Ashley A.

description: This is my favorite place for sushi.  Small and intimate, quiet and non pretentious.  They're sashimi is always perfectly fresh and melts in your mouth.  The specials change regularly and always get rave reviews from friends.  For the quality of food the prices are great, especially in San Francisco.
author: Kelesa S.

description:
Best sushi, hands down.  Everyone I have taken here falls in love with this place. 

Very fresh, fast and friendly.  Prices are good too compared to other places.   The chefs are so fun to watch and there is one there that is so cute.  He talks to you while he is creating these little art pieces.  They play good music and it is just a fun experience. 

Why are they outstanding?  Firecracker balls, Fiesta roll, Mango and black pepper

For the vegans: veggie croquettes, seaweed salad, sweet potato roll, shitake roll and the veggie roll.  OMG the veggie roll is so good!   It has all the different flavors that come together in the roll, just like sushi should.  

You will leave very happy and be back very soon.
author: Viola B.

description:
As far as sushi goes, this restaurant has very little selection and high prices.  Rolls tasted good, but it's the most expensive spicy tuna I've ever had.

The atmosphere is cozy, as the restaurant is very small.  Might work for a date if you want to spend a lot and not eat much.
author: Adam K.

description: Love the atmosphere here. And the staff is very nice. However, the rolls are very small - especially for the price. And every time I've been to Domo, the fish was not very fresh.
author: Kori M.

description: Solid raw fish/japanese restaurant in the cute Hayes valley area. the place isn't big but can accommodate roughly 20 people. It's pretty much bar sitting all around w/ one table for four. What I found most interesting on the menu was their small crudo. Two for $6. The rolls were thoughtful (i.e. nice pairing and made w/ quality fish). The sashimi was good. I guess I am only giving it three stars because they weren't so special that I would recommend making a special trip here if you weren't already in the area.
author: Lisa C.

description: I heart Domo! Dig the small space, great service, cool sushi chefs, delicious fresh fish, affordably priced, what more could you ask for? Totally loved the small crudo bites. The uni crudo is fantastic, we kept ordering it over and over again. Also loved the spicy tuna, scallop and ankimo crudos. Super delicious. I'm hooked. Will totally be a regular.
author: Sarah R.

description:
The food is always fresh, always really YUMMY. The first time we were there we splurged nearly $200 (for two) but it was so WORTH it. It's Intimate, great ambiance, great food, great for a date night.

I have no idea why people would ever compare Suppenkuche (which I also love) to this place! Two totally different places! If you are local and  tired of the noisy crowds at Suppenkuche, and most importantly, if you are craving some really good sushi, you will go to Domo.
author: Victoria A.

description:
What a jewel !! The food and service was outstanding. Get there before 7pm to avoid the crush of waiting people.  Awesome space of what used to be a small art gallery - would not go with more than 2 people- the seating is not condusive to groups.

THE ONLY COMPLAINT - my clothes still  stink of grill or deep fryer - left my clothes saturated with smell of cooked food... minus 1 star until better ventilation.
author: miguel p.

description:
Stopped by this Hayes Valley spot for dinner tonight. I was pleasantly surprised to see the sushi chefs behind the counter were actually Japanese. So rare to find nowadays. I sat with friends behind the counter that was looking out onto the street which was comfy for people gazing. 

To start, I ordered the Uni and Scallop crudos (choose two for $6). Both were good, but I thought the avocado on the uni competed a bit too much for my attention. I would have liked to have been able to taste the uni more. I also tried the inari nigiri and the ajitsuke hotate nigiri off the specials menu. If you like scallop, I would definitely recommend the ajitsuke hotate. It was really yummy.  My friends and I also tried a few rolls: fire cracker balls and sexy mama. The fire crackers balls had a great crunch and if you like spicy, this should satisfy. The sexy mama roll was different than I expected - very refreshing. The crunch of the asparagus was great, but finished off with the yuzu cucumber and lemon slice, it was definitely something unexpected. I finished off my meal with some black sesame ice cream. Nothing too special, but definitely different if you want to veer off the usual green tea ice cream path.

All in all, the food was reasonably priced, tasted good, and the atmosphere was comfy and relaxing. This is a great neighborhood spot.
author: Daphne R.

description: This place is phenomenal. Takes sushi to a whole new level. Not the healthiest sushi I've ever had (lot of deep fried things) but really amazing flavors, lots of spice, and overall excellent food.
author: E T.

description:
Domo has great fish. I've gotten take-out from them frequently, and I've never been disappointed. Seating is so tight that I've never bothered trying to get a seat -- it's a cozy sushi bar, but since I live in the area, take-out is much easier.

The tasmanian trout has been spectacular lately; I also like the Sexy Mama roll. Rolls, nigiri, and sashimi are all splendid. Beverages are good, if uninteresting.
author: Landish D.

description: Sushi was good.  A bit small for the price, but maybe thats me being from a place that is not san fran and I expect to be full after a meal that costs $40. We made the mistake of sitting outside, where afterr 7pm it got pretty cold. But it was a fun place.
author: Duncan R.

description: This is one of the few sushi places with a rice-less and seedless roll! It's the cucumber wrapped roll, but I'm not remembering its name.
author: Jesse C.

description:
this is a hidden gem in the hayes valley!!!  the dishes are simple but executed with such style and robust traditional flavors... the firecrackers are a must try and some how his toro sashimi is one of the freshest ive ever had... it just melts in your mouth!!! i would highly recommend this spot because after talking to the owner and learning about his culinary background, he has worked with and for some of the greatest chefs and establishments, which i will not name drop because what he does is his own style... much props to domo!!!




although i must leave an apology to the chef and owner, kuo. I got really drunk there and made an ass outta myself during the after hours... i feel really bad and i want you to know i meant no disrespect...
author: Nic M.

description: I am really not sure what the fuss is all about. I went here for lunch, so maybe lunch isn't as great as dinner or something but the food was . . .bland. How can spicy tuna be bland? Yet somehow it was. The service was great but there are far better sushi places in the city.
author: Sarcastic T.

description: Adorable little Hayes Valley sushi joint.  Though I am mostly vegetarian, once in a great while I will have a few bites of sushi.  This sushi was definitely worth the compromise!  I recommend the salmon, avocado roll with a delicious hint of lemon as well as the fish tacos (not really tacos but a very original creation).  The salmon sashimi was amazing, melt-in-your-mouth and savor-the-moment good.  We also had seaweed salad, a few other rolls, and a combination of sesame and green tea ice cream for dessert -- all of which were excellent.  Oh, and try the unfiltered sake, it's called creme de sake.
author: Celeste A.

description: this place went wayyyyyyyyyyyyyyy DOWNHILL from where it was few years back (when Kua, the original owner, was running the show) . I came back after a while and had the *lunch special*. the portion was seriously microscopic while the price went up 50%. the unagi was actually tasty and the service was nice, but the salmon was *borderline* at best. VERY, VERY disappointing experience. don't think i will be back.
author: Jarda B.

description:
I went here after around 6ish and pretty easily found a spot to sit.  It's a small place, so if you were to go when there was a line, it might take a while; the place seems to only seat 15 people or so.  I wasn't very impressed with the food at all.  The fish wasn't very fresh at all and I just didn't care for the spicy tuna.  The roll was huge, however, so if you're the kind of guy (or gal) who prefers quantity to quality, you might enjoy yourself.

All in all, the place is over hyped.  Give it a shot as it is relatively affordable, but don't expect much.  Bad fish!
author: Jerry T.

description: I wanted to let people know about Domo, an fantastically creative, if small, sushi restaurant. The owner is usually behind the bar, working with another sushi chef. The sushi is always extremely fresh, the rolls are creative and the warmth and generosity of the restaurant are apparent from all who work there. You will only find sushi of this quality in a couple of places in all of san francisco. I do miss the owner's brother, who has other things to attend to these days. He was also an excellent sushi chef. No reservations are taken, and I have no reservations about insisting you go directly to Domo, do not pass go~!
author: daniel k.

description: Mmhmm, beer at Suppenkuche and then stroll down the street to this teency weency sushi bar for some scrumptious sushi. Firecracker Balls live up to their hype, Domo Roll was dank, and the Spicy Hulk was a keeper as well. They have changing "specials" of which were all pretty good. I added Jalapenos to a "Dragon Domo" roll they have, and the chefs appreciated my recommendation...so next time I'm expecting to see the Matt's Dragon Domo Roll gracing the menu! Arigato!
author: Matt D.

description: I literally stumbled upon Domo in search of a place to eat in Hayes Valley and have been a huge fan ever since. It is truly a hidden find! Everything on the menu is amazing but the firecracker balls are a must have. The space is a bit small so not great for large parties but perfect for a dinner for two. Enjoy!
author: Ursula R.

description: Love, love, love this teensy little spot. A gem of a sushi restaurant squeezed in amongst a slightly off-the-main-drag Hayes Valley block. The place is pretty much all counter stools. The specials are written on the mirrored wall. And the food is phenomenal. Don't go with a group unless you're willing to sit outside (it's the only area that can really seat more than 2 people next to each other), but do go.
author: Shoshana D.

description:
oh my fucking god, kuowha.  seriously.

that was some NEXT. LEVEL. SHIT.

the ultimate omakase tonight.  the fresh, live lobster sashimi style presented on the shell was out of control.  the new & improved fish taco. the seared toro sashimi. the domo ceviche with scallops, octopus, and snapper. the luxurious return of the live scallops. and last, but certainly not least... the juicy, sweet, and absolute show stopping appearance of the wagyu beef, in all it's ultra marbled glory. this was truly the grand finale, and i even opted for a second order instead of wrapping things up with some monkfish liver or black sesame ice cream. there's a reason this shit is $90 a pound.... they were absolutely the best pieces of beef that have ever been in my mouth. goddamn. please get more, kuowha.

please.
author: George C.

description: I think it'd be the perfect lunch spot on a beautiful day, when you can enjoy the lunchtime happy hour in peace.  I'll be back when I don't have to swing back to work afterward.  Clean, tasty rolls.
author: Leo C.

description:
I love this place. The sushi is consistently good and the service has been friendly and helpful each time I've been there. 

I am a big fan of baked rolls and the more traditional and they have a large selection of both. 

What I also like is that this place is small and not a lot of people know about it so the longest I've ever had to wait is 30 minutes for a seat. 

There is only one table so it's not a good place for a group larger than 3-4 people but it's great to go with a friend and sit at the sushi bar or at the window bar and grub out.
author: Yelper S F.

description:
How have I not discover ed this little gem at an earlier time in life? It is so quaint and cute, the wait staff all cute and nice. 

The food is more on the simple and clean side, elegant and understated in presentation but don't be fooled, the food is amazing in your mouth. All of the fish is so fresh and succulent. The rolls range from fancy tempura rolls covered with fish, to more simple presentations. I like everything Ive had and I like that the flavors keep their integrity, the rolls arent too complex and overdone. The miso soup and little dishes are amazing too, and surprising Domo is very reasonably priced.

I love this area of hayes valley, and continue to frequent Domo whenever I get that urge.
author: Jared B.

description:
what is not to like about this place.  we happened on it last spring.  new to neighborhood less than a year.  truly a neighborhood eatery.  Owner "Kohua" (not sure spelling) is the man.  a creative artist in the dishes.  best to sit at sushi bar if you can and watch a master at work.  While we ate mostly off the menu, we watched him prepare some special delicacies for a freind.  WOW.. this is Sushi at its best.  thought I was in Japan.
the fish is fresh and tasty.  the servers attentive and freindly.  Hope we can get a seat next time in the city.
author: Kent W.

description:
really good, really fresh sushi.  they've got some pretty original rolls with unique flavor and amazing fish.  good service too. 

it's a small space, but really charming and not too cramped - get one of the seats looking out the window.
author: Tara H.

description: Great new addition to Hayes Valley! For such a tiny place, it delivered in a big way. It did a great job of maximizing their limited space by having mostly counter seating, one row in front of the window and one row at the sushi bar. They also added a couple small tables outside. I popped in here with a friend on a random weekday and they had a short waitlist. We grabbed a couple chairs outside and we were immediately greeted by a waiter asking if we'd like a glass of wine or beer while we waited. Way to show their A-game! Once we were seated, we ordered the sashimi combination and a couple rolls, including their signature Domo roll. Everything was fresh, delicious, and QUICK! They already seemed to figure out how to maximize profits by shuffling customers in and out. I couldn't find a single thing wrong with my experience so congratulations, Domo, five stars!
author: Susan L.

description: everything is good here. one of my fave places to eat and talk with a friend. intimate place, nice atmosphere, delicious and authentic rolls and some creative 'crudos'. Prolly not good for groups. again, GREAT FOOD.
author: Aimee F.

description: domo arigato mr roboto.. sorry but had to do it. this place a pretty nice place even tho its small. the rolls are fresh and tasty but the selection is pretty small. but i guess thats ok since what they do have is nice and fresh and done really well. the spicy hulk is a super good roll. usually i dont really like cucumber in my sushi but this one is all fish wrapped in cucumber and it gives sushi a really fresh and clean taste
author: edward k.

description: I went here on a Saturday evening, with a date.  It was cozy and we only waited 10 minutes to get a seat.  The sushi was amazing and unique.  We had the Spicy Hulk roll....the cucumber slices around it was amazing.  The service was quick and friendly.  I would definitely recommend checking this place out!
author: Erin D.

description:
Taiwanese owned......... I can hear them gossiping while making my sushi.... 

The sashimi is fresh and the rolls suck. I'm not sure what else I should say. Clean bathroom. 

Would I come back? yeah, I'm not quite sure why...
author: L w.

description:
Tried Domo for lunch one day and was enticed by the great, inexpensive lunch menu.  Overall, an OK sushi joint that is well priced...but not really worth going back to.

Bad start:  When we ordered the small crudo with scallops on a little porcelain spoon, I was dismayed to see that we were being presented with torched/seared scallop -- a sure sign that they were using less-than-fresh scallop.  It tasted OK, but I like my scallops raw. 

OK ending:  I had the sashimi on seaweed salad.  At $12, it includes miso soup and salad, which is nice.  The fish was fresh and the salad was nicely dressed.  Nothing that amazing to speak of.  The husband had chirashi, which is sashimi on a bed of rice.  The rice was cold and we were missing the classic bento box presentation of chirashi.  Again, nothing offensive about the fish and it did seem fresh.  We were still hungry, however, and ordered a good Rock-n-Roll (avocado + eel roll) which was pretty good.

Weird Service:  While they weren't rude, they weren't necessarily the friendliest.  And our interactions were kind of awkward.  I found it weird that they didn't greet a solo guest who walked through the door for like 5 minutes.  The sushi chef clearly saw him walk through and didn't make an effort to greet him or to let the host know that another guest had arrived...so strange.
author: J O.

description: This place fairly good. Makes a variety of rolls of different flavors. My roll of choice: Spicy Hulk. Great prices, but small restaurant.
author: Lisa C.

description: This is one of the best places in SF.  I take out of town guests here.  The setting and food is fantastic.  It is perfect for 2 people or 4 maximum.  It is not good for big parties.  The dragon roll is the best I have had here.
author: Duanne G.

description: My friend and I found this interesting small restaurant in the Hayes corridor.  We both ordered appetizers to test the place.  I had the albacore starter.  The fish did not look or taste fresh.  Luckily the order was very small.  My friend had the eel appetizer.  It also was a very small plate with a very small portion of a mediocre piece of eel.  We did not stay to order entrees.
author: irwin s.

description: Cute fun atmosphere. Looking out the window seating is nice. Yum yum baby I am a uni lover must get the uni crudos "small spoon" For sat night was in quick n food served fast just the way I like it:) will be back!
author: Crystal M.

description: Domo is good, but it did not rock my world.  The pieces are on the small side and it isn't exactly cheap.  However, I am glad to see them in the neighborhood and I hope they stick around.
author: joe b.

description:
We arrived early, waited outside with other anxious diners and at 5:30, grabbed two seats in front of the chef - not from Japan, but may be second or third generation?  He was already busy, and ably supported by his Latino assistant, but they did not exude much personality .  No interplay. OK... but that's part of a true sushi bar experience (and price!).

OK, here's where Mr. Excitable has it right. It's not an authentic  Japanese place. It did look like a casual neighborhood joint in Tokyo, but it's an American approximation, and I'd assume that being in the neighborhood and getting cast-off's from Suppenkuche and Sebo helps to keep their seats filled. There are countless "authentic" Japanese places in and around San Francisco, but of course it depends on whether you want to Hang in a Hip neighborhood, and then find sustenance, or if you are in search of authentic dishes. If you are, try Eiji, or Tanuki. Japanese people can be seen frequenting these places, if you go by that old rule....

I would probably go to Domo more if I lived in the neighborhood, but that is the key. I'll remember the place when and if I go to Hayes Valley, and won't be disappointed. But I'll keep my eye open for other "new" places around town to try, too.
author: KC J.

description: I like Domo - seating is scarce with mostly bar seats and 2 tables.   The service was good, quality was good, price was a little high for the serving size, its really closer to a 3.5 but it ai't an option - I DO like you Domo but in comparison to other 4 star places you just are not quite there..
author: Rick R.

description: I'm not entirely sure how I managed not to eat here before last night, but what a delight.  The sushi is inventive, plentiful, delicious and service is quick.  I can't believe how many times I have walked around Hayes Valley wanting sushi and not realizing this little dream was there.
author: Caroline K.

description: Unbelievably good sushi!!  Such a cute little restaurant.  Came here from a yelp recommendation and we were more than pleased.  Super nice staff but more than anything, the sushi was excellent.  Very fresh and incredible flavors.  Can't wait to go back again!!
author: Kathleen T.

description: This place is so cute and the sushi was awesome!  The place is very small and always seems to be steadily busy even on week nights. We usually just have to wait a few mins.   It's really a great date place or a place to go with one other person. I would not recommend going there with a big group.  The miso and spicy tuna are my favorite!
author: Leslie M.

description:
first of all, i want to say that the one star isn't about the food. 

the food i'd say is very mediocre. the rolls we got were alright, the salmon sashimi was alright, and the uni nigiri was good. but all the other nigiris we got, seriously the quality of the sashimi is not much better than stale safeway sushi... the edamame was good. price is average in SF. total 60 dollars before tips. i would recommend going to o-toro which is only a couple of blocks away. the quality of the fish is so much better.

now the really bad part was this one waiter. we got there around 7 or 7:30, the guy said there is one couple before us. didnt sound so bad right? so we put our name down.

then we waited patiently...

during this wait, a couple of things i've noticed. first, there were people waiting for seats, but this waiter would talk to people at this one table for 10 minutes about who knows what, leaving people who were waiting for their bill waiting, and people who were waiting for tables waiting...  second, i keep seeing people get seated and at some point i realize 4 parties had been seated since we arrived (and this was 8:30 or so). at this point, he called our name, but instead let others take the table. so i went up to the guy and asked 'hey when is gonna be our turn?' the guy said, next  is ours. i said, you told me there is only one couple before us, but now you are crossing off people (on the waiting list) that came after us...,  and the guy asked 'do you want me to ask them to leave?' of course i said no... even more ridiculous, he said 'i've never seen you before, i didnt talk to you earlier and said you are second in line'..... ok for a second i thought i was crazy, but my bf confirmed it was him this whole time...

then we got seated, and another girl waited on our table. she was nice, and took our order quickly (we were starving). the sushi all came quickly but a while after we finished, we still didnt see the edamame, so we asked. she said she was very sorry, and would take the edamame off the bill... but when the bill came, she didn't. but that is ok.

very unpleasant. wasted almost 70 dollars.
author: Danielle A.

description: Some wonderfully delicious sushi. I love their sweet potato roll. The place is well designed, quaint, and has great music. The staff is really nice and helpful. Not sure I would go there with more than 1 other person because it's all bar seating except for 1 inside table and a couple outside. But the bar makes for great people watching if face the window.
author: Michael H.

description: Delicious and very fresh. With so many sushi bars around, this one stands out because everything we ordered tasted very fresh. The fish at Domo was melt-in-your-mouth good. The firecracker balls were awesome. Tons of flavor and great texture. Thank goodness they have Asahi Black here because my partner and I love dark beers but always get bummed at Japanese restaurants because they usually only carry light Japanese beers that taste watery and dull. Service was very nice. Food came out fast! We got in at the best time, right after the pre-symphony dinner rush. I highly recommend going there around 8pm on symphony/opera nights.
author: Foodie F.

description: Good Sushi! This is a great place for a first date or chilling with a friend. The wait staff and chefs are the best part of this place. When we were there the chef was teaching one of the bus boys about making sushi rolls. There was a lot of laughter and good times goin' on. it's a pretty small place so it's great for bringing a date, you can enjoy a nice intimate but not intimidating setting. Great for Sat. Night Dates! My husband and I had a lot of fun hanging out with each other and being amused by the incredibly friendly and entertaining staff.
author: Amanda A.

description: Fantastic fish at very reasonable prices.  Spare yourself the disappointment of a meal at Sebo and march straight here.  Domo features a creative and unique menu with none of that California Roll nonsense, either.  The only drawback is that there is virtually no table seating so if you want to sit down and eat, you're best off showing up as a party of two and no more than three, so plan accordingly.
author: Ping C.

description:
We started out with the cucumber sunomono which was nice and refreshing.

We then had the kobe steak roll with asparagus.  The meat was so smooth and tasty.  We then had the sexy mama which was also very tasty.  Each roll came conveniently cut in 8 smaller bites.

We had hamachi belly and trout which were good.  The veggie croquette was also very nice.

We had a nice bottle of $10 sake.

All in all a very good meal in hayes valley.  It was $65 with tip, otherwise I would have rated it 4 stars.
author: Brian L.

description:
Update From Previous Post
So I made it back to Domo and consumed more than black sesame ice-cream this time. The place was just as charming and the staff just as warm and welcoming. The sushi was solid and decently priced. There are better sushi joints at this price-point, but I'm a lady and a true lady doesn't give away all her secrets....
Bottom line, I'll be back for more. I hope that Domo and I have a long future together. We probably won't ride off into the suset together, but it will certainly be a regular booty call.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I go to a sushi place and all I had was ice-cream... I don't even recognize myself anymore!
The b/f and I were headed to Apollo to get our Mitchell's ice-cream fix and decided to pop by this new sushi joint to check out the menu. Keep in mind that we'd just eaten very overpriced (though delicious) sushi at Tsunami. Domo's menu instilled none of the sticker shock that Tsunami does. As we stood outside discussing the soonest time we could make our way back to Domo, one of the owners came out and introduced himself. This lovely guy invited us in to have a look, and WOW the place is cute as a button! We told him we were just headed out for ice-cream and he offered that we try the black sesame ice-cream. Okay, for those who haven't tried BLACK SESAME ICE CREAM, lemme just say, this is the SH**! We also shared a bowl of green tea ice-cream (equally yummy). And all on the house! Welcome to the neighborhood, Domo! Now that you've fed this stray, you may never be rid of me!
author: Michelle D.

description: Its finally open, and fortunately it was worth the wait. Very good fish, the crudos are tasty and unique, and the atmosphere and service are good. Prices aren't super cheap but are pretty reasonable. The wait can be long in the evenings because its so small, so writing your name down and  getting some coffee at momi tobis or some beer at suppenkuche is probably a smart play. They'll serve you drinks in Domo while you wait, but theres nowhere extra to sit down (yet?).
author: Dan M.

description: I would not recommend this place. It's very small , almost entirely comprised of seating at the bar which lines the whole restaurant. There is a 3 top, which was empty when we arrived however we were refused seating because our party only had 2 people. Instead we were squeezed into a tiny space at the bar, I was seated next to a very large male who kept invading my space by leaning into me. The whole meal was spent with my arms and shoulders tucked in. We rushed our meal in order to escape. When we left the 3 top was still open and there was 2 parties of 2 waiting to be seated! Our meal was extremely average. They have three rolls (yes I like rolls) on the menu with shiso in them, so possibly I would give another star because I really like shiso, however the rolls were so average and over priced I'll keep it at 2. The miso soup was gross and the seaweed salad certainly came from a bag. It was very bland and served warm, so that was fairly unpleasant. I had a glass of sauvignon blanc, 8 dollars, and not very good. The waiter got my bf's beer wrong. Overall it was 50 dollars before tip to be served average rolls in an uncomfortable rushed environment, our order was wrong and the restaurant was hot! Way to hot for a place serving raw fish. There are most certainly better sushi spots, I would not return.
author: jen w.

description: Read all about the Firecracker Balls, and was not disappointed.  They were pretty amazing.  It is a cute and cozy place with a good selection of rolls.  Worth a stop if you are in the neighborhood.
author: Bryan E.

description: This place is so yummy.  They have unique rolls that are to die for.  A little pricy, but if you just want to slowly nibble - this is the place.  Domo only fits about 30 people MAX, but it makes for a quiet meal.  I would like to try their lunch menu... oh and the place across the street looks pretty good...
author: S L.

description:
I've been to this place many times. It's now my de facto neighborhood sushi place to go to whenever I want decent sushi and don't want to leave the hood. 

This is a tiny place (there are only about 20 seats total) and it's all bar seating. Tiny as it is, it's very comfortable and intimate. The low lighting and unobtrusive service make it a perfect place to have a great meal and catch up with a good friend. I've noticed that most of the people here are neighborhood peeps. Some come with their date or one other friend (due to the seating arrangements) and get lost in their own world and conversation. Very charming. 

I'm a little bit of a sushi/sashimi snob, so I'll have to say that the fish is fresh enough, though definitely not the top grade kind of fish served by the truly authentic Japanese restaurants who buy their fish from the markets in Japan. That said, it's still definitely good. Ive had their kampachi cappachio, all the crudos (salmon, spicy tuna, scallops, uni, etc), all the sashimis (standard fare of salmon, maguro, hamachi and albacore) and they are all good. I'm not a fan of the Fire Cracker Balls that most people like though. It's nothing special. Oh, and one time, they served me my miso soup with a spoon in it!!! What? Miso soup with a spoon? That's definitely NOT Japanese, and it threw me off a bit. But no worries, I just took out the spoon and proceeded to drink my soup from the bowl-the way it's supposed to! All in all, I still love this place. Mostly for the casual but charming atmosphere. That's important too when evaluating restaurants, right?
author: Selena L.

description: This is the best and most friendly sushi place in San Francisco. I got to meet the owner of the place and he was very customer oriented. He prepares sushi with great cares and listens actively to customer feedback. It is a nice little sushi shop to enjoy your evening with great crowd.
author: Jason L.

description:
the one and only liz s and i came here a few months ago for a quick and early dinner.  i must say, it was good that we arrived there early, because half an hour into our meal, a line was formed!

one of the unique things about this place was their "crudos" - think amuse bouche-sized tastes.  i'm normally not a big uni fan, but their uni was great, as was the salmon one.  

we also shared a couple rolls, including the spicy tuna and sexy mama.  both were well-executed, fresh, and most importantly, tasty!

i look forward to coming to domo again, and trying more of their interesting offerings.  thanks for sharing with me, liz!
author: Jill k.

description: very similar to o-toro, but slightly more expensive.  in comparison to o-toro, it's at a better location, but is smaller.
author: Shirley Z.

description:
Where to begin....  My first time at Domo I wasn't terribly impressed, but it's been consistently awesome every time I went back.  I guess I figured out the right things to order.
Those things would be: The Fiesta Roll (not on the menu, currently written on the wall - get there before it goes away!)  Salsa and mango in sushi?  Absurdly good.
Crispy spicy tuna (also not on the menu): holy crap.  $9.60 of intense flavor and great textures!  Comes on an extra long plate, and the pieces of the roll barely fit into my mouth.  It's super filling and very indulgent.  
The nigiri is always very good and fresh tasting.  I've tried to be more adventurous in my fish consumption - the Tazmanian Trout is a new favorite.
The Spicy Hulk roll is fun and tasty.  Using cucumber as a wrapper is inventive and I wanted to lick the sauce off the plate.
The Rock and Roll is a good standard unagi roll.
The Jalepeno Hamachi is another good combo - I really like the bright flavor of the pepper mixed with the fish.
My vegetarian friend has good things to say about the veggie stuff.  We both like the edamame.  
The service is brisk and efficient.  I prefer the female server we've gotten the past few times over the guy who served my friend and I tonight.  
Can't wait to keep eating my way through the Domo menu!
author: Kat M.

description: The lunch specials are a deal! You can get the sushi combo with the spicy tuna roll and 4 different types of nigiri for about 12$ or the Chirashi lunch special. The sashimi is fresh. I particularly enjoyed the tasmanian trout, which practically melts in your mouth. The Hamachi belly was succulent and for the price, well worth it! My friends love the firecracker balls although I still haven't tried it yet. Take out is efficient and the fish still tastes fresh. The restaurant is small but cosy. They get full quickly so I would call ahead to see how long the wait is.
author: bronwyn h.

description:
The firecracker balls were really good. Pretty heavy on the sauces. The kobe beef roll tastes strange with the avocado and asapragus together I wouldnt order this again. The rock and roll was really boring too. The ahi poke appetizer was so delicious! I didn't want to share with my friend. this place is kinda pricey. we each paid about $27 for 4 small dishes.

Won't be back again. Too far of a trek.
author: Crum B.

description: The sushi rolls are quite tasty but not spectacular. Small place which seats about 15. Long waits also.
author: Prescott T.

description:
I've been on Sushi hiatus for several years.  Due to a series of circumstances, I've dove back into eating sushi about 2 months ago.  Sushi Domo is the best sushi restaurant I have been to since I re-entered the sushi fray.  Mind you, that I have been to most sushi restaurants in Japan town and Sushi Domo tops them all easily.  I have experienced nothing but fresh, ample cuts in my nigiri and rolls (I've been 4 times in two weeks).  I order sake by the glass, generally $7-$9.  And Domo's glass is more like a miniature carafe.  Not huge, but larger than "glasses" at many sushi joints I've visited.   

As mentioned in other reviews, the place is a wee on the wee side.  But I haven't waited for more than 10 minutes to sit.  Any wait is worth it for me.  At this point, I'm only interested in trying Ebisu so see if it stacks up to Domo.  Otherwise Domo is my new sushi home.
author: Micah T.

description: Wow, this is a great addition to the neighborhood.  My impression is possibly enhanced by the great day in GG park under the sun, but the fish was so nourishing.  Sunazuri (yellowtail belly), maguro, and albacore was great.  The crudos were well worth it, I had the monkfish liver and the salmon.  Both had great taste and were presented beautifully.  I love shiso, so the spicy tuna roll was perfect for me.  The guys behind the counter and friendly and interactive, not stand-offish like some places.  They offer you some off the menu things if you butter them up a little.  Service for water or tea refills could be hard to get.  For the price, this is a good find.  Its not a destination restaurant, but if you want a good local place, this is superior to most.  Beats tourist traps and isn't pricey like Sebo.
author: Christian W.

description: I'm SO happy we tried this place!  It's a nice cozy atmosphere with delicious sushi (ALL 6 of the rolls we tried were TASTY), great service, and reasonable prices.  We're definitely coming back, especially with it being right down the street from our house!
author: Diana C.

description: This is a great addition to the neighborhood.  Good sushi, relaxing atmosphere, and a great hang out.  It's a lot more affordable than Sebo and you won't come out hungry.  The only downside is that there's usually a wait during weekends and the selection is good but not very large.
author: rose y.

description: Delicious Sexy Mama Roll, Kanpachi Carpaccio, and fresh sushi.  They run out every once in a while on the specials so get there early.  the Salmon Skin roll is also especially delicious.  It is a small-er establishment so it is best for an intimate snack for two with some unfiltered sake.
author: Diana L.

description: Worthwhile destination in Hayes Valley for unique sushi.  Very small and can be a tough table at prominent times.  Fish tacos are worth the visit alone, IMO.
author: J A.

description:
Rolls are amazing - go with the following:

firecracker, omega, kobe beef roll, unagi roll

bluefin toro sashimi is one of the best in the city

hamachi is amazing too

service is good, but the place can be a little cramped
author: blahblah h.

description: This is a tiny little place nestled in Hayes Valley & it is amazing. THe fish is so fresh, it melts in your mouth. They have this great appetizer called 'Firecracker Balls' which are a must have. This place is busy but they by no means turn tables or make you feel rushed. This is a great date place but definitely not for a crowd.
author: Heather M.

description: Deliciousley, awesomely fresh, times 10! Plus dinner with my main micheal and hunny made it all the more better.
author: Douggers M.

description: Hmmmm, I really can't vibe with the negative reviews of this ultra-delish and ultra-hip sushi joint.  It's not  yer average sushi place, which I actually LIKE.  They really know how to add some pizzazz to your typical roll.  The sake is also mighty good.  I will go here again and again and again and again...
author: Luna K.

description:
i'm pretty stoked to have another good sushi option relatively close to my place. this place is pretty small, so i was surprised that we were able to get seated right away - even at the bar no less! i wasn't too hungry so i only ordered a few items. i got my usual staple items - maguro and albacore nigiris. i also got a couple of little appetizers (called "small crudos" on the menu). they are served on spoons. i got the spicey tuna, crab, and uni ones. this was my first time trying uni. i don't think i enjoy the texture of it so much, so i think that might also be the last time i try uni. i also recommend trying the firecracker balls. delicious!

the service was also very good here. i'll definately be back.
author: James J.

description:
I love this place!  Go early because the place fills up fast, and the more people, the longer you'll wait for your food.  

I usually order 1 each of the crudos as soon as I sit down.  everything on the special menu (on the wall) is delicious, and if you're having an indecisive moment, just ask the chef.  He knows what he's serving, and I noticed that he will tinker with recipes if he feels he can make an improvement.  I even brought my mom here (traditional Japanese lady), and she liked everything she ate.  I prefer sitting in front of the chefs so I can chat with them, but nothing wrong with sitting on the other side.  It's difficult for servers to look over your shoulders, so go easy on them if they don't take your empty plate right away or fill your tea cup - the key is communication here.

the only negative I can find would be that it's not family or group friendly due to the bar chair seating - you do have an option of sitting outside, but evenings in the city gets a bit too chilly.
author: Momof T.

description: Best sushi I've had since Sansei's in Maui.  Freshest fish.  Dragon, spider, rock n roll, various nigiri...not much to really say since the taste all speaks for itself.   The waitress went out of her way to accomodate the four of us, no short order given how tiny the place it.   Pretty expensive, but since it's the best sushi I've had in the bay area, the price is warranted.  Fantastic!
author: Blah B.

description: Love this place!  The food and service are great here!  I love the fire cracker balls!  The chefs are really nice too!
author: Laura H.

description: Love the Domo Roll, the Spicy Hulk, and the Crudos. The restaurant is tiny and the seating isn't very spacious, but th great food and good service more than makes up for it.
author: Vijay C.

description: My boyfriend and I love Domo. The fish is consistently fresh and delicious and the menu offers something for everyone. They offer everything from spicy firecracker balls (amazing ) to light and fresh crudos. The staff is extremely attentive and gracious (Raoul is the man). Only downside - this place is tiny, tiny so don't make the mistake of getting there at 8 on a Saturday - you will wait. good news - the staff is nice enough to allow you to leave and walk across the street for a glass of wine or a beer while you wait...
author: Lee H.

description:
Had dinner @ DOMO tonight...the spa music was a bit too much. Now, don't get me wrong -- great addition to the neighborhood. But, there is going to be some bitch slapping to get seated in the restaurant on a weekend...em bitches in high heals who come in from the Marina to the trendy Hayes Valley. 
Oh. The sushi was decent. fresh...the ginga was fresh.
author: Jack F.

description: Daikon salad, soft shell crab roll, black beer - fresh, flavorful, impeccable. I live in the 'hood and strolled over to have a bite on a Saturday night,  hoping to sit at the bar and eat while reading another chapter of Keith Richards' autobiography. Quickly got a seat and thoroughly enjoyed the experience. Hip but welcoming atmosphere, efficient, friendly service and delicious sushi.
author: rosemary p.

description: Awesome sushi spot.  A little pricy, but that's ok because the fish is very fresh and very high quality.  I highly recommend this place if you're looking for great sushi in Hayes Valley.
author: Daniel B.

description: Do you ever go to a sushi restaurant and order the spicy tuna roll and it turns out to be really really spicy? Don't get me wrong, i LOVE spicy, but sometimes it just overpowers my palette and i can't taste anything. But you won't get that with the firecracker balls from domo! They were little balls of heaven! ugh just thinking about them makes my mouth water. The perfect amount of spice and fried crispiness and sauce...wow. Their jalapeno hamachi was mighty delicious as well, super fresh ingredients and you can taste the goodness. You might be thinking, jalapeno..is it spicy? NOPE! well, maybe just a tad but you mainly taste the fresh jalapeno taste without the tongue burning sensation cause the seeds don't come with it. The one roll i wasn't too crazy about was the salmon avocado lemon roll. It sounds like a great idea for a roll but the lemon overpowered the salmon and avocado. But all in all i really enjoyed my meal and i will definitely be coming back! (and it doesn't hurt that it's in a cute neighborhood!)
author: Suzan L.

description: Hole-in-the-wall tiny, but they certainly make the most of their space with the decor. It's coziness is made even more inviting by the really sweet staff. Wonderful service and absolutely delicious sushi. They don't have a lot on the menu (really only one vegetarian role -- but I could eat it again and again), but 'less is more' holds true in this case. Welcome to the hood! So happy to have you, new go-to sushi place.
author: Emily S.

description: Just what that hood has needed! Casual spot, just enough chic, delish sushi, totally reasonable prices.
author: Tracie B.

description:
One of the best sushi restaurants I've been to in SF. Only con is that it's a bit small so not good for large groups, but if you want great sushi, reasonable prices, excellent service, and all of this with just a few people,  you can't beat this place. 

They don't have a billion different rolls, but the ones they do have are so well prepared and very good. The prices are very reasonable ($10-12) and the sashimi is great. Also, great central location in Hayes Valley.  It's exactly what my neighborhood needed. Party in my mouth.
author: pankaj l.

description: I've been on this sushi rampage lately and tried this place for lunch a few weeks ago.  Awesome sashimi, fresh and tasty.  Ate outside on a sunny afternoon which added to the whole experience.  There are no tables inside, just sushi bar and counter eating, so not a date place.  The spicy tuna roll was good, but I will say their signature roll (think it was called the domo roll) was a bit of a disappointment...it's actually baked and the rice stuck to the tin foil.  Creative and yummy but not too easy to eat.
author: Eric C.

description:
Reasonably priced sushi in SF, in a trendy neighborhood, with good quality sushi??!    You're not gonna find better in SF.  No wonder it's usually overflowing onto the sidewalk.  Luckily we went early (I hear it gets insane here anytime after 6pm).  Three of us went, ordered a ton of food and a few rounds of beers to go with it, and still didn't come close to breaking the bank.  

 It was refreshing to see sushi done in a unique/creative fashion without just piling on crazy ingredients.   They really made the rolls enjoyable and fun, without over-doing it.  If I can find an evening to get there early again, I will be heading back for sure!!
author: N G.

description: My wife and I visiting some friends in San Francisco and we found this little gem right in the heart of Hayes Valley!  We had almost everything that Domo offer in 2 straight nights.  We had the famous firecracker, whole bunch of rolls and chef choice of deluxe sashimi and I was very impress with the freshness including live lobster sashimi.  Best I had in SF!!!!  Keep it up Domo!!!!
author: michael k.

description: Not impressed. I've had better sushi at many other restaurants and I did not appreciate the service. The waitress was unfriendly from the start and also got my order wrong. I like the location and setting, but I doubt I'll be coming back.
author: Susanna C.

description:
Ever since Naked Fish changed management, I've been looking for a staple  sushi joint.  Although not in my neighborhood, I'll make the trek to Hayes Valley any day to eat at Domo.

Firecracker balls?  Perfect.  Filled with tuna, not over fried, and unagi glaze/spicy mayo sauce combo truly dances on your taste buds.  The domo roll reminds me of the hot mama at naked fish - but fresher, better sauce, and more crab and salmon.  The more traditional options are equally satisfying - the hamachi belly melted perfectly in my mouth and tasted fabulous with both scallions in the negi-hama roll and with jalapenos in the hamachi-jalapeno roll.  Fresh, generous fish portions, and just perfectly executed.

The place is tiny, but get a seat at the bar overlooking Laguna and you'll have a fabulous time admiring the cute up-coming neighborhood and people watching.  I wish I lived down the block, it's truly the essence of your neighborhood sushi joint.

And if that wasn't enough...  4 rolls, edamame, 2 beers, and a tea = $50.  Done and done.
author: Casey M.

description: Great Great place.  Good food and a fantastic menu.  The owner is a sweetheart.  It is quite cozy and isn't for a large party... great for a twosome.  The bathroom is a huge plus - its spotless.  Reasonably priced and good service.
author: Jennifer V.

description: Definitely going to become one of the favorites. Nice and cozy and a very, very good food.
author: Irina K.

description:
ultra small, ultra cute, ultra gooOOod!

the dishes are innovative and ultra tasty. go with one or two people max. try the 'spicy hulk', asparagus roll, and the crudo's. holler.
author: C. G.

description: Two words- FIRECRACKER BALLS!!! Oh my gosh, soooooooooooooooooo good!
author: Rabia K.

description:
After art class, we were craving some sushi so I mentioned Sushi Zone to the gals and we stopped by to check out the status of the line.  We were fooled by only 4 people waiting at the door, until we realized that there was a white board listing 10 other parties that were waiting for a spot in stealth mode.
Z mentioned that there was a cute spot on Hayes that we should take a look at, but it might be swanky.  The place turned out to be Sebo and as we were checking out the overpriced menu, a guy named Niko told us to walk around the block and check out Domo instead. 

We had 5 rolls and sake for the 3 of us and were decently satisfied.  The 2 hamachi rolls we had, one with jalepeno and one with out, were tiny.   Sexy mama was tasty as was the spicy tuna.   
Would come back to check out the 10 lunch special.
author: Kelly G.

description:
it's a cute lil place but the sushi just didn't do it for me ... 

o mai gawd ... i've been on a MAJOR* japanese binge lately ...  lol, let's just say, i'm STILL craving sushi even though i JUST had it ... which means, i didn't get my sushi fix ... stay tuned for tomorrow's review in what i decide to nibble .. hint? another japanese joint ... 

the set up is quite contemporary, but rather super small, and quite squishy ... the bar was kinda set up like koo's ...nonetheless, the wait wasn't horrendous, but watchin the folks outside wait patiently wasn't a great way to enjoy a sushi dinner ... you want prime seating, better to face the chefs so you don't feel guilty enjoying your sushi as you eat your sushi aways facing the crowd... lol.

like koo's spoonful of happiness (http://www.yelp.com/user_details_review_search?userid=EKdyI4jpUF29YtPkKiCtcg&q=koo)
you could choose any 2 small crudos for $5.95 so we went for their uni and spicy tuna ... the uni was tastier at koo ... their nigiri wasn't exactly super fresh, but edible, not rotten to say the very least ... service? well, the server, however, was extremely cheery, despite the craziness and we did feel that we were being accomodated ... average price of sushi...  you're looking at an average of $8 and up for a creative, speciality roll ... 
lots of 4 & 5 stars for this place ... makes me wonder whether the whole world on yelp really KNOWS what sushi is supposed to taste like ... i'd give it a 4 for the vibe though ...

PS. $20 credit card min fee.

sry domo, disappointed ... the extra star = location.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
doumo, konnichiwa!  

Well Hello there!  No this Domo is not the strange creature that hatched from an egg, who is known to pass gas at the first sign of nervousness or discomfort.  Domo is a fresh new take on Japanese food in Hayes Valley.

The food at this tiny Japanese sushi bar is a mix of simple favorites complimented by trendy creative concoctions. The food is definitely worth the wait.  To pass the time order a beer or some sake, you won't be disappointed.

To start off our meal we ordered some 'small crudos'.  Individual sized servings of deliciousness.  The presentation was simple and the experience was all about the food.  The small crudos were followed by a handpicked sampling of Nigiri and two different kinds of rolls; Sexy Mama and Crunch California Roll.  The Nigiri was served up with a good fish to rice ratio and the rolls each had a signature kick.

The prices are reasonable and the food... oishii!

This place would best be enjoyed with a single companion.  The place is small and not designed for big groups, as most Sushi bars are.

Domo arigato gozaimasu!
author: Ashley Q.

description: One of the very best. Loves it. The best nigiri! SO well sliced very thin and not too much rice, when you want nigiri who wants it on a huge bed of rice? Simply great.
author: Jay S.

description: my recommendations. spicy hulk, Fire Cracker Balls, kobe beef roll..
author: amit s.

description:
ate there with my toddler.  definitely not kid/family friendly place because the place is small and cramp and have to sit at counter-top
which not the most comfortable if you want to relax or have a bad back.  Asked the waitress what she recommended and it was pretty much what has been yelped about........firecracker balls, domo roll, etc.   I found everything to be average, not outstanding.  They definitely was pushing the various rolls.  Had a few sushi, such as Hamachi and albacore tuna.  They were fresh, but not very generous slices ,  
My summation is that it is more of an  "Americanized" sushi restaurants.  Go there if you don't mind difficult parking, a cramp restaurant and if you are primarily interested in funky rolls.  Price is average.
author: jason l.

description: Let me just start by putting my cards out on the table here. This is seriously some of the best sushi I've had in a while. A long while. The fish was deliciously fresh and the service was really nice, as our server walked us through the specials, was very attentive to our needs, etc. The sushi came out really fast -- almost too fast, but you can't fault a sushi artist for making his/her stuff quickly! The environment is classic Japanese-chic - VERY small inside, but very tastefully decorated. This is an great date-place, as my date and I noticed everyone that was there was in pairs of two. Probably not the best place to take the entire team for a work lunch, as there's just no room inside. But really, who cares - let's get back to the sushi! We ordered the Mac Daddy, Firecracker Balls and the Spicy Hulk. The Mac Daddy was amazing - featuring ocean trout and a bunch of other stuff. As other yelpers have mentioned, the FireCracker Balls are super-tasty. In fact, all three rolls were just excellent. Admit it, you don't want to read any more of this, you just want to go and try it yourself... enjoy!
author: Jono K.

description:
... randomly stumbled upon this place wandering aimlessly around sf with a bunch of hungry doods after being told that the restaurant we originally wanted to go to had a 1hr 40min wait.  what can i say about sushi places?  i love sushi but after eating at about a million different sushi joints they kind of all start to taste the same, falling into one of two categories - 'nasty' & 'not nasty'.  this place falls under the 'not nasty'  category.

i will say this: they make their rolls just the way i like them - very little rice & sauce.  hamachi melted in my mouth.  tasmanian trout had a weird lime-ish taste to it (i much prefer my fish with lemon), but it wasn't nasty.  i also had this fish taco thingy that was all right.  like i said, not nasty.

we were seated outside & the service wasn't compromised.  super nice bathroom.  there's a peephole on the bathroom door.  cute.
author: K-Y    j i L L y.

description: Really good prices, not much of a selection, but great quality fish. Priced like Wasabi and Ginger, but better atmosphere and more innovative.
author: Mia T.

description: Domo is the best!  Always fresh, delicious and the service is great.  Limited seating but that adds to the atmosphere.
author: Nicolette L.

description: Had lunch with a date. I expected a little bit pricey and the food to be OK.  What I got was below average sushi and sizes that are a joke.  The prices given the size are terrible.  Would not go back.  Also, there are no tables whatsoever so they should call themselves a sushi stand not a restaurant.
author: Z A.

description: I love DOMO!!!! The food just melts in your mouth. It's fresh. It's delicious. It is one of my favorite Sushi places!!! Domo is a cozy, relaxing and the service is great!  mmmmm I'm craving their sushi!!!
author: Jag B.

description: 3.5 I'll not claim to be an aficionado of sushi, but I do like Domo. It's a cute place to meet a friend (ONE friend. do not try to go here with 3+ people because there's not really any suitable seating) and the sushi is generally tasty. The rolls are particularly good, but they write them on this mirror that makes them almost impossible to read. My companion and I were seated at a table where we didnt' even have a clear line of sight to the big mirror, and when we asked our server if she could sort of summarize what was on there, she sighed. I know its kind of weird to ask someone to read you the menu, but she could have just pointed out a few things or engaged us about what we were interested in or something. Overall, its a pretty good value, and they have takeout lunch boxes that I like (though not too many options). I would give it 4 stars except it often smells so much like lysol that its unpleasant (I know, this is kind of a double-edged-sword.)
author: Julia G.

description: I couldn't ask for more in my neighborhood sushi spot. Excellent sushi, moderate price, though not cheap by any stretch of the imagination. It's definitely not traditional, so if that's what you're into, don't go. If you like crazy rolls, you'll love it--don't miss the firecracker balls (I could eat these everyday for the rest of my life and die a happy man) and spicy hulk roll!
author: Xander M.

description: Nothing super fancy.  The sushi is OK.  For the price you pay, you could get better sushi down the street at Otoro.
author: F S.

description: with the pretension choking me to death at sebo, it was a blessing to have domo open. the food is delicious and the chef is cool as shit. with il borgo, modern tea, and double decker around the way, all i need is a taqueria and ramen house and i'll never leave my hood.
author: stephen a.

description: i went here for the first time last weekend, and even though i had to cut my meal short b/c of an allergy attack (unrelated to the food!), i highly enjoyed my experience there. the place is small (think cozy and intimate), the lighting is dim and the food is delicious. prepare to wait a little while for a table, though.
author: Elle B.

description: Absolutely delicious sushi but the space is very small. This place is made for couples but not for larger groups. The service is great, but the wait can be somewhat long.  Ultimately I do recommend it highly because the sushi is absolutely delicious!!!!
author: Lola W.
